IDENTIFICATION: Correlate repeated authentication failures against a single identity object or small identity set.
Detect success events following high-velocity failure bursts from the same hostile node.
Compare activity against historical baselines for the identity realm and access channel.
CONTAINMENT: Suspend or lock the targeted identity object pending validation with asset owner.
Invalidate and revoke all active sessions and tokens associated with the identity object.
Quarantine the hostile node at perimeter and internal segmentation controls.
COUNTERMEASURES: Enforce multi-factor or adaptive authentication on the affected access pathways.
Deploy rate-limiting and lockout thresholds on exposed authentication interfaces.
Harden credential policies, including password length, rotation, and reuse restrictions.
FORENSICS: Extract authentication telemetry covering the full brute force window for archival.
Construct a timeline of attempts, successes, and cross-identity targeting patterns.
Preserve logs from identity providers, VPN concentrators, and edge gateways in cold storage.

IDENTIFICATION: Identify unusual command-line or scripting interpreter invocations on monitored hosts.
Correlate execution events with non-standard parent processes or service accounts.
Detect use of obfuscated, encoded, or downloaded script content from untrusted sources.
CONTAINMENT: Isolate the affected host from non-essential network segments pending triage.
Terminate identified malicious or suspicious interpreter processes and descendants.
Revoke or reset credentials used to launch unauthorized interpreter activity.
COUNTERMEASURES: Apply application control or script control policies to restrict interpreter misuse.
Limit scripting engine permissions for non-administrative and service identities.
Deploy monitoring for high-risk interpreter flags, encoded payloads, and remote includes.
FORENSICS: Capture process trees, command-line arguments, and associated script artifacts.
Acquire volatile memory images where feasible for deeper payload reconstruction.
Archive endpoint detection telemetry and OS logs tied to the execution timeline.

IDENTIFICATION: Detect sustained outbound data transfers to rare or previously unseen external endpoints.
Identify encrypted or covert channels piggybacking on established C2 infrastructure.
Correlate data movement with prior privilege escalation or credential theft events.
CONTAINMENT: Block outbound communications to the identified hostile endpoints at all egress points.
Suspend compromised identities and systems used as exfiltration pivots.
Increase inspection and rate-limiting on similar outbound protocols and ports.
COUNTERMEASURES: Implement strict egress filtering and domain allow-listing for critical environments.
Deploy data loss prevention or content inspection on high-risk network paths.
Instrument anomaly-based detection for abnormal transfer size, timing, and destinations.
FORENSICS: Preserve netflow, proxy, and firewall telemetry for the exfiltration window.
Reconstruct data volume estimates and approximate content classes exfiltrated.
Record all identified C2 endpoints, domains, and certificates for threat intelligence reuse.

IDENTIFICATION: Detect inbound messages containing suspicious URLs, attachments, or spoofed sender identities.
Correlate user-report signals with downstream authentication anomalies or malware events.
Inspect messages targeting high-value roles, administrators, or financial operators.
CONTAINMENT: Quarantine the malicious messages and recall similar messages where supported.
Disable or reset credentials for users who interacted with hostile content.
Block identified sender domains, IP ranges, and malicious URLs at email and web gateways.
COUNTERMEASURES: Deploy advanced phishing protection, including URL rewriting and attachment sandboxing.
Enforce security awareness cadence for users frequently targeted or compromised.
Align email authentication controls such as SPF, DKIM, and DMARC with strict policies.
FORENSICS: Archive the full message artifacts, headers, and attachment payloads.
Document targeted users, lure themes, and infrastructure indicators for campaign tracking.
Correlate with wider threat intelligence to attribute recurring phishing operators.

T1027.TITLE: Defense Evasion – Obfuscated or Encrypted Payloads

IDENTIFICATION: Identify binaries, scripts, or archives exhibiting packing, heavy obfuscation, or encryption.
Detect repeated execution of unpacking tools or custom loaders on monitored hosts.
Correlate opaque payload delivery with bypassed or suppressed security alerts.
CONTAINMENT: Isolate affected systems from untrusted networks pending deeper inspection.
Suspend execution of the suspicious payloads and associated loader processes.
Temporarily elevate monitoring thresholds around the impacted host group.
COUNTERMEASURES: Deploy static and dynamic analysis workflows to inspect and detonate suspicious payloads.
Enhance endpoint policies to block known packers and unapproved encryption utilities.
Instrument detection for abnormal archive formats, entropy levels, and nested packaging.
FORENSICS: Preserve the original payloads, loaders, and any unpacked artifacts in secure storage.
Capture endpoint logs detailing file creation, modification, and execution ordering.
Document detection gaps exploited by the obfuscated payload for control improvements.

IDENTIFICATION: Detect logins from valid accounts exhibiting anomalous geography, timing, or device profiles.
Correlate newly observed access patterns with prior credential theft or phishing events.
Identify concurrent logins for the same identity object from incompatible locations.
CONTAINMENT: Force sign-out and revoke active sessions for the suspected identities.
Temporarily disable affected accounts pending secure credential reset.
Block suspicious source IPs and device fingerprints at access control layers.
COUNTERMEASURES: Enforce strong multi-factor authentication and conditional access policies.
Segment administrative accounts and require hardened access pathways.
Monitor privileged identities with heightened behavioral analytics and alerting.
FORENSICS: Export authentication telemetry for the full compromise period for archival.
Reconstruct access patterns, resource touches, and administrative changes.
Record all affected identities and dependent systems for follow-up review.

IDENTIFICATION: Detect unusual process memory modification, remote thread creation, or DLL injection activity.
Correlate injected processes with unexpected parent relationships or non-standard binaries.
Identify security tool processes exhibiting anomalous behavior or code sections.
CONTAINMENT: Isolate the affected host from the network for containment.
Terminate injected and associated parent processes after memory capture when feasible.
Revoke credentials used by processes implicated in the injection chain.
COUNTERMEASURES: Harden endpoint protections to block untrusted code injection patterns and APIs.
Deploy exploit mitigation features such as code integrity and memory protection.
Limit local administrative access and script execution capabilities at endpoints.
FORENSICS: Capture full memory images of impacted hosts for offline analysis.
Preserve endpoint logs documenting process creations, module loads, and handle operations.
Document injection techniques observed for rule and detection signature enhancement.

IDENTIFICATION: Detect access to LSASS, SAM, or security hive artifacts by non-standard processes.
Identify execution of known credential dumping utilities or equivalent behaviors.
Correlate credential dumping attempts with subsequent lateral movement or privilege escalation.
CONTAINMENT: Isolate the host performing credential dumping from lateral communication.
Force system reboot after securing forensic artifacts where operationally acceptable.
Rotate credentials for local, domain, and service accounts potentially exposed.
COUNTERMEASURES: Implement LSASS protection and restrict debug privileges to tightly controlled roles.
Remove interactive logon rights from high-privilege accounts on endpoints.
Deploy monitoring for suspicious access patterns to credential stores and memory.
FORENSICS: Archive security, system, and endpoint logs tied to the dumping event.
Capture tool hashes, command lines, and access timestamps for intelligence reuse.
Compile a list of accounts active on the system during the compromise window.

IDENTIFICATION: Identify enumeration commands querying users, groups, or directory structures at scale.
Correlate discovery commands from newly compromised or low-reputation hosts.
Detect repetitive directory or API enumeration from non-administrative identities.
CONTAINMENT: Monitor the origin host for escalation attempts and lateral movement.
Restrict directory query capabilities for non-essential identities.
Flag and review recent privilege changes for the querying identity object.
COUNTERMEASURES: Apply least-privilege models to directory and identity information access.
Segment administrative directories and service accounts away from general access.
Instrument detection for high-volume or scripted directory enumeration signatures.
FORENSICS: Preserve directory service and authentication logs around the enumeration window.
Record queried objects, groups, and organizational units for impact assessment.
Correlate enumeration attempts with other reconnaissance or intrusion phases.

IDENTIFICATION: Detect rapid file encryption or extension changes across multiple directories or hosts.
Identify creation of ransom notes or uniform instructions across the environment.
Correlate file-access anomalies with suspicious process origins or new binaries.
CONTAINMENT: Immediately isolate impacted hosts from shared storage and the wider network.
Disable compromised identities tied to the encryption processes.
Suspend automated deletion or rotation of backups pending integrity validation.
COUNTERMEASURES: Enforce application allow-listing to prevent unauthorized encryptors from executing.
Segment critical data stores and limit write access to tightly controlled identities.
Maintain immutable and offline backups with routine restoration testing.
FORENSICS: Preserve copies of ransom notes, encryption binaries, and associated artifacts.
Document impacted systems, data sets, and encryption timelines.
Collect payment channel indicators, such as wallets or contact addresses, for intelligence.

T1105.TITLE: Command and Control – Ingress Tool Transfer

IDENTIFICATION: Detect inbound file transfers from suspicious external endpoints to internal hosts.
Identify tools staged in temporary or unusual directories ahead of execution.
Correlate transfers with command-and-control beacons or newly opened connections.
CONTAINMENT: Block further inbound transfers from identified hostile infrastructure.
Quarantine hosts that received unauthorized tools pending review.
Invalidate credentials on hosts where unauthorized tools were executed.
COUNTERMEASURES: Constrain direct inbound access and require brokered or proxied administrative channels.
Deploy inspection on file transfer protocols to detect executable or archive delivery.
Alert on staging behaviors such as tools dropped then renamed or relocated.
FORENSICS: Archive transfer logs, including file hashes, sizes, and source endpoints.
Catalog received tooling and compare against known offensive frameworks and malware.
Establish a linkage between ingress tools and subsequent attacker actions.

IDENTIFICATION: Identify long-lived outbound connections over ports not typically used by monitored hosts.
Detect protocol misuse where application signatures do not match the underlying port.
Correlate suspicious non-standard port usage with prior compromise indicators.
CONTAINMENT: Block or rate-limit suspicious connections on non-standard ports at egress points.
Inspect and, where necessary, terminate suspect tunnels carrying opaque traffic.
Increase scrutiny on hosts establishing repeated connections on anomalous ports.
COUNTERMEASURES: Implement strict egress-control policies defining permitted protocols and ports.
Deploy deep packet inspection where feasible to validate protocol adherence.
Instrument detection for beacon-like timing and jitter patterns on rare ports.
FORENSICS: Preserve firewall, proxy, and netflow logs tied to suspect non-standard connections.
Map observed ports, destinations, and durations for campaign tracking.
Correlate with threat intelligence to identify reused infrastructure.

T1547.TITLE: Persistence – Boot or Logon Autostart Execution

IDENTIFICATION: Detect new or modified autostart entries in registry, startup folders, or service lists.
Correlate persistence mechanisms with newly introduced binaries or scripts.
Identify autostart items created by non-standard parent processes or low-reputation users.
CONTAINMENT: Disable or remove malicious autostart entries after forensic capture.
Isolate affected hosts from sensitive segments pending full review.
Revoke credentials of identities that deployed unauthorized persistence.
COUNTERMEASURES: Apply configuration baselines and integrity monitoring to autostart locations.
Limit permissions to modify autostart mechanisms to tightly controlled administrators.
Instrument alerts for deviations from approved startup and service inventories.
FORENSICS: Capture current autostart configurations and compare against historical baselines.
Archive registry hives and service configurations for offline review.
Document persistence type, location, and associated binaries for threat profiles.

IDENTIFICATION: Identify creation or modification of scheduled tasks or cron jobs by unapproved identities.
Detect tasks configured with suspicious commands, scripts, or remote payload locations.
Correlate new tasks with prior compromise or privilege escalation events on the host.
CONTAINMENT: Disable or delete malicious scheduled tasks after acquisition of configuration details.
Isolate hosts running rogue tasks from critical network segments.
Rotate or revoke credentials used to configure or execute hostile tasks.
COUNTERMEASURES: Enforce approval workflows and logging for creation of scheduled tasks.
Restrict task creation permissions to designated administrative groups.
Deploy monitoring for tasks invoking interpreters, remote shares, or encoded commands.
FORENSICS: Export task or cron configurations and execution histories for archival.
Record task names, triggers, and command lines for campaign correlation.
Associate malicious tasks with file system and network activity over time.

T1222.TITLE: Privilege Escalation – File and Directory Permissions Modification

IDENTIFICATION: Detect modifications to file and directory permissions on security-critical paths.
Identify privilege grants that deviate from baseline access-control models.
Correlate permission changes with new executable deployments or service changes.
CONTAINMENT: Revert unauthorized permission changes to last known good baseline.
Temporarily restrict access to sensitive paths pending impact assessment.
Review and, if required, suspend identities responsible for risky modifications.
COUNTERMEASURES: Implement configuration management enforcing strict ACL baselines.
Limit the set of administrators authorized to alter critical permissions.
Monitor for privilege inheritance abuses and world-writable or executable flags.
FORENSICS: Archive file-system audit logs and ACL change histories for the incident window.
Document affected objects, previous permissions, and unauthorized deltas.
Correlate with lateral movement or execution events that used modified paths.

IDENTIFICATION: Detect disabling, uninstalling, or tampering with security agents and logging services.
Identify configuration changes that reduce alerting, coverage, or control strength.
Correlate impairment attempts with concurrent privilege escalation or tool deployment.
CONTAINMENT: Restore security tooling and logging configurations to enforced baselines.
Isolate hosts where defenses were impaired from trust-sensitive zones.
Revoke privileges from identities that modified security configurations.
COUNTERMEASURES: Enforce tamper protection and self-defense mechanisms on security agents.
Centralize configuration management and disallow local override of logging and controls.
Alert on any attempt to disable, suspend, or uninstall protective technologies.
FORENSICS: Preserve logs from configuration management, security platforms, and OS sources.
Document the sequence and scope of defense impairment across systems.
Capture tool and user identifiers associated with the impairment activity.

T1497.TITLE: Defense Evasion – Virtualization or Sandbox Evasion

IDENTIFICATION: Detect processes performing environment checks for virtualization, debuggers, or sandboxes.
Identify malware that alters behavior when instrumentation or analysis tools are present.
Correlate evasive checks with later-stage payload deployment or delayed execution.
CONTAINMENT: Increase monitoring for hosts where evasive behavior was detected.
Isolate suspect hosts and prevent them from reaching external command infrastructure.
Block known evasive samples and associated indicators across the environment.
COUNTERMEASURES: Enhance sandboxing and analysis environments to better emulate production conditions.
Deploy behavior-based detection that does not rely solely on sandbox verdicts.
Monitor for repeated failed detonation attempts or samples that self-terminate under analysis.
FORENSICS: Archive logs and telemetry from analysis platforms and affected endpoints.
Record environment checks and anti-analysis techniques used by hostile code.
Use evasive behavior profiles to refine future malware triage workflows.

IDENTIFICATION: Detect anomalous token theft, duplication, or impersonation events on endpoints.
Identify processes assuming higher-privilege tokens than expected for their identity.
Correlate token misuse with lateral movement attempts and administrative actions.
CONTAINMENT: Terminate processes associated with illegitimate token operations.
Force logoff for affected identities and invalidate related sessions.
Temporarily restrict administrative token usage while scope is assessed.
COUNTERMEASURES: Limit token-related privileges to heavily controlled administrative identities.
Deploy monitoring for token manipulation APIs and known offensive tooling behaviors.
Separate duties so high-privilege accounts are not used for routine interactive logons.
FORENSICS: Archive security logs capturing logon, logoff, and token-related events.
Document identities, hosts, and sessions linked to manipulated tokens.
Correlate token misuse with any configuration or data-access anomalies.

IDENTIFICATION: Detect file copies or tool transfers between internal hosts using administrative channels.
Identify staging of consoles, frameworks, or custom tooling on non-administrative systems.
Correlate tool transfer with new service creation, scheduled tasks, or remote execution.
CONTAINMENT: Restrict or terminate remote file transfer channels used for unauthorized staging.
Quarantine systems acting as tool distribution hubs during the incident.
Rotate credentials used with administrative protocols leveraged for transfer.
COUNTERMEASURES: Constrain administrative protocols such as SMB and WinRM to controlled management paths.
Deploy monitoring for high-risk tool names, hashes, and directory usage.
Implement just-in-time access models for administrative sessions and tool use.
FORENSICS: Preserve logs showing inter-host file transfers, including source, destination, and hashes.
Record hosts where offensive tooling was staged or executed.
Associate tool movement with corresponding authentication and execution telemetry.

IDENTIFICATION: Detect unusual RDP, SSH, or SMB logons between internal hosts.
Identify remote service usage from accounts or hosts that rarely initiate such sessions.
Correlate remote logons with prior credential abuse, discovery, or persistence activity.
CONTAINMENT: Limit or suspend remote service access for compromised identities.
Quarantine high-risk hosts that initiated unauthorized remote sessions.
Tighten firewall policies to reduce unnecessary inter-host remote service exposure.
COUNTERMEASURES: Implement strong authentication and authorization for all remote services.
Segment administrative management networks separate from user subnets.
Monitor for new or unexpected remote service endpoints and listeners.
FORENSICS: Archive remote access logs from endpoints, servers, and network devices.
Map remote session paths taken by the hostile operator across the environment.
Document service types, accounts, and timeframes for later incident reconstruction.

IDENTIFICATION: Detect changes to authentication modules, plugins, or provider configuration.
Identify insertion of unauthorized authentication handlers or credential interceptors.
Correlate authentication pipeline changes with new persistence or credential access behavior.
CONTAINMENT: Revert authentication configurations to approved, signed baselines.
Invalidate tokens and sessions issued after the suspected modification time.
Restrict access to systems hosting authentication components until validated.
COUNTERMEASURES: Harden authentication infrastructure with signed modules and integrity checks.
Limit who can modify authentication configuration to a minimal, audited group.
Instrument alerts for configuration drift in identity and access systems.
FORENSICS: Preserve configuration files, registry entries, and change logs for authentication systems.
Record all modified modules, their sources, and observed behavior.
Correlate with suspicious logons, privilege changes, or data-access anomalies.

IDENTIFICATION: Identify staging of tools, payloads, or infrastructure components in preparation for operations.
Detect registration or acquisition of domains and certificates used for later campaigns when observable.
Correlate internal staging with testing behavior against decoy or non-critical systems.
CONTAINMENT: Monitor and restrict locations where offensive tooling can be stored or executed.
Remove discovered staging artifacts and block associated hashes and paths.
Increase surveillance on systems and identities involved in staging behaviors.
COUNTERMEASURES: Apply strict control over access to code repositories, build servers, and deployment paths.
Monitor for unapproved tooling and shadow infrastructure build-outs.
Leverage deception assets to surface adversary staging behaviors earlier.
FORENSICS: Archive evidence of staged tools, domains, and infrastructure components.
Track timelines between staging events and active exploitation phases.
Feed observed staging patterns into threat hunting and detection engineering.

IDENTIFICATION: Detect directory or command-line queries enumerating domain trusts and forest relationships.
Identify use of administrative tools from unusual hosts or identities to inspect trust paths.
Correlate trust discovery with lateral movement or privilege escalation attempts.
CONTAINMENT: Increase monitoring on discovered trust paths for unauthorized access attempts.
Restrict usage of tools capable of enumerating domain trusts to authorized administrators.
Review and, if needed, temporarily tighten trust relationships at high risk.
COUNTERMEASURES: Apply least-privilege principles to cross-domain and forest-level access.
Regularly review and justify all established domain and forest trust relationships.
Monitor for abnormal authentication flows traversing trust boundaries.
FORENSICS: Preserve directory service logs capturing trust queries and related actions.
Document all trust objects queried and the identities performing discovery.
Correlate trust discovery events with subsequent cross-domain activity.

IDENTIFICATION: Detect modifications to group policy objects or equivalent domain-level policy constructs.
Identify policy changes granting elevated rights, logon abilities, or relaxed security settings.
Correlate domain policy changes with new administrative group memberships or access patterns.
CONTAINMENT: Immediately review and revert unauthorized policy changes to last known good state.
Invalidate sessions potentially affected by malicious policy modifications.
Temporarily restrict administrative access to domain controllers while verifying integrity.
COUNTERMEASURES: Enforce change-control with multi-party approval for domain policy edits.
Segment duties so policy administration is separate from routine operational tasks.
Instrument real-time alerting for high-impact policy changes and privilege grants.
FORENSICS: Archive policy versions, change histories, and administrative logs for the impact window.
Record affected OUs, groups, and security settings altered during the incident.
Associate policy changes with any exploited access they enabled.

IDENTIFICATION: Identify acquisition or download of offensive frameworks, exploit kits, or malware packages.
Detect retrieval of tools from code repositories or sharing platforms not approved for use.
Correlate tool acquisition with subsequent scanning, exploitation, or credential theft activity.
CONTAINMENT: Block access to known distribution points for offensive tooling where appropriate.
Remove unapproved tools from internal hosts and storage locations.
Increase scrutiny of systems where offensive capabilities were staged.
COUNTERMEASURES: Restrict outbound access to high-risk code and tooling repositories.
Define and enforce a catalog of approved security testing tools and their usage.
Monitor for hash or signature matches to known offensive frameworks within the environment.
FORENSICS: Preserve logs showing capability acquisition, including URLs, repositories, and timestamps.
Catalog obtained tools, their functions, and associated threat actors when known.
Feed capability-obtainment intelligence into defensive content and training.

IDENTIFICATION: Detect processes or drivers intercepting keyboard or input events outside normal patterns.
Identify unauthorized installation of keylogging utilities or input-capture libraries.
Correlate input capture with credential use, sensitive application access, or data exfiltration.
CONTAINMENT: Isolate impacted hosts from sensitive resources and networks.
Terminate keylogging processes and remove associated binaries after evidence capture.
Rotate credentials used on systems where keylogging was active.
COUNTERMEASURES: Harden endpoint configurations to restrict low-level input hooks to trusted components.
Deploy monitoring for input-capture APIs and suspicious screen or keystroke logging behavior.
Educate operators on signs of compromised endpoints exhibiting abnormal input lag or focus changes.
FORENSICS: Preserve endpoint telemetry capturing process, driver, and input-hook activity.
Document duration, scope, and likely data types captured via keylogging.
Correlate keylogging windows with unauthorized logons or data-access events.

T1555.TITLE: Credential Access — Credentials from Password Stores

IDENTIFICATION: Identify access to browser password stores, database files, or credential vaults shortly before infostealer activity.
Detect unusual reads of login data files such as Chrome 'Login Data', Firefox key4.db, or Windows Credential Manager.
Correlate processes that open credential stores with unexpected network connections or data staging behavior.
CONTAINMENT: Reset all harvested or suspected-compromised user credentials.
Quarantine the affected host and block outbound communication to known infostealer infrastructure.
Invalidate tokens, cookies, and browser-synced credentials associated with the compromised user.
COUNTERMEASURES: Harden local credential storage by enabling OS-level encryption, DPAPI protections, and MFA requirements.
Deploy EDR monitoring for unauthorized reads of browser credential databases and password managers.
Educate users about unsafe browser storage and enforce enterprise-managed password vaults.
FORENSICS: Preserve credential store files for verification of unauthorized access or tampering.
Capture process execution trees around the suspected theft event to determine the exact extraction method.
Correlate stolen credential usage with subsequent login attempts or lateral movement.

IDENTIFICATION: Detect creation of new accounts with administrative or elevated roles outside of expected workflows.
Identify modifications to group memberships, role assignments, or login restrictions for existing accounts.
Correlate account manipulation with recent credential theft, MFA reset, or suspicious login activity.
CONTAINMENT: Revoke unauthorized role assignments and remove rogue accounts from privileged groups.
Invalidate active sessions and tokens belonging to manipulated identities.
Temporarily suspend accounts used to perform unauthorized changes pending investigation.
COUNTERMEASURES: Require multi-party approval and change-control for privileged account creation and role changes.
Enable alerting and logging for administrative operations on identities and groups.
Separate duties so identity administration is distinct from normal operational roles.
FORENSICS: Preserve IAM logs, directory service events, and change histories for affected accounts.
Document the timeline of account manipulation, including who initiated changes and from where.
Correlate identity changes with subsequent access to sensitive resources or configuration tampering.

IDENTIFICATION: Detect changes to authentication modules, plug-ins, or identity provider configuration.
Identify insertion of new authentication handlers or credential interception components.
Correlate modifications in the authentication pipeline with anomalous successes or bypassed MFA challenges.
CONTAINMENT: Revert authentication-related configuration to an approved baseline.
Invalidate active sessions and tokens created after the suspected modification time.
Temporarily restrict administrative access to identity systems until integrity is verified.
COUNTERMEASURES: Harden identity infrastructure with signed modules, code integrity, and configuration protection.
Limit who can modify authentication configuration to a small, audited administrative group.
Instrument alerting for any drift in identity provider, SSO, or MFA configuration.
FORENSICS: Archive configuration files, registry entries, and change logs associated with authentication systems.
Record all modules and handlers added or modified, along with their origins and hashes.
Correlate modifications with suspicious login behavior, privilege escalation, or data-access anomalies.

T1550.TITLE: Credential Access – Use of Alternate Authentication Material

IDENTIFICATION: Detect use of tokens, API keys, Kerberos tickets, or certificates that were not legitimately issued to the requesting principal.
Identify replay of authentication material from unusual devices, locations, or processes.
Correlate anomalous token use with known credential theft or keylogging activity.
CONTAINMENT: Revoke or invalidate compromised tokens, keys, and certificates.
Force re-issuance and re-enrollment for affected authentication material.
Block IPs, devices, or workloads that repeatedly attempt to use stolen or replayed credentials.
COUNTERMEASURES: Bind tokens to device, context, or hardware properties rather than static secrets alone.
Shorten token and key lifetimes and enforce rotation policies.
Instrument detection rules for token misuse, including impossible travel and multi-tenant anomalies.
FORENSICS: Preserve authentication logs, token issuance events, and certificate use history.
Determine when and where alternate material was first used and for what operations.
Correlate observed misuse with suspected infostealer or memory scraping events.

IDENTIFICATION: Detect high-rate connection attempts to multiple ports or services from a single source.
Identify scanning behavior targeting broad IP ranges, critical subnets, or management networks.
Correlate scan patterns with new, low-reputation, or compromised internal hosts.
CONTAINMENT: Throttle or block scanning source nodes at internal firewalls and network access controls.
Isolate compromised scanning hosts from sensitive network segments.
Notify responsible teams if scanning originates from sanctioned security tools to confirm legitimacy.
COUNTERMEASURES: Apply strict segmentation and limit visibility of high-value services to only required sources.
Deploy network intrusion detection tuned for port scans, service enumeration, and stealth probes.
Monitor for repeated scanning attempts following initial blocking or throttling.
FORENSICS: Archive netflow and firewall logs capturing scan behavior, ports, and protocols.
Document scan scope, targeted services, and any successful follow-on connections.
Correlate scanning with subsequent exploitation, lateral movement, or credential attacks.

IDENTIFICATION: Detect activation of packet capture utilities or interfaces placed into promiscuous mode.
Identify unauthorized use of network monitoring tools on non-monitoring hosts.
Correlate sniffing behavior with high-value traffic paths such as authentication or database segments.
CONTAINMENT: Terminate unauthorized packet capture processes and remove associated tooling.
Restrict the affected host’s access to sensitive network segments.
Rotate credentials and secrets passed over observed network paths if unencrypted.
COUNTERMEASURES: Encrypt traffic for authentication, database, and management protocols end-to-end.
Restrict installation and usage of packet capture tools to dedicated monitoring infrastructure.
Monitor for interfaces entering promiscuous mode and for creation of new capture files.
FORENSICS: Preserve network capture artifacts for analysis and legal review where policy permits.
Record hosts, interfaces, and time windows involved in sniffing activity.
Correlate network capture periods with downstream misuse of captured credentials or data.

IDENTIFICATION: Detect large or unusual uploads to web-based services such as storage platforms, file-sharing, or paste sites.
Identify outbound HTTP(S) requests with atypical payload sizes, frequencies, or destinations.
Correlate suspected data transfers with prior credential theft or staging events.
CONTAINMENT: Block or throttle access to suspicious web services at egress points.
Disable or restrict accounts used to authenticate to targeted web services.
Engage data-loss prevention or deeper inspection for high-risk outbound traffic classes.
COUNTERMEASURES: Define and enforce allow-lists for approved web storage and collaboration platforms.
Deploy DLP policies for uploads containing sensitive or regulated data.
Monitor for patterns of compression, encryption, and staging prior to outbound transfers.
FORENSICS: Preserve proxy, firewall, and web gateway logs for the exfiltration window.
Estimate data volumes and types transferred to each external service.
Correlate exfiltration events with affected identities, hosts, and repositories.

T1537.TITLE: Exfiltration – Transfer Data to Cloud Account

IDENTIFICATION: Detect large-scale data transfers from on-prem or other cloud services into attacker-controlled cloud accounts.
Identify new or unusual synchronization jobs, copy tasks, or replication activities.
Correlate data migration operations with compromised credentials or rogue automation accounts.
CONTAINMENT: Suspend or remove suspicious cloud connectors, sync agents, and automation identities.
Pause or cancel active transfer jobs associated with unverified destinations.
Restrict network and IAM permissions allowing data movement to external cloud tenants.
COUNTERMEASURES: Enforce strict IAM policies around cross-account data movement and replication.
Monitor for unsanctioned storage buckets, tenants, or external organization links.
Apply DLP controls on cloud-to-cloud transfers and backups.
FORENSICS: Preserve cloud activity logs detailing who initiated transfers, what data moved, and to where.
Document object paths, repositories, and data classes involved.
Correlate cloud transfers with earlier staging, compression, or discovery events.

T1530.TITLE: Collection – Data from Cloud Storage Object

IDENTIFICATION: Detect abnormal read operations against cloud storage objects containing sensitive data.
Identify bulk downloads or listing operations on buckets not typically accessed by the identity.
Correlate cloud storage access anomalies with recent role changes or credential use from new locations.
CONTAINMENT: Restrict access to affected storage objects and buckets to essential identities only.
Rotate access keys and tokens used to read from the compromised storage locations.
Temporarily enforce stricter access controls or require step-up authentication for sensitive objects.
COUNTERMEASURES: Apply least-privilege IAM policies to cloud storage resources.
Enable object-level logging, versioning, and access alerts for critical datasets.
Tag and classify sensitive storage objects to support targeted monitoring.
FORENSICS: Preserve cloud storage access logs and object change histories.
Determine what objects were accessed, by whom, and over what timeframe.
Correlate cloud storage activity with exfiltration or privilege escalation behavior.

T1528.TITLE: Credential Access – Steal Application Access Token

IDENTIFICATION: Detect access to application tokens, refresh tokens, or OAuth credentials stored locally or in cloud metadata endpoints.
Identify use of application tokens from unexpected locations, workloads, or devices.
Correlate token theft with suspicious access to metadata services or local credential caches.
CONTAINMENT: Revoke and rotate compromised application tokens and client secrets.
Restrict or disable service principals, application identities, or roles associated with misused tokens.
Isolate workloads that accessed or exposed tokens via local file, environment, or metadata leaks.
COUNTERMEASURES: Bind application tokens to specific workloads, runtimes, or IP ranges.
Avoid long-lived secrets by using managed identities and short-lived credentials.
Monitor for requests to cloud metadata endpoints and unusual token minting patterns.
FORENSICS: Preserve cloud audit logs showing token issuance and use.
Identify impacted resources accessed with stolen application tokens.
Correlate token abuse with code deployment and infrastructure changes.

IDENTIFICATION: Detect bulk mail export, mailbox scraping, or full-folder synchronization events outside of normal behavior.
Identify creation of forwarding rules, auto-forwarding to external domains, or abuse of shared mailboxes.
Correlate suspicious mail access with compromised credentials or new device enrollments.
CONTAINMENT: Disable rogue forwarding rules and revoke suspicious application or device access.
Force re-authentication and password resets for identities associated with abusive email access.
Temporarily restrict external forwarding and bulk export capabilities for impacted accounts.
COUNTERMEASURES: Require MFA for mail access, especially from unmanaged devices and legacy protocols.
Monitor for rule creation, forwarding configuration changes, and unusual export operations.
Limit which users or applications can perform bulk mailbox access or export.
FORENSICS: Preserve email audit logs, rule change histories, and mailbox access records.
Identify which mail folders, messages, and attachments were likely accessed or exported.
Correlate email collection with follow-on phishing, fraud, or credential attacks.

IDENTIFICATION: Detect messages containing suspicious links, spoofed senders, or known malicious templates.
Identify user reports of phishing and correlate with blocked or clicked messages.
Correlate delivered phishing campaigns with subsequent login anomalies or malware alerts.
CONTAINMENT: Quarantine malicious messages and recall or delete similar messages across mailboxes where supported.
Block sender domains, URLs, and attachment hashes at email and web gateways.
Reset credentials and enforce MFA for users who interacted with phishing material.
COUNTERMEASURES: Deploy advanced phishing protection, including URL rewriting and attachment sandboxing.
Regularly train users on recognizing phishing attempts, focusing on high-target groups.
Enforce strict SPF, DKIM, and DMARC policies to reduce spoofing.
FORENSICS: Archive full message content, headers, and attachments for campaign analysis.
Document targeted roles, lure types, and infrastructure used in the campaign.
Correlate phishing operations with other intrusion stages, including C2 and credential theft.

IDENTIFICATION: Identify external reporting that organization or key personnel are being profiled by hostile actors.
Correlate credential dumps, social profiles, and breached data with internal identities.
Detect targeted spearphishing or password spraying leveraging gathered identity data.
CONTAINMENT: Notify affected individuals and require credential rotation for exposed accounts.
Apply heightened monitoring and stronger MFA enforcement for high-risk identities.
Coordinate with legal and communications teams for external exposure management.
COUNTERMEASURES: Monitor breach and dark web sources for newly exposed identity data tied to the organization.
Encourage minimal public exposure of sensitive role information and contact details.
Deploy password policies and MFA that mitigate risk from reused or leaked passwords.
FORENSICS: Document sources and nature of exposed identity data.
Map exposed email addresses, usernames, and roles back to internal identity records.
Correlate exposure timelines with observed attacks on the same identities.

IDENTIFICATION: Identify external scanning, mapping, or enumeration of the organization’s IP ranges and domains reported by threat intelligence sources.
Detect recurring probes from infrastructure associated with known reconnaissance operations.
Correlate external reconnaissance reports with internal network scan or exploit attempts.
CONTAINMENT: Harden exposed services and reduce unnecessary internet-facing attack surface.
Block or rate-limit hostile infrastructure engaged in persistent reconnaissance.
Implement additional monitoring on systems and ranges identified in external reports.
COUNTERMEASURES: Regularly perform internal attack surface management to identify exposed services before adversaries.
Use threat intelligence to inform firewall policies and detection content.
Apply segmentation and zero-trust principles to reduce blast radius from discovered endpoints.
FORENSICS: Preserve threat intelligence reports, IOC feeds, and matching internal telemetry.
Document targeted ranges, services, and technologies identified in reconnaissance.
Correlate reconnaissance timelines with subsequent exploitation or intrusion activity.

T1539.TITLE: Credential Access – Steal Web Session Cookie

IDENTIFICATION: Detect filesystem, memory, or browser calls accessing session cookie storage.
Identify requests replaying stolen cookies or bypassing authentication flows.
Correlate cookie theft with new login locations lacking password/MFA challenges.
CONTAINMENT: Invalidate affected session cookies globally across federated services.
Force MFA re-authentication and reset tokens tied to suspected sessions.
Block IPs or devices attempting replay attacks using stolen cookies.
COUNTERMEASURES: Bind sessions to device and cryptographic properties rather than cookies alone.
Enforce short session lifetimes and rotate tokens frequently.
Detect simultaneous active sessions from incompatible geographies.
FORENSICS: Preserve session metadata, device fingerprints, and network indicators.
Identify vectors used to harvest cookies, including malware and browser exploitation.
Correlate stolen session use with changes in account privileges or data access.

IDENTIFICATION: Detect access to plaintext credentials stored in config files, local scripts, or exported logs.
Identify automated tools scanning directories for secrets and authentication artifacts.
Correlate detection with malware execution or suspicious scripting engines.
CONTAINMENT: Remove or encrypt stored secrets in configuration paths.
Rotate keys, tokens, and passwords exposed in compromised files.
Quarantine systems that accessed or modified exposed credentials.
COUNTERMEASURES: Enforce secret-scanning on deployment pipelines, repositories, and storage paths.
Use vault-based secrets with ephemeral credentials.
Restrict file system access to configuration directories.
FORENSICS: Collect access logs to file paths containing static credentials.
Determine whether secrets were read, exfiltrated, or executed.
Review commit history and backups to remove leaked credentials.

IDENTIFICATION: Correlate processes accessing LSASS, SAM, NTDS, or other credential stores with non-standard tools or unusual parent processes.
Detect use of credential dumping utilities or native commands that extract hashes, tickets, or secret material from memory or disk.
Monitor spikes in access to domain controllers, security databases, or key vault services from atypical administrative identities or hosts.
CONTAINMENT: Isolate affected hosts from the network while maintaining forensic integrity of memory and disk.
Terminate and block identified dumping tools, scripts, and processes from further execution.
Reset or revoke exposed accounts, tokens, and secrets with priority on privileged and service identities.
COUNTERMEASURES: Harden domain controllers and security infrastructure with credential guard, LSASS protection, and restricted administrative logon policies.
Implement tiered administrative models and just-in-time access controls to limit long-lived privileged credentials.
Centralize secret storage into managed vaults and remove locally cached or hard-coded credentials wherever possible.
FORENSICS: Capture full memory images and system images from impacted systems for offline analysis of credential artifacts.
Enumerate which credential types were accessible on each host and map them to corresponding accounts and business systems.
Reconstruct attacker timelines by correlating credential theft with subsequent lateral movement, privilege escalation, and data access.

IDENTIFICATION: Identify scripts, files, or configuration data containing hardcoded passwords, API keys, or tokens.
Detect access to known sensitive file paths such as environment files, configuration backups, and plaintext credential exports.
Correlate file read events with processes that do not normally access sensitive configuration files.
CONTAINMENT: Rotate all exposed API keys, tokens, and credentials immediately.
Remove plaintext credentials from files, scripts, or shared drives.
Restrict file-system permissions to limit unnecessary access to configuration files.
COUNTERMEASURES: Enforce secrets management solutions for developers, automation, and services.
Implement scanning pipelines to detect hardcoded secrets in code repositories and storage locations.
Deploy monitoring for unauthorized reads or copies of configuration directories containing sensitive data.
FORENSICS: Collect copies of exposed files and determine which credentials were present and for how long.
Analyze process access logs to determine which user or service accessed the files.
Correlate exposed secrets with subsequent authentication attempts, cloud API calls, or lateral movement.

T1558.TITLE: Credential Access — Steal or Forge Kerberos Tickets

IDENTIFICATION: Monitor domain controllers and key distribution centers for anomalous ticket-granting ticket (TGT) and ticket-granting service (TGS) activity.
Detect signs of Kerberoasting, golden ticket, or pass-the-ticket behavior, such as high-volume TGS requests or unusual encryption types.
Correlate LSASS access events and credential dumping with subsequent Kerberos ticket misuse.
CONTAINMENT: Immediately rotate the krbtgt account password following established multi-step rotation procedures.
Invalidate active Kerberos tickets where possible and force re-authentication for high-value accounts and services.
Isolate compromised hosts and limit communication with domain controllers to trusted administrative systems.
COUNTERMEASURES: Implement strong service account governance, including unique accounts per service with minimal privileges.
Enable and tune Kerberos logging for anomalous requests, unusual encryption, and cross-realm behavior.
Deploy tiered administrative models and dedicated admin workstations to protect privileged Kerberos material.
FORENSICS: Review historical Kerberos logs for anomalous ticket issuance, lifetime manipulation, or unusual service principal name (SPN) access.
Map forged or stolen tickets to impacted services, hosts, and user accounts.
Correlate ticket abuse with lateral movement, directory changes, and access to sensitive data stores.

T1550.TITLE: Credential Access — Use Alternate Authentication Material

IDENTIFICATION: Detect reuse of access tokens, Kerberos tickets, password hashes, or session cookies from unusual hosts or locations.
Correlate authentication events that succeed without corresponding interactive logon or MFA challenges.
Identify lateral movement patterns that leverage token-based or hash-based authentication instead of cleartext credentials.
CONTAINMENT: Revoke or invalidate compromised tokens, tickets, and sessions at the identity provider and service endpoints.
Force password resets and MFA re-registration for impacted accounts.
Segment or isolate systems that issued or accepted suspicious authentication material.
COUNTERMEASURES: Implement short-lived tokens and strict refresh policies for web, API, and cloud access.
Enable hardened protections against pass-the-hash and pass-the-ticket on endpoints and domain infrastructure.
Adopt phishing-resistant MFA and modern authentication protocols that minimize long-lived bearer tokens.
FORENSICS: Reconstruct token issuance and usage timelines across identity providers, applications, and services.
Determine whether compromised authentication material originated from credential dumping, web compromise, or OAuth abuse.
Correlate alternate authentication material usage with data access, configuration changes, and privilege escalation.

T1110.004.TITLE: Credential Access — Brute Force: Credential Stuffing

IDENTIFICATION: Detect high-volume login attempts across many accounts with single or few password values drawn from known breach data.
Monitor failed and successful authentication attempts from rotating IP ranges, automation infrastructure, or bot-like user agents.
Correlate spikes in login failures against externally exposed portals, VPNs, SSO, and cloud applications.
CONTAINMENT: Rate-limit or temporarily block sources performing large-scale login attempts across multiple accounts.
Enforce account lockout or step-up verification for accounts targeted by repeated stuffing attempts.
Redirect suspicious traffic through enhanced inspection, bot detection, or challenge mechanisms.
COUNTERMEASURES: Deploy adaptive authentication and anomaly-based access controls for public-facing identity endpoints.
Integrate breach password intelligence to proactively block known-compromised credential pairs.
Encourage or enforce password managers and unique passwords across services for all users.
FORENSICS: Correlate targeted accounts with any successful logins during or after stuffing campaigns.
Review fraud, transaction, and data access logs for compromised accounts to determine impact.
Preserve authentication, proxy, and CDN logs to attribute campaigns to infrastructure, tooling, or known threat actors.

IDENTIFICATION: Detect anomalous issuance, modification, or injection of web session cookies, SAML assertions, or OAuth tokens.
Monitor for authentication events that originate without corresponding interactive logons or MFA challenges.
Correlate high-privilege or cross-tenant access with tokens signed by unexpected authorities or with unusual lifetimes.
CONTAINMENT: Revoke forged or suspicious web sessions and tokens at identity providers and relying applications.
Rotate signing keys and certificates used for SAML, OpenID Connect, or custom token services if compromise is suspected.
Limit or temporarily disable administrative access via federated identity pathways while investigation proceeds.
COUNTERMEASURES: Enforce strict key management practices, including HSM-backed signing keys and periodic rotation.
Apply least-privilege scopes to tokens and reduce default token lifetime, especially for administrative roles.
Implement continuous access evaluation and conditional access policies that reevaluate risk throughout the session.
FORENSICS: Review identity provider logs for anomalous token issuance, signing, and validation activity.
Identify all sessions and resources accessed using forged or suspect web credentials.
Correlate token abuse with configuration changes, privilege escalation, and data exfiltration activity.

IDENTIFICATION: Detect installation or execution of keyloggers, clipboard monitors, or screen overlay tools on endpoints.
Monitor for untrusted processes hooking into input APIs or capturing keyboard, mouse, or clipboard data.
Correlate suspicious input capture tools with subsequent credential use, browser logins, or VPN connections.
CONTAINMENT: Quarantine affected endpoints and terminate identified input capture processes.
Invalidate credentials that may have been entered on compromised systems during the suspected capture window.
Block identified binaries, scripts, and associated hashes across the environment.
COUNTERMEASURES: Deploy endpoint protection and EDR rules to detect and block known keylogging and input capture behaviors.
Restrict local administrative rights and application installation on user workstations.
Encourage use of password managers and out-of-band authentication mechanisms that reduce direct keyboard entry of secrets.
FORENSICS: Acquire full disk and memory images from affected systems to confirm the scope and capabilities of the capture tooling.
Reconstruct which applications, portals, and dialogs were active while the input capture tool was running.
Correlate timing of capture activity with downstream account misuse or data access anomalies.

T1621.TITLE: Credential Access — Multi-Factor Authentication Request Generation

IDENTIFICATION: Detect repeated or high-frequency MFA push, SMS, or call requests targeting the same account or device.
Correlate MFA prompts with failed login attempts from unusual locations, devices, or IP ranges.
Identify MFA approvals that follow long sequences of denied or ignored requests, especially for privileged accounts.
CONTAINMENT: Temporarily block or step-up challenge accounts experiencing MFA fatigue-style attacks.
Invalidate active sessions associated with suspicious MFA approvals and require fresh authentication.
Notify targeted users and security teams of ongoing MFA abuse attempts and provide guidance not to approve unexpected prompts.
COUNTERMEASURES: Enable phishing-resistant MFA methods where possible and reduce reliance on push-only mechanisms.
Configure throttling, anomaly detection, and explicit user-reporting features for suspicious MFA requests.
Limit self-service password reset and account recovery paths that can be abused to trigger unsolicited MFA prompts.
FORENSICS: Review identity provider and MFA logs to reconstruct the sequence of login attempts and MFA events.
Determine whether any fraudulent approvals resulted in unauthorized data access or configuration changes.
Correlate MFA abuse with credential exposure events, phishing campaigns, or dark web credential sightings.

IDENTIFICATION: Detect authentication and remote session activity between internal hosts using administrative protocols such as RDP, SMB, SSH, WinRM, or DCOM.
Identify accounts that initiate remote connections to systems they do not normally administer or access.
Correlate new or unusual remote service use with prior credential theft, privilege escalation, or endpoint compromise signals.
CONTAINMENT: Restrict or temporarily block remote administration protocols between non-administrative segments.
Limit remote service access to dedicated management hosts and known administrative identities.
Isolate endpoints that show unauthorized or anomalous remote service activity pending investigation.
COUNTERMEASURES: Enforce least-privilege and tiered administration models for remote service use.
Require MFA and strong authentication for remote administrative access wherever possible.
Harden and monitor remote access protocols with logging, intrusion detection, and just-in-time access controls.
FORENSICS: Review remote login and session logs to map which hosts and accounts were involved in lateral access.
Correlate remote service activity with file transfers, process creation, and configuration changes on target hosts.
Reconstruct the attacker’s lateral movement path to identify initial access, pivot points, and blast radius.

T1021.001.TITLE: Lateral Movement — Remote Services: Remote Desktop Protocol (RDP)

IDENTIFICATION: Detect new or unusual RDP connections between internal hosts, especially to servers or workstations not typically accessed by the source account.
Monitor for RDP sessions initiated from compromised users, service accounts, or systems recently flagged for malware.
Identify RDP access outside approved time windows or from jump points that are not dedicated management systems.
CONTAINMENT: Temporarily restrict RDP access to affected hosts and enforce access only via hardened bastion or jump hosts.
Terminate suspicious RDP sessions and require re-authentication with MFA for impacted accounts.
Quarantine endpoints used as unauthorized RDP pivot points for deeper inspection.
COUNTERMEASURES: Disable direct RDP between workstations and limit RDP usage to tightly controlled administration paths.
Enable Network Level Authentication (NLA) and strong encryption for all RDP services.
Deploy monitoring and alerting for RDP session creation, failed attempts, and configuration changes on RDP services.
FORENSICS: Collect RDP connection logs, security logs, and session metadata from both source and destination hosts.
Determine which accounts, processes, and data were accessed during suspicious RDP sessions.
Correlate RDP activity with file transfers, new user creation, or persistence mechanisms on target systems.

T1021.002.TITLE: Lateral Movement — Remote Services: SMB/Windows Admin Shares

IDENTIFICATION: Monitor for access to administrative SMB shares (e.g., C$, ADMIN$, IPC$) from unusual hosts or identities.
Detect file copy and remote service creation over SMB that deploys binaries, scripts, or tools to other systems.
Identify repeated authentication attempts to multiple hosts over SMB using the same account or credential set.
CONTAINMENT: Restrict access to administrative shares to dedicated management hosts and authorized admin accounts.
Block or throttle SMB traffic originating from compromised or non-administrative segments.
Isolate endpoints showing unauthorized admin share access while preserving logs and artifacts.
COUNTERMEASURES: Disable or limit default administrative shares where operationally feasible and replace with managed alternatives.
Implement host-based firewalls and network segmentation to constrain SMB lateral movement.
Monitor and alert on remote service installation and execution initiated via SMB-admin paths.
FORENSICS: Review SMB logs, security events, and file access records for evidence of remote tool deployment.
Correlate SMB-based lateral movement with credential theft, service installation, and registry modification events.
Map out all hosts touched via SMB admin shares to determine the full lateral spread.

T1021.003.TITLE: Lateral Movement — Remote Services: Distributed Component Object Model (DCOM)

IDENTIFICATION: Detect remote DCOM activation or method invocation from hosts that do not typically manage the target system.
Monitor for DCOM-based process creation or execution of scripts and binaries on remote Windows hosts.
Correlate DCOM activity with suspicious use of administrative credentials or recent privilege escalation events.
CONTAINMENT: Restrict DCOM-based remote activation to known management servers and authorized administrative users.
Temporarily block DCOM traffic from suspected pivot systems while analysis is performed.
Increase scrutiny on hosts receiving unexpected DCOM calls for additional signs of compromise.
COUNTERMEASURES: Harden DCOM configurations and limit exposed COM objects to those required for business operations.
Implement endpoint and network controls to monitor and alert on remote DCOM process creation.
Use role-based administration and dedicated admin workstations for activities that rely on DCOM.
FORENSICS: Collect event logs related to DCOM activation, remote execution, and associated user contexts.
Identify which commands or binaries were executed via DCOM and which accounts initiated them.
Correlate DCOM-based lateral movement with other execution and persistence mechanisms on target systems.

IDENTIFICATION: Monitor for SSH logins between internal hosts that deviate from normal administrative patterns.
Detect new SSH key usage, especially keys not previously observed for the account or host.
Correlate SSH activity with recent credential theft, key discovery, or configuration changes to authorized_keys files.
CONTAINMENT: Lock down SSH access to critical systems to a small set of management hosts and trusted identities.
Revoke or rotate SSH keys suspected to be compromised or misused.
Temporarily restrict SSH access from suspected pivot points while verifying their integrity.
COUNTERMEASURES: Enforce key-based authentication with strong key management policies and disable password SSH logins where possible.
Implement allow-lists for permitted SSH source–destination pairs and privileged accounts.
Enable detailed SSH logging and integrate with SIEM for detection of anomalous login patterns and command usage.
FORENSICS: Review SSH logs for session origins, executed commands, and file transfer activity.
Identify when and where new SSH keys were added, modified, or used for the first time.
Correlate SSH lateral movement with changes to services, cron jobs, or sudoers configuration on target systems.

T1021.006.TITLE: Lateral Movement — Remote Services: Windows Remote Management (WinRM)

IDENTIFICATION: Detect new or unusual WinRM sessions from hosts that are not designated management systems.
Monitor for script blocks, commands, and payloads executed over WinRM that are atypical for the environment.
Correlate WinRM usage with recent credential access events and other remote administration protocol usage.
CONTAINMENT: Restrict WinRM to dedicated management hosts and tightly controlled administrator roles.
Terminate suspicious WinRM sessions and temporarily block access from compromised or untrusted sources.
Quarantine endpoints used as WinRM pivot nodes for further investigation.
COUNTERMEASURES: Harden WinRM by enforcing HTTPS, certificate-based authentication, and constrained endpoints where possible.
Enable PowerShell and WinRM logging, including script block and transcription logging, and forward to centralized logging.
Regularly review and audit WinRM configuration, listeners, and allowed hosts lists.
FORENSICS: Collect PowerShell, WinRM, and security logs from source and destination systems.
Reconstruct commands, scripts, and payloads executed via WinRM, along with their outcomes.
Map WinRM-based pivot paths and determine the scope of lateral movement enabled by these sessions.

IDENTIFICATION: Detect file transfers of administrative tools, malware, or scripts from one internal host to another using SMB, RDP, WinRM, SSH, or custom protocols.
Identify new binaries or utilities appearing on multiple hosts that were not deployed through standard software distribution channels.
Correlate tool transfers with remote execution events and privilege escalation on receiving systems.
CONTAINMENT: Block known malicious or unauthorized tools at endpoints and network gateways.
Quarantine hosts involved in suspicious tool distribution or reception for deeper inspection.
Disable temporary file shares or ad-hoc transfer mechanisms used in the lateral movement chain.
COUNTERMEASURES: Maintain an allow-list of approved administrative tools and block unapproved remote management utilities.
Use application control and code signing validation to prevent execution of unauthorized binaries.
Inspect internal file transfer patterns and restrict peer-to-peer sharing in sensitive segments.
FORENSICS: Collect hashes, file paths, and distribution patterns for tools moved laterally across the environment.
Determine whether transferred tools were used for credential theft, discovery, or persistence.
Correlate lateral tool transfer with specific threat actor TTPs or known intrusion playbooks.

T1210.TITLE: Lateral Movement — Exploitation of Remote Services

IDENTIFICATION: Detect exploitation attempts against remote services such as RDP, SMB, VPN, SSH, or application protocols on internal hosts.
Monitor for crashes, abnormal log entries, or suspicious process behavior associated with inbound network connections.
Correlate exploit signatures or behavioral indicators with new processes, shells, or persistence artifacts on targeted systems.
CONTAINMENT: Immediately isolate exploited or suspected-compromised hosts from the network.
Block network access to vulnerable remote services until patches or mitigations are in place.
Reset credentials and revoke tokens associated with services or accounts exposed through the exploited interface.
COUNTERMEASURES: Apply timely patching and configuration hardening to remote services, prioritizing externally exposed and critical internal systems.
Limit exposure of remote services using segmentation, VPNs, and zero-trust access controls.
Deploy intrusion detection and prevention tuned to detect exploitation of high-risk remote service vulnerabilities.
FORENSICS: Preserve logs, memory, and relevant application telemetry from exploited systems for exploit chain reconstruction.
Identify payloads delivered during exploitation and map follow-on activities such as lateral movement and data access.
Correlate exploitation with threat intelligence on known vulnerabilities and active campaigns targeting similar services.

T1563.TITLE: Lateral Movement — Remote Service Session Hijacking

IDENTIFICATION: Detect unusual activity occurring within existing remote sessions, such as actions inconsistent with the original user’s behavior or profile.
Monitor for token theft, session handle manipulation, or impersonation of existing remote sessions on endpoints.
Correlate hijacked session behavior with known compromise indicators on the host originating or receiving the session.
CONTAINMENT: Invalidate or forcibly terminate suspect remote sessions and log off impacted accounts.
Require re-authentication and MFA for accounts associated with hijacked sessions.
Quarantine hosts where session tokens or handles were manipulated for detailed analysis.
COUNTERMEASURES: Enable strong session isolation and token protection mechanisms on servers and workstations.
Limit the lifetime of remote sessions and enforce automatic timeouts for idle connections.
Instrument monitoring for privilege use, impersonation, and process injection linked to remote sessions.
FORENSICS: Collect logs and telemetry associated with remote sessions, including actions taken and processes spawned.
Determine how session tokens, handles, or credentials were accessed or stolen by the attacker.
Correlate session hijacking with lateral movement, data access, and persistence operations.

T1563.002.TITLE: Lateral Movement — Remote Service Session Hijacking: RDP Hijacking

IDENTIFICATION: Monitor for RDP session takeovers where session control changes without a corresponding logon event.
Detect local or remote tools that attach to or manipulate existing RDP sessions or session descriptors.
Correlate RDP hijack behavior with preceding privilege escalation or credential theft on the same host.
CONTAINMENT: Immediately disconnect suspicious RDP sessions and require re-authentication from legitimate users.
Disable local tools, scripts, or services used to hijack or attach to RDP sessions.
Restrict RDP access to critical hosts to tightly controlled admin workstations.
COUNTERMEASURES: Harden RDP session management, including disabling unnecessary session shadowing or takeover capabilities.
Use just-in-time RDP access and limit concurrent sessions, especially for privileged accounts.
Enable auditing for RDP-related session management operations and integrate with SIEM alerting.
FORENSICS: Review RDP session logs, security logs, and system events to determine when and how the hijack occurred.
Identify commands executed and resources accessed during hijacked sessions.
Correlate RDP hijacking attempts with broader attacker lateral movement and C2 infrastructure.

IDENTIFICATION: Detect use of external remote access services such as VPN, VDI, or third-party remote support tools into the environment.
Monitor for new or unusual external remote service providers used to access internal resources.
Correlate external remote access with anomalous geographic locations, devices, or user agents.
CONTAINMENT: Restrict external remote access to approved providers and tightly controlled entry points.
Temporarily disable external access for accounts exhibiting suspicious remote connectivity.
Block or limit access from unapproved remote service domains, IP ranges, or applications.
COUNTERMEASURES: Mandate MFA for all external remote service access, with risk-based controls for sensitive roles.
Regularly review and validate all configured remote access solutions and associated trust relationships.
Instrument monitoring for new remote access tools or tunnels appearing in the environment.
FORENSICS: Collect logs from VPNs, remote desktops, and third-party remote access tools to map session activity.
Identify internal assets accessed via external remote services and assess potential impact.
Correlate external remote service use with credential theft, phishing, and lateral movement events.

IDENTIFICATION: Detect queries and tools that enumerate domain trust relationships, forest trusts, or cross-domain authentication paths.
Monitor for discovery commands executed by accounts or hosts that do not normally perform directory reconnaissance.
Correlate trust discovery with prior domain compromise or credential access on domain-joined systems.
CONTAINMENT: Restrict access to directory and forest metadata to dedicated administrative systems and roles.
Increase monitoring of authentication attempts across domain and forest trust boundaries.
Temporarily tighten cross-domain access permissions if active abuse of trust paths is suspected.
COUNTERMEASURES: Apply least-privilege principles and minimize unnecessary domain trusts and forest relationships.
Segment and monitor high-value domains separately, with strong boundaries between trust zones.
Implement enhanced logging for directory service queries that enumerate trust topology.
FORENSICS: Review directory service logs and command histories to identify when and how trust information was queried.
Determine whether discovered trusts were later used for lateral movement or privilege escalation.
Correlate trust discovery activity with subsequent access to resources in other domains or forests.

IDENTIFICATION: Detect use of enterprise software deployment tools (e.g., SCCM, configuration managers, orchestration platforms) outside normal change windows or change tickets.
Monitor for deployment tasks that push unfamiliar binaries, scripts, or payloads to multiple hosts.
Correlate suspicious deployment activity with accounts recently exhibiting compromise indicators.
CONTAINMENT: Suspend or disable deployment jobs that appear malicious or unapproved.
Restrict access to deployment consoles and agents to a minimal set of trusted admin accounts.
Isolate systems that received potentially malicious deployments for analysis and remediation.
COUNTERMEASURES: Enforce strong authentication, MFA, and role-based access control for software deployment systems.
Implement change-control workflows and approvals for production-wide or high-impact deployments.
Log and alert on deployments of new or unknown binaries, especially to critical or sensitive systems.
FORENSICS: Collect deployment logs, job definitions, and console activity to determine what was pushed and by whom.
Identify all hosts affected by suspicious deployments and examine them for additional compromise indicators.
Correlate misuse of software deployment tools with broader attacker lateral movement and impact objectives.

IDENTIFICATION: Detect repetitive or scripted data transfer activity from a host that deviates from historical patterns for that system or service.
Monitor scheduled tasks, services, or scripts that package and send data to external destinations without corresponding user interaction.
Correlate unusual outbound data flows with newly deployed tools, scripts, or configuration changes on the originating host.
CONTAINMENT: Throttle or block suspicious automated transfer jobs at egress controls while preserving forensic data.
Disable or quarantine scripts, services, or scheduled tasks responsible for repeated outbound transfers.
Temporarily restrict outbound connectivity for the affected host or service pending investigation.
COUNTERMEASURES: Enforce change control and approvals for automation that moves or exports data outside the organization.
Baseline normal automated transfer patterns and alert on new or significantly altered jobs and destinations.
Implement DLP and behavioral analytics on high-value repositories and egress points to spot unauthorized automation.
FORENSICS: Review task schedulers, cron entries, and orchestration logs for creation and modification of automated transfer jobs.
Identify datasets and repositories accessed by the automation and determine data sensitivity.
Correlate automation-driven transfers with account activity, tool deployment, and other intrusion stages.

IDENTIFICATION: Detect network traffic mirroring, port spanning, or packet capture streams that forward copies of traffic to unapproved destinations.
Monitor for creation or modification of SPAN, TAP, or mirror configurations that direct internal traffic to unknown collectors.
Correlate traffic duplication with new, unrecognized capture processes or tools running on network infrastructure or sensors.
CONTAINMENT: Disable unauthorized mirroring or capture configurations on switches, routers, or virtual networking components.
Block outbound connections from rogue packet capture hosts to external collectors.
Isolate or lock down management interfaces for network devices exhibiting unexpected mirroring behavior.
COUNTERMEASURES: Restrict the ability to configure traffic mirroring and capture to a small, vetted group of network administrators.
Regularly audit SPAN/TAP configurations and packet capture endpoints for unauthorized changes.
Log and monitor use of packet capture tools in sensitive segments and management networks.
FORENSICS: Review configuration histories on network devices to determine when and by whom mirroring was enabled.
Identify destinations of duplicated traffic and assess what portions of network communications were exposed.
Correlate traffic duplication with lateral movement, credential theft, and data staging activity.

IDENTIFICATION: Detect multiple small outbound transfers to the same destination that collectively represent a large dataset.
Monitor for repeated connections or sessions with consistent maximum sizes just below alerting or throttling thresholds.
Correlate chunked transfer behavior with access to large files or repositories shortly before exfiltration.
CONTAINMENT: Temporarily lower thresholds or apply tighter rate limits on outbound transfers to suspicious destinations.
Block or sandbox destinations involved in repeated small chunk transfers while the pattern is investigated.
Introduce additional authentication or approvals for bulk exports from sensitive systems.
COUNTERMEASURES: Implement DLP and anomaly detection that considers aggregate transfer volume and frequency, not just single events.
Define strict thresholds for total data volume per user, system, or application to external endpoints.
Monitor compression, archiving, and staging behaviors that often precede chunked exfiltration.
FORENSICS: Reconstruct aggregated transfer volumes by correlating multiple small sessions over time.
Determine which data sources were read or staged before chunked exfiltration began.
Assess whether exfiltrated data contains regulated or highly sensitive information requiring notification.

IDENTIFICATION: Detect command-and-control channels that begin carrying high-volume or structured data beyond typical beacon patterns.
Monitor for compressed, encoded, or batched payloads being transferred over established C2 sessions.
Correlate increased C2 traffic with prior data staging on endpoints or servers, including archive creation and repository access.
CONTAINMENT: Block or sinkhole identified C2 endpoints while preserving traffic captures for analysis.
Isolate compromised hosts participating in C2-driven exfiltration to prevent further data loss.
Revoke credentials, tokens, and keys used on systems associated with active C2 channels.
COUNTERMEASURES: Deploy network inspection and behavioral analytics tuned to identify deviations from normal C2 beacon patterns.
Segment critical data repositories away from systems directly exposed to the internet or common C2 ingress points.
Apply egress filtering and DNS controls to restrict outbound communication to vetted domains and services.
FORENSICS: Analyze captured C2 traffic to estimate the volume and type of data exfiltrated.
Reconstruct timelines correlating C2 establishment, data staging, and exfiltration phases.
Map impacted data sets to business processes and regulatory obligations to determine impact.

IDENTIFICATION: Detect outbound data transfers using protocols not typically associated with the source system or application (e.g., FTP, SMTP, DNS, custom ports).
Monitor for sudden onset of new protocol use to external hosts from servers that historically use limited protocols.
Correlate protocol shifts with blocked or disrupted primary C2 channels or egress routes.
CONTAINMENT: Block or limit outbound use of rarely needed protocols to the identified destinations.
Enforce protocol allow-lists on critical segments to reduce unauthorized alternative channels.
Temporarily restrict outbound access from systems generating suspicious alternative protocol traffic.
COUNTERMEASURES: Establish clear policies and firewall rules restricting which protocols can be used for outbound communication.
Deploy protocol-aware inspection and anomaly detection to highlight unexpected application-layer behaviors.
Regularly review firewall and proxy logs for new external services contacted via unusual protocols.
FORENSICS: Analyze packet captures to understand the structure, contents, and potential encoding of exfiltrated data.
Determine whether the alternative protocol was used as a fallback after other channels were blocked.
Correlate alternative protocol use with known malware families or threat actor TTPs.

T1048.003.TITLE: Exfiltration — Exfiltration Over Unencrypted Non-C2 Protocol

IDENTIFICATION: Monitor for cleartext or lightly encoded data transfers over non-C2 protocols such as HTTP, FTP, or custom TCP/UDP services.
Detect large or structured payloads sent to external endpoints over protocols not typically used for bulk data export.
