Correlate unencrypted exfiltration attempts with prior data staging or compression on the source host.
CONTAINMENT: Block outbound connections to destinations involved in suspicious unencrypted transfers.
Apply deep packet inspection or temporary blocking for affected protocols from the originating host segment.
Introduce rate-limiting and tighter egress rules for systems exhibiting these behaviors.
COUNTERMEASURES: Use DLP and content inspection at key egress points to detect cleartext sensitive data leaving the environment.
Configure security tooling to alert on bulk transfers of sensitive file types over non-typical ports and protocols.
Encourage use of approved, logged, and monitored channels for any legitimate large data exports.
FORENSICS: Review logs and packet captures to identify exact data elements exfiltrated in clear or weakly encoded form.
Map exfiltrated data back to source systems, applications, and owners for impact assessment.
Correlate unencrypted exfiltration with initial compromise, lateral movement, and data collection phases.

T1011.TITLE: Exfiltration — Exfiltration Over Other Network Medium

IDENTIFICATION: Detect use of alternate network media such as cellular modems, Wi-Fi hotspots, or ad-hoc wireless networks from sensitive hosts.
Monitor for new network interfaces, tethering, or wireless adapters enabled on systems that typically use only wired enterprise networks.
Correlate physical or wireless connectivity changes with privileged data access events on the host.
CONTAINMENT: Disable unauthorized wireless adapters, modems, or tethering features on affected systems.
Enforce policies prohibiting unapproved external connectivity from sensitive systems and servers.
Physically secure and restrict access to areas where high-value systems operate to reduce covert wireless exfiltration risk.
COUNTERMEASURES: Inventory and control all network interfaces and wireless capabilities on critical assets.
Deploy wireless intrusion detection to identify rogue access points, ad-hoc networks, and unusual RF activity.
Educate users and administrators on the risks of attaching unauthorized modems or mobile devices to corporate systems.
FORENSICS: Collect OS logs, driver logs, and network configuration histories for evidence of alternative network usage.
Determine timing and duration of connections over the alternate medium and assess what data was accessible during that period.
Correlate alternate medium use with other intrusion events, including physical access anomalies.

IDENTIFICATION: Monitor for large file copies to removable media such as USB drives or external disks from sensitive hosts.
Detect mounting of removable storage devices on systems that rarely or never use them in normal operations.
Correlate removable media events with access to high-value repositories or bulk export operations.
CONTAINMENT: Restrict or temporarily disable removable media usage on critical systems and in sensitive zones.
Quarantine or retain removable devices used during suspected exfiltration events for analysis.
Revoke or review access rights for users associated with suspicious removable media usage.
COUNTERMEASURES: Implement device control policies to limit removable media use to approved, encrypted devices.
Log and alert on removable media connect/disconnect events and large file copy operations.
Provide secure, monitored methods for legitimate data transfers to reduce reliance on ad-hoc removable media usage.
FORENSICS: Examine audit logs and file system histories to determine which files were copied to removable media.
Analyze seized devices for presence of sensitive or regulated data and potential onward transfer.
Correlate physical exfiltration with badge access, camera logs, and user activity around the time of events.

IDENTIFICATION: Detect uploads of large or unusual volumes of data to external web services such as cloud storage, file-sharing platforms, or paste sites.
Monitor for new or atypical domains associated with web-based storage accessed from sensitive hosts.
Correlate web service uploads with recent data staging, archiving, or compression on the originating systems.
CONTAINMENT: Block or tightly restrict access to high-risk web storage services from critical segments.
Temporarily suspend or sandbox accounts or systems that initiate unexplained bulk uploads.
Apply URL filtering and SSL inspection where permitted to better observe suspicious upload activity.
COUNTERMEASURES: Define a vetted list of approved external web services and restrict access to others by default.
Deploy CASB or equivalent controls to monitor and govern data movement to external SaaS and storage platforms.
Implement labeling and DLP controls that prevent sensitive data from being uploaded to unmanaged locations.
FORENSICS: Review proxy, firewall, and CASB logs to identify the volume, timing, and destination of uploaded data.
Work with platform providers where possible to verify account ownership and actions taken on their side.
Correlate web service exfiltration with compromised identities, malware activity, or insider threats.

IDENTIFICATION: Detect pushes or uploads to public or unmanaged code repositories from systems that typically do not interact with those platforms.
Monitor for large binary or archive files being committed to repositories rather than typical source code changes.
Correlate repository access with accounts that recently accessed sensitive documentation, source, or design artifacts internally.
CONTAINMENT: Temporarily block or restrict access to unmanaged code hosting platforms from sensitive networks.
Contact repository operators or use available controls to lock or remove suspicious repositories when feasible.
Suspend or review user accounts that performed suspicious commits or uploads.
COUNTERMEASURES: Establish and enforce policies specifying which code repositories and hosting providers are allowed for business use.
Monitor for new repository creation or unusual commit patterns originating from corporate networks.
Educate developers and staff on the risks of uploading internal data to personal or public repositories.
FORENSICS: Clone or snapshot suspicious repositories to identify what internal data has been uploaded.
Map exfiltrated repository contents back to internal projects, systems, or data owners.
Correlate code repository exfiltration with insider activity, compromised accounts, or third-party access paths.

IDENTIFICATION: Detect recurring outbound data transfers that occur on a predictable schedule from compromised hosts.
Monitor for newly created or modified scheduled tasks, cron jobs, or orchestration flows that send data externally.
Correlate scheduled transfers with prior data staging or repository access in the minutes or hours before each run.
CONTAINMENT: Disable or pause suspicious scheduled jobs while preserving their configuration for review.
Block scheduled transfer destinations at egress points until they can be validated.
Apply enhanced monitoring and temporary restrictions to hosts generating scheduled exfiltration traffic.
COUNTERMEASURES: Enforce approvals and documentation for all scheduled jobs that move data outside organizational boundaries.
Baseline known legitimate schedules and alert on new or modified jobs affecting sensitive systems.
Limit direct scheduling of outbound transfers from critical assets; prefer centralized, audited data movement services.
FORENSICS: Review scheduler logs and job definitions to determine when and by whom exfiltration jobs were configured.
Identify data sources tied to scheduled jobs and estimate the volume and sensitivity of transferred data.
Correlate scheduled exfiltration with attacker dwell time, collection patterns, and staging infrastructure.

T1537.TITLE: Exfiltration — Transfer Data to Cloud Account

IDENTIFICATION: Detect transfers of data from internal systems directly into external cloud accounts not managed by the organization.
Monitor for use of cloud storage clients, sync tools, or APIs configured with personal or unknown tenant identities.
Correlate cloud upload activity with access to sensitive internal repositories, databases, or document stores.
CONTAINMENT: Block access to unmanaged or unknown cloud tenants from sensitive networks and critical systems.
Revoke tokens, API keys, and credentials associated with suspicious cloud accounts or integrations.
Suspend or investigate local accounts and processes used to authenticate to the external cloud destinations.
COUNTERMEASURES: Implement strong governance and CASB controls around sanctioned cloud accounts and storage locations.
Restrict the ability to configure new cloud sync or backup targets without security review.
Use tenant restrictions, conditional access, and egress controls to prevent data transfer to unknown cloud identities.
FORENSICS: Review cloud provider logs where accessible to determine what data was stored, accessed, or shared after exfiltration.
Map exfiltrated data sets back to internal systems and owners to evaluate business and regulatory impact.
Correlate cloud account exfiltration with insider risks, compromised credentials, and prior reconnaissance.

T1059.001.TITLE: Execution — Command and Scripting Interpreter: PowerShell

IDENTIFICATION: Detect PowerShell processes launched with encoded commands, hidden windows, or non-interactive flags from user workstations and servers.
Monitor for PowerShell execution from unusual parent processes, such as office applications, browsers, or service hosts.
Correlate PowerShell activity with network connections to untrusted destinations, script block logging, and AMSI detections.
CONTAINMENT: Terminate malicious or suspicious PowerShell processes while preserving forensic artifacts such as script block logs.
Temporarily restrict PowerShell to constrained language mode or block non-admin PowerShell usage on affected systems.
Isolate endpoints with repeated malicious PowerShell activity from sensitive network segments.
COUNTERMEASURES: Enable and centralize PowerShell logging, including script block and module logging, and integrate with SIEM detections.
Use application control or policy to restrict PowerShell usage to administrative workflows and signed scripts.
Harden endpoint baselines to block or alert on PowerShell invoked from office macros, email attachments, or user profile paths.
FORENSICS: Collect PowerShell event logs, script block logs, and command-line arguments for executed PowerShell instances.
Reconstruct executed scripts and commands to enumerate attacker objectives, such as discovery, credential theft, or persistence.
Correlate PowerShell execution timelines with other host artifacts, including registry changes, file writes, and lateral movement.

T1059.003.TITLE: Execution — Command and Scripting Interpreter: Windows Command Shell

IDENTIFICATION: Monitor cmd.exe launches from non-interactive contexts such as services, scheduled tasks, or office documents.
Detect command lines containing suspicious patterns such as chaining operators, obfuscated paths, or built-in LOLBAS usage.
Correlate command shell usage with file system modifications, new user creation, or script and binary execution.
CONTAINMENT: Terminate clearly malicious command shell processes and associated child processes.
Restrict usage of cmd.exe for non-admin users on systems where it is not required for business operations.
Increase logging and detection sensitivity on hosts exhibiting repeated suspicious shell usage.
COUNTERMEASURES: Implement application control rules that limit which binaries and scripts can be launched from the command shell.
Educate administrators on secure scripting practices and discourage ad hoc command execution directly on production systems.
Deploy detections for known malicious command patterns, including reconnaissance, credential dumping, and remote tool execution.
FORENSICS: Collect process creation logs capturing command-line arguments for cmd.exe instances.
Reconstruct execution chains by correlating shell activity with spawned processes and file changes.
Identify whether command shell execution was user-driven, automated, or attacker-controlled via remote access.

T1059.004.TITLE: Execution — Command and Scripting Interpreter: Unix Shell

IDENTIFICATION: Monitor for shell processes (bash, sh, zsh, etc.) launched by web servers, application servers, or other daemons.
Detect shell usage with suspicious flags, inline scripts, or execution from temporary directories or world-writable paths.
Correlate shell activity with unexpected file downloads, script fetches, and outbound connections to untrusted hosts.
CONTAINMENT: Terminate malicious shell sessions and isolate affected systems from external networks.
Disable or restrict interactive shell access to production servers except through approved administration channels.
Disable compromised user accounts and rotate credentials used to initiate hostile shell sessions.
COUNTERMEASURES: Enforce key-based authentication and restrict direct root shell access in Unix and Linux environments.
Deploy centralized logging for shell history and process auditing where feasible and legally permissible.
Limit which services are allowed to spawn shells, and monitor for unexpected parent–child shell relationships.
FORENSICS: Collect shell histories, process trees, and relevant log files from affected hosts.
Reconstruct sequences of commands executed via the shell to identify data access, persistence, and lateral movement.
Correlate shell abuse with exploited vulnerabilities, misconfigurations, or compromised accounts.

T1059.005.TITLE: Execution — Command and Scripting Interpreter: Visual Basic

IDENTIFICATION: Detect execution of Visual Basic scripts and macros from office applications, script engines (wscript, cscript), or HTA files.
Monitor for VB-based execution triggered by email attachments, embedded objects, or downloads from the internet zone.
Correlate Visual Basic execution with process injection, registry modification, and follow-on payload deployment.
CONTAINMENT: Disable or block execution of untrusted macros and Visual Basic scripts on endpoints where not strictly required.
Quarantine documents and script files identified as malicious or containing suspicious macro behavior.
Temporarily restrict office macro execution organization-wide in response to active malicious campaigns.
COUNTERMEASURES: Enforce macro security policies that disable macros by default and only allow signed, trusted code.
Deploy AMSI and script engine logging to capture Visual Basic script content and execution traces.
Use email and web gateway filtering to block known-malicious VBA templates and script-based payloads.
FORENSICS: Collect malicious documents, scripts, and associated logs showing how Visual Basic code was executed.
Analyze VB code to identify capabilities such as downloaders, credential theft, or persistence creation.
Correlate Visual Basic execution with initial phishing vectors, user actions, and lateral movement steps.

T1059.006.TITLE: Execution — Command and Scripting Interpreter: Python

IDENTIFICATION: Monitor for Python interpreter execution on systems where Python is not part of the standard software stack.
Detect Python scripts running from temporary directories, user profile locations, or network shares.
Correlate Python execution with network connections to suspicious infrastructure and file system changes indicating staging or exfiltration.
CONTAINMENT: Terminate unauthorized Python processes and quarantine associated script files for analysis.
Restrict installation and execution of Python on endpoints that do not require it for business purposes.
Increase monitoring on servers where Python is required, focusing on non-standard script locations and arguments.
COUNTERMEASURES: Implement application control policies that limit Python usage to signed or vetted scripts and environments.
Standardize Python deployments on servers and prohibit ad hoc interpreter installations by end users.
Deploy detections for common offensive Python frameworks and libraries used by attackers.
FORENSICS: Collect Python scripts, interpreter logs, and process metadata from affected systems.
Determine script functionality, including any embedded C2, credential access, or data mining logic.
Correlate Python-based execution with exploit delivery, persistence, and lateral movement artifacts.

T1059.007.TITLE: Execution — Command and Scripting Interpreter: JavaScript

IDENTIFICATION: Detect execution of standalone JavaScript files via script hosts (wscript, cscript) or HTA applications on endpoints.
Monitor browsers and electron-style applications for suspicious script execution patterns and dropped JS payloads.
Correlate JavaScript execution with downloads from untrusted sites, phishing attachments, or drive-by compromise activity.
CONTAINMENT: Block or restrict execution of standalone JavaScript files through OS script hosts where business use is minimal.
Quarantine suspicious JavaScript files and associated HTML or HTA containers.
Increase browser and endpoint protections for users targeted by script-based attacks.
COUNTERMEASURES: Use web and email gateways to detect and block malicious script attachments and embedded JavaScript.
Restrict or monitor HTA and script host usage within the environment.
Deploy endpoint controls to flag or block JavaScript executed outside of standard application contexts.
FORENSICS: Collect JavaScript payloads, associated container files, and execution logs from impacted systems.
Analyze script content to determine capabilities such as download, injection, or credential theft.
Correlate JavaScript execution with initial infection vector, user interaction, and subsequent attack stages.

IDENTIFICATION: Monitor for WMI process creation and remote WMI invocation from unusual systems or identities.
Detect WMI event consumers, filters, and bindings created or modified outside normal administrative workflows.
Correlate suspicious WMI usage with remote code execution, script deployment, or persistence mechanisms.
CONTAINMENT: Disable or remove malicious WMI event consumers and associated scripts on affected systems.
Restrict remote WMI access to dedicated management hosts and approved admin groups.
Isolate endpoints exhibiting unauthorized WMI usage for further analysis.
COUNTERMEASURES: Enable detailed WMI logging and forward relevant events to the SIEM for analysis.
Harden WMI namespaces and permissions, granting write access only to tightly controlled admin roles.
Use endpoint controls to detect and block known offensive WMI usage patterns and tooling.
FORENSICS: Export and review the WMI repository for abnormal event consumers, filters, and scripts.
Correlate WMI-based execution with other artifacts such as PowerShell, CMD, or service creation events.
Reconstruct attacker actions performed via WMI, including lateral movement and persistence operations.

IDENTIFICATION: Detect creation or modification of Windows scheduled tasks outside of documented change windows.
Monitor for tasks configured to run from unusual directories, with suspicious arguments, or under unexpected accounts.
Correlate new scheduled tasks with earlier execution of malicious scripts, droppers, or loaders.
CONTAINMENT: Disable or delete malicious scheduled tasks and associated binaries or scripts.
Revoke credentials and review group memberships for accounts used by suspicious tasks.
Increase monitoring on hosts where malicious tasks were created to detect residual persistence.
COUNTERMEASURES: Apply least-privilege to scheduled tasks, avoiding use of highly privileged service accounts where not needed.
Audit scheduled tasks regularly to identify unauthorized or legacy entries.
Deploy EDR and SIEM detections for known offensive scheduled task creation patterns and tool usage.
FORENSICS: Export task definitions and review triggers, actions, and associated credentials.
Determine when malicious tasks were created, how often they ran, and which payloads they executed.
Correlate scheduled task execution with observed lateral movement, exfiltration, or encryption events.

IDENTIFICATION: Monitor for new or modified cron entries in user and system crontabs that execute from suspicious paths or with obfuscated commands.
Detect cron jobs configured for unusual intervals, off-hours, or without clear operational justification.
Correlate cron changes with prior compromise indicators on the same host, such as web shell installation or privilege escalation.
CONTAINMENT: Disable or remove malicious or unknown cron entries while preserving their definitions for analysis.
Restrict write access to cron configuration files to authorized administrators only.
Isolate compromised hosts where cron-based persistence or execution has been identified.
COUNTERMEASURES: Standardize automation through centralized, auditable scheduling systems instead of ad hoc cron jobs on critical servers.
Implement file integrity monitoring on cron configuration files and related directories.
Educate administrators on secure scheduling practices and detection of suspicious cron entries.
FORENSICS: Collect all relevant crontab files, system cron directories, and associated scripts from impacted systems.
Determine how long malicious cron jobs have been present and what commands or payloads they executed.
Correlate cron job execution times with other log sources to identify the effects of scheduled malicious activity.

IDENTIFICATION: Detect creation or modification of system services configured to run attacker-controlled binaries or scripts.
Monitor for services configured to start automatically from non-standard directories or with suspicious parameters.
Correlate service changes with prior malicious activity such as privilege escalation, file drops, or registry tampering.
CONTAINMENT: Stop and disable malicious services and quarantine associated binaries.
Limit who can create or modify system services to a tight set of administrative identities.
Isolate affected systems where malicious services were used for persistence or execution.
COUNTERMEASURES: Implement service configuration auditing and alert on new or changed services on critical systems.
Apply application control to prevent unapproved binaries from being registered as services.
Use dedicated, well-documented service accounts and avoid reusing high-privilege identities for multiple services.
FORENSICS: Extract service configuration data, including binary paths, arguments, and accounts used.
Determine how long malicious services have been present and what operations they performed.
Correlate service-based execution with network connections, file access, and registry changes.

IDENTIFICATION: Detect processes that directly call low-level native APIs for process injection, memory allocation, or code execution.
Monitor for unusual or high-frequency use of APIs associated with creating remote threads, mapping sections, or executing shellcode.
Correlate native API abuse with unsigned or suspicious binaries, packers, or obfuscated loaders.
CONTAINMENT: Terminate processes exhibiting malicious native API usage and quarantine their binaries.
Increase EDR policy strictness on hosts where native API-based execution is detected.
Isolate systems where repeated native API abuse is observed to prevent further lateral movement.
COUNTERMEASURES: Deploy EDR rules that detect and block common injection and hollowing techniques using native APIs.
Limit untrusted code execution paths and enforce strong code-signing policies for critical applications.
Encourage the use of high-level, monitored frameworks for legitimate advanced operations instead of direct native calls.
FORENSICS: Analyze EDR telemetry and memory artifacts to reconstruct native API call sequences and injected payloads.
Identify which modules and processes were targeted by native API-based attacks.
Correlate native API execution with exploit chains, loaders, and persistence mechanisms.

IDENTIFICATION: Detect exploitation of client applications such as browsers, document viewers, media players, or email clients that results in unexpected code execution.
Monitor for crash signatures, abnormal child processes, or shell spawning from client applications.
Correlate client exploits with delivery mechanisms like malicious documents, weaponized web pages, or drive-by downloads.
CONTAINMENT: Isolate compromised endpoints where client exploitation is suspected or confirmed.
Block access to malicious websites, email attachments, or delivery infrastructure associated with the exploit.
Revoke tokens, browser sessions, and application credentials used on the affected hosts.
COUNTERMEASURES: Maintain aggressive patching of client software, especially browsers, document readers, and rich media components.
Use sandboxing and application isolation for high-risk client applications that interact with untrusted content.
Deploy exploit mitigation technologies such as DEP, ASLR, and modern hardened runtimes where possible.
FORENSICS: Collect crash dumps, application logs, and memory images from exploited clients.
Identify the vulnerability exploited and determine whether it is a known CVE or suspected zero-day.
Correlate client exploitation with follow-on payloads, persistence artifacts, and C2 communications.

IDENTIFICATION: Monitor bulk downloads from cloud buckets, SaaS repositories, or object storage from accounts not normally accessing such data.
Detect API calls listing bucket contents, generating signed URLs, or exporting data from cloud console sessions.
Correlate large cloud storage reads with new IAM role assumptions, token theft, or privilege escalation.
CONTAINMENT: Suspend or restrict access tokens used to access cloud storage buckets illicitly.
Block bucket downloads from unapproved regions or external networks.
Quarantine compromised cloud workloads/accounts and rotate associated access keys.
COUNTERMEASURES: Enforce regional access controls and bucket policies limiting sensitive data access to trusted resources.
Enable object-level logging and DLP scanning on cloud storage repositories.
Use conditional access policies and MFA for access to high-value cloud datasets.
FORENSICS: Review bucket access logs and API call history to reconstruct what data was viewed or downloaded.
Determine whether access was authenticated via stolen keys, federated tokens, or compromised sessions.
Correlate storage exfiltration timeline with discovery, persistence, and C2 activity.

IDENTIFICATION: Detect session tokens exported from cloud application caches, browser profiles, metadata services, or token stores.
Monitor for unexpected session re-use from new devices, IPs, or regions without corresponding authentication events.
Correlate token theft with compromised workloads, phishing events, or local process credential scraping.
CONTAINMENT: Invalidate stolen tokens and force re-authentication globally.
Quarantine workloads or hosts believed to be sources of credential token theft.
Rotate API keys, refresh tokens, and OIDC credentials linked to compromised identities.
COUNTERMEASURES: Use short-lived tokens with continuous revalidation and conditional access.
Encrypt token storage and enforce secure credential isolation for cloud workloads.
Enable logging for credential issuance and session validity in cloud IdP.
FORENSICS: Trace origin of stolen tokens via issuance logs and device fingerprints.
Determine which APIs and datasets were accessed using stolen tokens.
Correlate token use with known intrusion paths and follow-on lateral movement.

IDENTIFICATION: Detect access to credential files stored in local config folders for AWS, Azure, GCP, or Kubernetes CLIs.
Monitor for credential file access by processes that do not typically interact with cloud tooling.
Correlate credential file access with suspicious command execution or outbound API usage.
CONTAINMENT: Revoke exposed keys and rotate cloud credentials associated with compromised hosts.
Restrict access to local credential stores via filesystem ACLs and OS policy.
Isolate endpoints where credential harvesting was detected.
COUNTERMEASURES: Use short-lived cloud credentials and remove static keys where possible.
Deploy workstation hardening to prevent unauthorized credential file extraction.
Replace file-based authentication with managed identity or workload identity federation.
FORENSICS: Identify which credentials were accessed, copied, or exfiltrated via logs or memory analysis.
Trace use of stolen credentials in cloud logs to determine impact.
Correlate credential theft with initial compromise vector.

IDENTIFICATION: Detect enumeration of IAM roles, buckets, resource groups, VPC networks, and cloud service listings.
Monitor for new cloud reconnaissance API calls originating from compromised workloads or identities.
Correlate cloud discovery with recent authentication anomalies or privilege escalation.
CONTAINMENT: Restrict cloud discovery permissions to limited administrative roles.
Revoke access tokens and isolate identities performing unauthorized cloud enumeration.
Apply temporary deny policies to sensitive services during active investigation.
COUNTERMEASURES: Enforce least-privilege IAM policies preventing broad cloud-wide listing permissions.
Require service-to-service identity federation rather than broadly scoped access tokens.
Enable cloud-native threat detection services for IAM enumeration.
FORENSICS: Review cloud audit logs for discovery API calls, role queries, and region listings.
Determine which identities performed reconnaissance and whether privilege abuse followed.
Map discovered resources against observed attacker movement paths.

T1606.TITLE: Cloud — Forge Web Tokens / Cloud Authentication Forgery

IDENTIFICATION: Detect access attempts using tokens not issued by the organization’s identity provider.
Monitor cloud API calls where authentication succeeded without a preceding login event.
Correlate forged token usage with anomalous privilege assignment and cross-tenant access.
CONTAINMENT: Invalidate forged tokens by rotating signing keys or revoking trust for compromised issuers.
Disable affected identity federation configurations while forensic analysis proceeds.
Quarantine workloads suspected of minting or injecting forged tokens.
COUNTERMEASURES: Rotate identity provider signing certificates regularly and enforce key protection using HSMs.
Enable strict token validation settings including issuer, audience, and nonce enforcement.
Segment privileged cloud administration roles behind dedicated identity boundaries.
FORENSICS: Identify signing keys, STS providers, or token issuers that were compromised.
Reconstruct which resources and identities were accessed using forged tokens.
Correlate token forgery with privilege escalation, exfiltration, or destructive operations.

T1550.001.TITLE: Cloud — Use of Stolen Web Session Cookie

IDENTIFICATION: Detect access to cloud management consoles using session cookies that do not match legitimate authentication flows.
Monitor new device logins without MFA challenges due to cookie reuse.
Correlate cookie-based access with phishing campaigns, browser theft, or memory scraping.
CONTAINMENT: Invalidate stolen cookies by forcing global sign-out and MFA revalidation.
Suspend accounts where stolen cookies originated or were used.
Rotate associated tokens, API credentials, and session secrets.
COUNTERMEASURES: Enforce conditional access and device trust rather than cookie persistence alone.
Limit session lifetime for sensitive consoles and require continuous authentication.
Use secure browser isolation for admin cloud sessions.
FORENSICS: Trace session IDs to originating devices and determine compromise path.
Review cloud access logs to assess actions performed using stolen cookies.
Correlate cookie theft with wider credential abuse.

IDENTIFICATION: Detect API calls accessing large volumes of email messages or entire mailboxes.
Monitor for creation of inbox rules forwarding messages to external domains.
Correlate bulk mailbox access with authentication anomalies or token theft.
CONTAINMENT: Disable malicious inbox forwarding rules and revoke access tokens.
Lock or reset accounts with unexpected mail access patterns.
Block connections to suspicious forwarding domains or accounts.
COUNTERMEASURES: Enforce MFA and conditional access for cloud email platforms.
Disable legacy protocols (IMAP/POP) where feasible to prevent bypassing modern auth.
Monitor admin-level API access to group mailboxes and journaling exports.
FORENSICS: Export audit logs from cloud email platforms showing access scope and timestamps.
Determine which folders or messages were accessed and whether attachments were exfiltrated.
Correlate mailbox access with lateral privilege escalation in cloud identity systems.

IDENTIFICATION: Detect new cloud IAM users created outside of approved provisioning workflows.
Monitor creation of service principals, access keys, or federated identities added unexpectedly.
Correlate new accounts with suspicious token issuance or data access immediately after creation.
CONTAINMENT: Disable newly created accounts until validated by security or identity teams.
Revoke access keys and permissions for accounts tied to suspicious creation events.
Lock down IAM permissions for compromised admins and rotate privileged credentials.
COUNTERMEASURES: Enforce change-control around cloud identity provisioning.
Require privileged roles to use ephemeral or just-in-time elevation rather than permanent roles.
Implement identity governance automation to flag unapproved account additions.
FORENSICS: Review audit logs to determine who created the new account and from which identity.
Analyze what roles, keys, and privileges were granted and what resources were accessed.
Correlate unauthorized account creation with broader identity compromise.

T1098.003.TITLE: Cloud — Additional Cloud Roles / IAM Permission Escalation

IDENTIFICATION: Detect abnormal privilege grants to cloud identities, including admin roles, policy changes, or trust policy edits.
Monitor assignment of roles that allow token minting, resource deletion, or cross-tenant access.
Correlate elevation events with suspicious authentication or credential theft.
CONTAINMENT: Revoke elevated roles and revert IAM policies to last known-good configuration.
Disable compromised identities and enforce MFA resets.
Restrict IAM policy modification to break-glass or restricted accounts during response.
COUNTERMEASURES: Apply permission boundaries and deny policies that prevent privilege escalation even with compromised accounts.
Use just-in-time access and request-based privilege elevation with full audit logging.
Continuously validate IAM policy drift against security baselines.
FORENSICS: Review IAM change logs to identify which roles were modified, when, and by whom.
Assess resources accessed during elevated privilege window.
Correlate IAM elevation with subsequent exfiltration or destructive operations.

T1020.004.TITLE: Cloud — Exfiltration Over Cloud Storage Sync

IDENTIFICATION: Detect large or unusual data uploads from endpoints to cloud sync clients such as OneDrive, Google Drive, Box, or custom SaaS.
Monitor new sync connections on systems that normally do not use cloud storage clients.
Correlate sync uploads with local staging activity and recent credential theft.
CONTAINMENT: Suspend sync accounts and disable sync client processes on affected systems.
Block outbound access to cloud storage tenants until validated.
Lock affected user identities and rotate session tokens.
COUNTERMEASURES: Restrict access to approved enterprise-managed storage accounts only.
Deploy CASB and DLP controls to govern uploads to cloud applications.
Block unmanaged cloud storage applications at the host and network layer.
FORENSICS: Review cloud access logs to determine file names, sizes, and target accounts.
Map uploads to internal file access to determine breach scope.
Correlate exfiltration with privilege escalation or staging activities.

T1485.TITLE: Cloud — Data Destruction via Cloud APIs

IDENTIFICATION: Detect mass deletion, instance termination, or destructive API calls targeting cloud storage or compute resources.
Monitor changes to encryption keys, access control lists, and lifecycle policies that remove retention protections.
Correlate destructive API calls with identity compromise or token theft.
CONTAINMENT: Revoke access to the identities performing destructive operations.
Enable retention locks and versioning on storage buckets to recover deleted data.
Place affected cloud accounts into emergency read-only lockdown mode.
COUNTERMEASURES: Enable immutable snapshots, backups, and retention lock on critical cloud data.
Implement guardrails that prevent destructive actions without break-glass authorization.
Segment workloads to prevent a single identity from destroying entire environments.
FORENSICS: Analyze audit logs to identify when destructive actions began and what triggered them.
Reconstruct deleted resources using snapshots and restore workflows.
Correlate destruction with ransom demands, forced access eviction, or counter-forensic activity.

IDENTIFICATION: Detect abnormal increases in compute, storage, or GPU consumption in cloud tenants.
Monitor creation of high-cost instance types or unexpected autoscaling events.
Correlate cryptomining signatures with compromised IAM roles or exposed cloud keys.
CONTAINMENT: Terminate unauthorized compute workloads and revoke permissions used to launch them.
Restrict instance creation in affected accounts to approved templates and service identities.
Temporarily cap spending limits and scale policies during incident handling.
COUNTERMEASURES: Apply cost and resource policies that limit instance types and region deployment.
Rotate compromised keys and enforce workload identity rather than static credentials.
Use detections for mining pools, wallet addresses, and mining binaries.
FORENSICS: Analyze cloud logs to identify which identities created unauthorized compute resources.
Trace connections from mining workloads to attacker infrastructure.
Assess whether mining activity served as a distraction for data theft or persistence.

IDENTIFICATION: Monitor cloud workloads that request identity tokens for additional services not normally accessed by that workload.
Detect abnormal chaining of authentication requests across multiple services or tenants.
Correlate reflective authentication with role escalation or new token issuance.
CONTAINMENT: Restrict authentication delegation for cloud workloads to explicitly approved service dependencies.
Revoke tokens and disable role assumptions originating from compromised workloads.
Harden IAM trust relationships to prevent unauthorized token minting.
COUNTERMEASURES: Use workload identity federation instead of broad-scoped service credentials.
Apply restrictive policy boundaries limiting token issuance scope.
Enforce identity-based segmentation for cloud services.
FORENSICS: Trace token issuance graphs to identify abuse patterns and privilege pathways.
Determine the initial identity used to trigger reflective authentication.
Correlate abnormal authentication with data access or lateral movement.

THREAT_INTEL_IOC_MATCH_NETWORK.TITLE: Threat Intel — IOC Match: Malicious IP / Domain / URL

IDENTIFICATION: Confirm that the flagged IP, domain, or URL is present in at least one reputable threat intel feed or trusted provider.
Correlate network connections to the indicator with endpoint process data, user identity, and time-of-day patterns.
Check whether the indicator is associated with known malware families, C2 infrastructure, or phishing campaigns.
CONTAINMENT: Block outbound and inbound traffic to the malicious indicator at firewalls, proxies, and DNS resolvers.
Isolate hosts that have actively communicated with the IOC, prioritizing systems with repeated or sustained connections.
Suspend or step-up authentication on user accounts tied to suspicious sessions resolving to the indicator.
COUNTERMEASURES: Operationalize intel feeds into prevention controls (firewall, DNS, proxy, endpoint) rather than detection-only lists.
Tune allow-lists for business-critical third-party services to reduce false positives around shared infrastructure.
Establish a routine IOC review cadence to expire stale indicators and promote high-fidelity ones to permanent blocks.
FORENSICS: Pull full connection logs (source host, user, process, destination, bytes) associated with the flagged indicator.
Determine whether data was downloaded, uploaded, or whether the connection was purely beacon-style C2.
Map IOC-driven activity to any malware execution, lateral movement, or credential access on involved hosts.

THREAT_INTEL_MALWARE_FAMILY_MATCH.TITLE: Threat Intel — Malware Family / Tooling Correlation

IDENTIFICATION: Validate that the detected file, hash, or behavior aligns with a known malware family, toolkit, or framework in threat intel sources.
Correlate observed behaviors (persistence, C2 style, file system artifacts) with documented TTPs for the matched family.
Check whether additional infrastructure or artifacts from the same family are present elsewhere in the environment.
CONTAINMENT: Quarantine infected hosts and terminate processes linked to the identified malware family.
Block related hashes, filenames, mutexes, and network infrastructure derived from threat intel reporting.
Disable or step-up protection on accounts accessed during or after the malware execution window.
COUNTERMEASURES: Convert documented IOCs and behaviors for this family into permanent detection and prevention rules across security controls.
Review and harden controls on the specific initial access vectors favored by the malware family (phishing, RDP, web exploits, etc.).
Use threat intel context to prioritize patching, segmentation, and backup validation for assets targeted by this family.
FORENSICS: Compare host artifacts (logs, registry, files, memory) against threat intel reports to validate variant and version.
Assess whether the malware module executed full payloads (exfiltration, ransomware, downloader) or only initial loader stages.
Correlate local findings with any external reporting on current campaigns using this family to estimate intent and impact.

THREAT_INTEL_RANSOMWARE_PROFILE_MATCH.TITLE: Threat Intel — Ransomware Family / Playbook Alignment

IDENTIFICATION: Confirm that observed behaviors (encryption patterns, note format, extension, C2, tooling) match a known ransomware group’s playbook.
Correlate threat intel on this ransomware family with in-progress events such as shadow copy deletion, backup targeting, or mass encryption.
Determine whether the intel indicates double-extortion behavior (data theft plus encryption) and check for exfiltration signs.
CONTAINMENT: Immediately isolate impacted systems and any hosts showing precursors such as C2 beacons or credential theft tied to this family.
Disable compromised admin accounts and revoke high-privilege tokens or sessions referenced in intel for this group.
Block C2 infrastructure, payment portals, and any known negotiation channels associated with the ransomware family.
COUNTERMEASURES: Apply network-level segmentation and disable non-essential lateral movement protocols (RDP, SMB admin shares, WinRM) environment-wide.
Harden backups by ensuring they are offline/immutable and not accessible with the same credentials the attackers have compromised.
Leverage threat intel on initial vector (e.g., specific email lures, vulnerabilities, or remote access services) to close gaps rapidly.
FORENSICS: Compare encryption logic, file notes, and infrastructure to current intel to confirm responsible group and campaign.
Assess whether data exfiltration has occurred prior to or during the encryption phase using DLP and network telemetry.
Document all attacker actions in a timeline and feed back new IOCs and behaviors into internal and external intel sharing channels.

THREAT_INTEL_APT_CAMPAIGN_ALIGNMENT.TITLE: Threat Intel — Suspected APT / Targeted Campaign

IDENTIFICATION: Compare observed TTPs, infrastructure, and malware with published APT or targeted campaign profiles in trusted intel sources.
Verify overlaps across multiple dimensions: infrastructure reuse, malware families, working hours, targeting patterns, and victimology.
Assess whether your organization’s sector, geography, or technology stack matches the known focus of the suspected APT or campaign.
CONTAINMENT: Activate heightened incident response posture with executive awareness and legal/compliance engagement.
Isolate affected hosts and critical identity infrastructure, prioritizing domain controllers, IdPs, and key cloud control planes.
Limit outbound connectivity to only essential destinations while investigation identifies active C2 and staging points.
COUNTERMEASURES: Use campaign-specific threat intel to deploy targeted detections across endpoints, network, and cloud for known TTPs.
Review and harden long-term access vectors (VPN, SSO, privileged accounts, vendor access) favored by the identified APT.
Implement multi-layered monitoring on sensitive data repositories, code repositories, and email systems targeted by the group.
FORENSICS: Build a detailed intrusion timeline and map each step to known APT TTPs to confirm or refute attribution hypotheses.
Share sanitized findings with trusted intel partners or ISACs to refine understanding of the campaign’s evolution.
Identify long-term persistence mechanisms and data of strategic interest that may have been accessed or exfiltrated.

THREAT_INTEL_CREDENTIAL_LEAK_ALERT.TITLE: Threat Intel — Credential Leak / Dark Web Exposure

IDENTIFICATION: Validate reported leaked credentials (usernames, emails, password hashes) against corporate identity stores and directories.
Determine whether exposed credentials are current, reused, or tied to privileged or high-risk accounts.
Correlate leak timing with any suspicious logins, password reset attempts, or brute-force patterns against exposed accounts.
CONTAINMENT: Force immediate password resets and revoke all active sessions for exposed accounts.
Require MFA re-enrollment and step-up authentication for impacted users and admins.
Temporarily restrict high-risk operations (e.g., privilege changes, mass exports) on affected identities.
COUNTERMEASURES: Enforce strong, unique passwords and password manager usage to reduce reuse across services.
Mandate MFA on all externally accessible services, especially VPN, SSO, and email platforms.
Integrate leak-monitoring services with identity governance workflows for faster automated response.
FORENSICS: Determine whether leaked credentials originated from your environment, a third-party breach, or user reuse on external services.
Analyze authentication logs for evidence of credential stuffing, password spraying, or targeted account takeover.
Correlate any successful logins that followed the leak with data access, changes, or device enrollment events.

THREAT_INTEL_SUPPLY_CHAIN_VENDOR_COMPROM.TITLE: Threat Intel — Vendor / Supply Chain Compromise Notification

IDENTIFICATION: Validate the authenticity of the vendor compromise notification or threat intel advisory via multiple trusted channels.
Identify all integrations, VPNs, SSO connections, and data flows between your environment and the compromised vendor.
Correlate any traffic, logins, or data transfers from the vendor’s infrastructure with current or recent anomaly detections.
CONTAINMENT: Temporarily limit or disable connectivity (VPN, SSO, API access) from the compromised vendor until risk is evaluated.
Revoke or rotate credentials, tokens, keys, and shared secrets used for vendor integrations.
Apply additional monitoring and restrictions around systems and data exposed to the vendor.
COUNTERMEASURES: Segment critical systems and data away from third-party access paths wherever possible.
Implement zero-trust controls for vendor access, with strong authentication and least-privilege authorization.
Align vendor security requirements and contracts with your minimum security baselines and monitoring expectations.
FORENSICS: Review historical logs for vendor-originated sessions, API calls, and data transfers to determine potential exposure.
Work with the vendor (where feasible) to obtain incident details, IOCs, and timelines that affect your environment.
Document all dependencies on the vendor for future risk assessments and potential vendor diversification.

THREAT_INTEL_ZERO_DAY_CAMPAIGN.TITLE: Threat Intel — Active Zero-Day Campaign Against Your Tech Stack

IDENTIFICATION: Confirm that the reported zero-day affects software, services, or devices present in your environment.
Identify all exposed instances of the vulnerable technology, both externally facing and internal, using asset and vulnerability data.
Correlate intel IOCs and behavioral indicators for the zero-day with current detections in logs, EDR, and network telemetry.
CONTAINMENT: Apply vendor or community-provided temporary mitigations (virtual patches, config changes, access controls) where patches are unavailable.
Reduce exposure by limiting external access, enforcing strict ACLs, or disabling high-risk features in vulnerable components.
Isolate or place behind strong gateways the most critical instances that cannot be taken offline immediately.
COUNTERMEASURES: Deploy targeted detections for indicators and TTPs associated with the active zero-day campaign.
Accelerate patch testing and deployment as soon as official fixes become available, prioritizing internet-facing and high-value assets.
Leverage threat intel to prioritize work: focus first on vulnerable systems most attractive to the observed threat actor set.
FORENSICS: Retrospectively hunt for exploitation patterns and artifacts back to the earliest reported campaign activity.
Capture logs, memory images, and system artifacts from any systems suspected of being exploited.
Collaborate with trusted intel and incident-sharing communities to refine detection and remediation tactics.

THREAT_INTEL_INDUSTRY_CAMPAIGN_WATCH.TITLE: Threat Intel — Sector / Industry Campaign on Watch

IDENTIFICATION: Review intel on campaigns currently targeting your industry, region, or technology stack, even if no direct indicators are active in your environment.
Compare published TTPs for active sector campaigns with your existing detections and control coverage.
Assess whether any lower-confidence detections in your environment partially align with these campaign behaviors.
CONTAINMENT: Increase logging granularity and alert sensitivity around techniques heavily used in these sector campaigns.
Pre-emptively restrict high-risk access paths (e.g., exposed remote services, weakly secured web apps) that the campaigns are known to abuse.
Coordinate with internal stakeholders about heightened vigilance and potential targeted phishing or social engineering.
COUNTERMEASURES: Map campaign TTPs to your MITRE coverage and prioritize closing gaps in detection and prevention.
Update response runbooks to reference current campaign behaviors and IOCs for faster triage.
Subscribe to additional sector-specific intel sources or ISACs to maintain fresh insight into evolving tactics.
FORENSICS: Perform targeted threat hunts in historical data for key indicators and behaviors tied to the sector campaign.
Document any weak signals or near-miss events to improve future detection rules and tuning.
Feed lessons learned into strategic risk assessments and security roadmap priorities.

IDENTIFICATION: Look for commands or tooling that delete shadow copies, backup catalogs, restore points, or disable recovery services (e.g., vssadmin, wbadmin, bcdedit, wmic).
Detect sudden disabling of backup agents, snapshot tasks, or recovery-related services across multiple hosts in a short timeframe.
Correlate system recovery suppression with suspicious file encryption, privilege escalation, or lateral movement on the same hosts.
CONTAINMENT: Immediately isolate hosts issuing mass recovery-disabling commands and revoke privileged accounts observed executing them.
Block further execution of known recovery-disabling tooling via EDR application control where possible.
Engage backup and platform teams to verify status of off-host/offline backups and ensure they remain intact and reachable.
COUNTERMEASURES: Restrict execution of administrative utilities that manage backups and recovery to tightly controlled admin groups and jump hosts.
Harden backup infrastructure with separate credentials, network segments, and immutability settings.
Continuously monitor and alert on recovery-related configuration changes, treating them as high-sensitivity events.
FORENSICS: Reconstruct the exact recovery and backup settings prior to modification using logs, configuration backups, and system baselines.
Determine which identities issued the destructive commands and whether they were compromised, shared, or misused.
Map the timeline between recovery inhibition, data encryption/destruction, and any ransom or extortion activity.

T1486.TITLE: Impact — Data Encrypted for Impact (Ransomware / Encryption Attack)

IDENTIFICATION: Detect rapid file renames, extension changes, and high-volume writes that match known or novel ransomware behavior patterns.
Monitor for mass access and modification of user and shared directories, especially combined with deletion of shadow copies or backups.
Identify ransom notes, registry keys, or scheduled tasks associated with known ransomware families or encryption tooling.
CONTAINMENT: Immediately isolate impacted systems from the network and stop encryption processes where safe to do so.
Disable compromised accounts, especially those with administrative or backup-related privileges.
Temporarily prevent new file modifications on shared storage and critical servers while scope is assessed.
COUNTERMEASURES: Maintain offline/immutable backups and rehearse restoration procedures for business-critical systems.
Deploy application allowlisting and macro/script controls to prevent untrusted encryption tooling from executing.
Use segmentation and least privilege to reduce blast radius if any single host or account is compromised.
FORENSICS: Identify patient zero and the initial access vector (phishing, RDP, software vulnerability, etc.).
Determine which data sets were encrypted, whether exfiltration occurred prior to encryption, and which keys or notes were used.
Capture samples of the encryptor, keys, and configuration for potential decryption, intel sharing, and law enforcement support.

IDENTIFICATION: Detect unauthorized modification of web content, login banners, internal portals, or other user-facing visual assets.
Monitor for unexpected file replacements, changes to web templates, or edits to CMS themes and static content directories.
Correlate defacement events with suspicious logins, web shell activity, or exploitation of web-facing services.
CONTAINMENT: Revert affected content to known-good backups or versions under change control.
Disable compromised web admin accounts and rotate credentials used to manage web infrastructure.
Block or remove web shells, backdoors, or malicious plugins discovered during triage.
COUNTERMEASURES: Place critical web assets behind robust change-control processes and CI/CD pipelines with signed artifacts.
Harden admin interfaces with MFA, IP restrictions, and VPN requirements.
Regularly patch web servers, CMS platforms, and plugins, and remove unused or legacy components.
FORENSICS: Review web server logs, CMS logs, and WAF data to identify exploitation paths and attacker IPs.
Determine how long the defacement was present, what content was altered, and whether data access also occurred.
Preserve screenshots and content samples for legal, regulatory, and incident reporting requirements.

IDENTIFICATION: Identify changes to internal web portals, intranet pages, login banners, or desktop wallpapers that were not deployed via normal channels.
Monitor for scripts, GPOs, or management tools pushing visual changes to large groups of internal systems unexpectedly.
Correlate internal defacement with privilege misuse, internal threat activity, or existing compromise on management systems.
CONTAINMENT: Rollback unauthorized visual changes through endpoint management and configuration management platforms.
Disable or restrict access for accounts or tools that were used to push defacing content.
Verify that no additional payloads (such as malware or backdoors) were distributed alongside the defacement.
COUNTERMEASURES: Limit who can modify internal login messages, wallpapers, and intranet content to a small, audited group.
Apply integrity monitoring on key internal content directories and configuration locations.
Educate staff on reporting unusual or intimidating visual content as potential security incidents.
FORENSICS: Determine whether the defacement served as a distraction from other malicious activity such as data theft or lateral movement.
Review configuration management, GPO, and software distribution logs to identify origin of the changes.
Correlate internal defacement with user reports, ticket timelines, and any extortion or intimidation messages.

IDENTIFICATION: Detect unauthorized modifications to public websites, customer portals, or externally exposed applications.
Monitor for tampering with DNS records, CDN content, or external hosting configurations that alter what users see.
Correlate defacement with exploitation attempts, credential stuffing, or deployment of web shells and malicious plugins.
CONTAINMENT: Restore defaced content from known-good backups and verify integrity through change-control records.
Lock down access to DNS, CDN, and hosting provider consoles, resetting credentials and enabling MFA where missing.
Block attacker IP ranges and user agents associated with the intrusion, while preserving evidence.
COUNTERMEASURES: Use WAF and RASP controls to mitigate common web exploit paths used to gain write access to content.
Consolidate external web management under hardened accounts, protected with strong MFA and strict role separation.
Continuously monitor external digital assets for unauthorized content changes or injected scripts.
FORENSICS: Determine whether the defacement also included malicious scripts (e.g., skimmers, phishing injections, or redirections).
Trace how attackers gained write privileges: web vulnerabilities, credential compromise, supply chain issues, or console abuse.
Capture full copies of defaced pages, scripts, and associated logs for legal, regulatory, and threat intel use.

IDENTIFICATION: Detect repeated process launches, resource-intensive operations, or exploit-driven crashes that degrade or deny endpoint services.
Monitor for recurring OS or service crash events associated with the same user, process, or remote source.
Correlate endpoint DoS signs with attacker activity such as lateral movement, encryption attempts, or destructive tooling deployment.
CONTAINMENT: Isolate affected endpoints to prevent propagation of DoS tooling or exploit traffic.
Disable or patch vulnerable services being targeted for repeated crash or lock, where operationally feasible.
Temporarily shift critical workloads to unaffected hosts or virtual infrastructure while remediation occurs.
COUNTERMEASURES: Patch operating systems and endpoint applications regularly to reduce exploit-able DoS vulnerabilities.
Limit exposed services and ports on endpoints to only what is operationally necessary.
Enable rate limiting, resource controls, and protective monitoring on high-value servers and VDI environments.
FORENSICS: Collect crash dumps, event logs, and application logs associated with the DoS activity.
Determine whether the endpoint DoS was used as a smokescreen for other actions on objectives.
Identify specific tools, exploits, or scripts used and feed resulting IOCs into broader detection.

T1499.001.TITLE: Impact — Endpoint DoS: OS Exhaustion Flood

IDENTIFICATION: Monitor for excessive CPU, memory, handle, or thread consumption driven by a single process or user that leads to system instability.
Detect repeated resource-intensive API calls, script loops, or test tools intentionally driving resource spikes.
Correlate resource exhaustion with remote connections, scheduled tasks, or malicious tools dropped shortly before impact.
CONTAINMENT: Terminate offending processes and isolate endpoints that show OS-level exhaustion patterns.
Apply temporary resource limits or throttling to services subject to repeated exhaustion attempts.
Fail over impacted workloads to alternate hosts if available and safe.
COUNTERMEASURES: Harden system resource thresholds and configure monitoring to alert well before complete exhaustion.
Restrict use of stress-testing or load-generation tools to dedicated test environments only.
Enforce least privilege so untrusted code cannot directly impact high-value system processes or services.
FORENSICS: Capture resource utilization timelines and identify the exact process chains driving exhaustion.
Determine whether the flooding was manual, script-driven, or part of a larger automated campaign.
Assess collateral damage, including lost availability for critical applications or corrupted in-memory data.

T1499.002.TITLE: Impact — Endpoint DoS: Service Exhaustion Flood

IDENTIFICATION: Detect repeated, high-frequency requests to specific services or APIs on an endpoint that lead to service instability or crash.
Monitor logs for abnormal spikes in error responses, queue backlogs, or timeouts from the same user, host, or source IP.
Correlate service exhaustion with other malicious activity such as exploitation attempts or credential misuse.
CONTAINMENT: Throttle or block abusive request patterns at local firewalls, reverse proxies, or API gateways.
Restart or temporarily disable impacted services while applying mitigations or patches.
Isolate clients generating the abusive traffic and investigate their compromise status.
COUNTERMEASURES: Implement rate limiting, circuit breakers, and backpressure controls for critical services and APIs.
Deploy WAF/API gateways with behavioral detection for abnormal traffic patterns.
Architect critical services with horizontal scaling and autoscaling safeguards where appropriate.
FORENSICS: Review web/service logs to identify abusive patterns and attacker infrastructure.
Determine whether the exhaustion was purely disruptive or used as cover for other attacks.
Feed relevant endpoint and network IOCs back into detection pipelines and threat intel.

T1499.003.TITLE: Impact — Endpoint DoS: Application Exhaustion Flood

IDENTIFICATION: Identify repeated execution of resource-heavy application features (complex queries, report generation, exports) in short intervals.
Monitor for a single user or IP repeatedly invoking expensive operations far beyond normal usage patterns.
Correlate application-level exhaustion with user account anomalies or known malicious IP ranges.
CONTAINMENT: Temporarily disable or restrict access to the abused application functionality.
Throttle or cap resource consumption per session or user for the targeted features.
Suspend or closely monitor accounts that are intentionally driving exhaustion.
COUNTERMEASURES: Introduce server-side limits on concurrent heavy operations and queue management for resource-intensive tasks.
Restrict access to high-cost features to approved roles and vetted workflows.
Instrument application telemetry to detect and alert on unusual use of heavy operations.
FORENSICS: Analyze application logs to determine which operations, accounts, and IPs were involved in the exhaustion.
Identify whether the attacker successfully impacted SLAs, availability, or downstream systems.
Document patterns for future detection and share relevant IOCs with threat intel partners.

T1499.004.TITLE: Impact — Endpoint DoS: Application or System Exploitation

IDENTIFICATION: Detect repeated exploitation attempts against the same service or application leading to crashes or forced restarts.
Monitor for recurring faulting application or system events referencing the same module, input pattern, or remote origin.
Correlate crash activity with known public vulnerabilities or exploit signatures used in the wild.
CONTAINMENT: Remove the targeted system from direct exposure where possible (take offline, move behind a gateway, or apply ACLs).
Apply emergency configuration changes or vendor workarounds to reduce exploitability until full patching is available.
Block attacker IPs, domains, or signatures associated with exploit delivery at network boundaries.
COUNTERMEASURES: Maintain robust and timely patch management, prioritizing internet-facing and business-critical components.
Use exploit mitigation technologies (DEP, ASLR, CFG, sandboxing) to limit impact of crash-inducing exploits.
Reduce attack surface by disabling unneeded services and modules on exposed endpoints.
FORENSICS: Collect crash dumps and logs for analysis to confirm exploit type and impacted components.
Correlate exploitation with any follow-on actions (backdoor deploy, privilege escalation, lateral movement).
Document exploited vulnerabilities and ensure long-term remediation and hardening are tracked to completion.

IDENTIFICATION: Detect unusual spikes in inbound or outbound traffic saturating bandwidth, especially towards specific services or IPs.
Monitor for sudden increases in dropped packets, connection failures, or timeouts affecting critical services.
Correlate network DoS indicators with known DDoS infrastructure, reflectors, or botnet activity from threat intel.
CONTAINMENT: Engage upstream providers, DDoS protection services, or scrubbing centers to filter malicious traffic.
Apply temporary filtering, rate limiting, or geoblocking at perimeter devices to reduce attack volume.
Fail over critical services to more resilient or protected network paths where possible.
COUNTERMEASURES: Deploy DDoS protection and rate-limiting controls for internet-exposed services.
Segment critical services onto separate network paths and protected IP ranges to limit collateral damage.
Ensure capacity planning includes burst tolerance and pre-defined response steps for volumetric attacks.
FORENSICS: Analyze traffic captures and flow logs to understand attack vectors, sources, and used protocols.
Identify whether the DoS was opportunistic, extortion-based, or part of a broader intrusion campaign.
Feed attacker infrastructure details into threat intel and blocklists for future protection.

T1498.001.TITLE: Impact — Network DoS: Direct Network Flood

IDENTIFICATION: Monitor for large volumes of traffic from one or more sources directly targeting a service or IP with no legitimate pattern.
Identify protocol floods (TCP, UDP, ICMP, or application-layer) significantly above normal baselines.
Correlate attack traffic with known botnet nodes, compromised hosts, or previous attack campaigns.
CONTAINMENT: Apply ACLs, rate limits, and blackhole routes for clearly malicious sources where operationally acceptable.
Reroute attack traffic through scrubbing providers or DDoS mitigation platforms.
Temporarily reduce exposed surface (services, ports, IPs) for targeted systems to maintain partial availability.
COUNTERMEASURES: Establish baseline network profiles and alarms for anomalous volume or protocol use.
Work with ISPs and cloud providers to preconfigure DDoS response paths and contacts.
Limit direct internet exposure where possible by placing services behind reverse proxies or CDNs.
FORENSICS: Capture representative traffic samples to document attack methods and patterns.
Determine if the attack coincides with extortion attempts, political events, or targeted business cycles.
Share sanitized indicators with industry peers and intel partners to improve collective defense.

IDENTIFICATION: Detect large volumes of unsolicited responses from known reflector services (DNS, NTP, Memcached, etc.) towards internal IPs.
Identify spoofed source patterns where responses target your infrastructure without corresponding outbound requests.
Correlate amplification traffic with global attack campaigns or misuse of open resolvers and misconfigured services.
CONTAINMENT: Coordinate with upstream providers and owners of reflector infrastructure to block spoofed or abusive traffic.
Implement strict ingress/egress filtering (BCP 38-style) to reduce spoofing opportunities.
Temporarily rate limit or drop traffic from common amplification protocols at the edge when possible.
COUNTERMEASURES: Avoid operating open resolvers or amplifiable services within your environment.
Encourage and support anti-spoofing efforts with partners, ISPs, and industry groups.
Use DDoS protection that specifically accounts for reflection and amplification attack patterns.
FORENSICS: Log and analyze reflector types, response sizes, and target patterns used in the attack.
Assess which services were most impacted and adjust their exposure and resilience strategies.
Update detection and playbooks with attack signatures and lessons learned from response.

IDENTIFICATION: Detect attempts to write or flash firmware on endpoints, network devices, or specialized hardware outside of approved maintenance windows.
Monitor for boot failures, repeated reboot loops, or systems that become unbootable following suspicious activity.
Correlate firmware update events with admin account anomalies, new tools, or low-level access attempts.
CONTAINMENT: Remove affected devices from the network and stop any ongoing firmware flashing activity.
Engage hardware and platform teams to determine feasibility of re-flashing or replacing compromised components.
Disable compromised administration channels (out-of-band management, console access, or provisioning tools).
COUNTERMEASURES: Restrict firmware update capabilities to a small set of trusted processes and dedicated maintenance accounts.
Enable secure boot, firmware integrity checking, and vendor-provided attestation mechanisms where available.
Keep firmware versions current and monitor for vendor advisories related to firmware vulnerabilities.
FORENSICS: Collect copies of firmware images, logs, and device states for comparison to known-good baselines.
Determine whether firmware corruption was used purely for denial-of-service or also to implant persistent malware.
Document affected assets, business impact, and coordinate with vendors or law enforcement where appropriate.

IDENTIFICATION: Monitor for unauthorized code, hooks, or instrumentation injected into processes that render or transform data for users.
Detect mismatches between data at rest (stored values) and data presented to users or downstream systems.
Correlate anomalous application behavior with suspicious module loads, memory modifications, or debugging interfaces.
CONTAINMENT: Isolate affected applications or hosts to prevent further manipulation of live data.
Terminate injected or tampered processes and restore application binaries from trusted sources.
Fail over critical business workflows to known-good instances or backup systems where feasible.
COUNTERMEASURES: Enforce code integrity and signing policies to prevent unapproved modules or instrumentation from loading.
Implement strong change control and integrity checks on applications responsible for critical decision data.
Use application-level logging and auditing to track data transformations and key decision calculations.
FORENSICS: Reconstruct which data fields, transactions, or outputs were manipulated and over what timeframe.
Identify attacker objectives: fraud, process disruption, or hiding other malicious actions.
Coordinate with business owners to correct corrupted outcomes and strengthen controls around affected processes.

IDENTIFICATION: Detect tools or commands performing raw disk writes, MBR/boot sector changes, or low-level disk operations outside of maintenance windows.
Monitor for rapid, large-scale file corruption, volume unmounting, or partition table changes across multiple systems.
Correlate disk wipe attempts with destructive malware activity, failed encryption, or APT-level operations.
CONTAINMENT: Isolate impacted hosts from the network and stop destructive processes if still running.
Prevent additional systems from being reached by disabling shared admin credentials and remote management channels.
Suspend automated reboots or power cycles that could finalize destructive changes on partially affected hosts.
COUNTERMEASURES: Maintain regular, tested, and offline backups for critical systems and data.
Restrict low-level disk tools and raw disk access to a minimal set of trusted admins and processes.
Implement strong monitoring and alerts for anomalous disk-related API usage and driver loading.
FORENSICS: Document which hosts and volumes were wiped, and whether any partial data recovery is viable.
Identify the wiping tool or malware family used and its spread path across the environment.
Correlate wipe timing with attacker objectives, extortion demands, or attempts to destroy forensic evidence.

IDENTIFICATION: Monitor for processes performing large sequential writes of random or fixed patterns across data volumes.
Detect rapid loss of file contents while directory structures remain intact, indicative of content-only wiping.
Correlate wipe patterns with malware families, scripts, or tools known to overwrite disk content.
CONTAINMENT: Stop active wiping processes and power down impacted systems in a controlled manner if necessary.
Protect remaining unaffected volumes and backups by segregating them from potentially compromised admin paths.
Disable access for accounts that executed or scheduled content wiping operations.
COUNTERMEASURES: Limit installation and use of disk utilities capable of raw writes to specific, audited maintenance workflows.
Use file integrity monitoring and anomaly detection to identify early stages of content wiping.
Ensure backup policies cover both system and data volumes with sufficient point-in-time recovery.
FORENSICS: Assess which files and data types were targeted and whether any selective wiping occurred.
Determine if content wiping was used instead of encryption or in conjunction with exfiltration.
Capture artifacts of the wiping tool and its configuration for threat intel and remediation planning.

IDENTIFICATION: Detect modifications to boot sectors, partition tables, or volume metadata not associated with legitimate maintenance.
Monitor for sudden failure of multiple systems to boot correctly following coordinated suspicious activity.
Correlate structure wiping with destructive malware known to target the MBR or critical disk structures.
CONTAINMENT: Physically and logically isolate affected systems to prevent further propagation of wiping malware.
Coordinate with platform teams to attempt MBR or structure repair only after forensic capture, if feasible.
Prioritize restoration of critical systems from bare-metal or full-image backups.
COUNTERMEASURES: Enforce secure boot and integrity checks on bootloaders and firmware where supported.
Restrict privileges and tools capable of altering disk structures to highly controlled admin workflows.
Harden critical servers and domain controllers with additional monitoring for boot and disk changes.
FORENSICS: Capture full-disk images (even if partially wiped) and logs for deeper malware and timeline analysis.
Identify which systems were targeted first and whether there was logic behind the selection (domain controllers, backup servers, etc.).
Map structure wiping as part of a broader strategy to impede recovery or erase attacker traces.

IDENTIFICATION: Detect deletion, disabling, or lockout of multiple user or admin accounts in a short time window.
Monitor for mass password changes, MFA resets, or role removals that are not tied to scheduled maintenance.
Correlate account removal with ongoing ransomware, destructive activity, or suspicious administrative actions.
CONTAINMENT: Use break-glass or separate admin accounts to restore access and reverse malicious account changes.
Temporarily restrict access to identity administration consoles until compromise is assessed and contained.
Re-enable or recreate critical service and admin accounts using known-good attributes and strong credentials.
COUNTERMEASURES: Enforce strong RBAC for identity administrators and require MFA and just-in-time elevation.
Log and alert on high-risk account operations such as delete, disable, global role change, and mass lockouts.
Maintain multiple independent admin paths (e.g., separate tenants or roots) for recovery from identity compromise.
FORENSICS: Review identity provider and directory logs to identify who initiated account access removal and from where.
Determine which services and systems were impacted by revoked or altered accounts.
Correlate account removal timing with other impact techniques to understand attacker intent and choreography.

IDENTIFICATION: Monitor for unexplained changes to critical business data where there is no corresponding legitimate transaction or workflow.
Detect anomalies where reported values, metrics, or state differ between systems that should be synchronized.
Correlate suspected data manipulation with compromised applications, API misuse, or attacker presence on application servers.
CONTAINMENT: Freeze affected records, systems, or workflows to prevent further reliance on potentially corrupted data.
Fail over to validated replicas or read-only snapshots for critical decision-making processes.
Limit access to the systems and identities capable of modifying the targeted data sets.
COUNTERMEASURES: Implement strong audit logging and non-repudiation for critical data changes, including who, what, and when.
Use integrity checks, digital signatures, or reconciliation processes to detect silent data tampering.
Segment high-integrity systems and apply stricter access controls for processes that can alter key records.
FORENSICS: Identify the scope of altered data, including which records, tables, or objects were affected and over what time.
Determine the attacker’s objective: fraud, misdirection, operational disruption, or cover for other malicious activity.
Coordinate with business stakeholders to roll back or correct manipulated data using logs, backups, and domain expertise.

T1547.TITLE: Persistence — Boot or Logon Autostart Execution (General)

IDENTIFICATION: Identify mechanisms that cause code to run automatically at boot or user logon, including startup folders, run keys, service entries, and logon scripts.
Monitor for modifications to auto-start extension points (ASEPs) outside of approved software installation workflows.
Correlate new or altered autostart entries with suspicious binaries, unknown publishers, or recent alerts on the same host.
CONTAINMENT: Disable or remove unapproved autostart entries while preserving artifacts for analysis.
Block execution of newly registered binaries associated with the persistence mechanism via EDR controls.
Isolate endpoints where multiple or layered autostart mechanisms appear, indicating entrenched persistence.
COUNTERMEASURES: Baseline expected autostart entries for critical systems and alert on deviations.
Restrict write access to common autostart locations (registry hives, startup directories) to administrative processes only.
Use application allowlisting to prevent arbitrary binaries from being registered as autostart programs.
FORENSICS: Collect full ASEP inventories (registry, startup folders, services, scheduled tasks) from impacted hosts.
Determine when each autostart item was created or modified and which account was responsible.
Correlate persistence installation with initial infection vector and subsequent attacker activity.
