T1547.001.TITLE: Persistence — Registry Run Keys / Startup Folder

IDENTIFICATION: Monitor registry locations such as Run, RunOnce, and related keys for new or modified entries pointing to non-standard binaries or paths.
Detect additions to user and global startup folders that reference suspicious executables, scripts, or shortcuts.
Correlate new autostart entries with recent malware detections, phishing events, or suspicious process execution.
CONTAINMENT: Disable or remove malicious registry run entries and startup items identified as unauthorized.
Quarantine referenced binaries or scripts and block their execution across the environment.
Reset permissions on registry and startup folders if they show signs of tampering or overly permissive ACLs.
COUNTERMEASURES: Apply file and registry integrity monitoring to autostart locations with high-sensitivity alerting.
Restrict modification of run keys and startup folders to trusted installer processes and administrators.
Educate users and admins to avoid placing ad hoc scripts or tools into global startup locations.
FORENSICS: Review registry modification logs and ShimCache/AmCache where available to determine when entries were added.
Analyze referenced binaries to understand capabilities such as C2, credential theft, or lateral movement.
Correlate autostart persistence with the broader intrusion timeline, including first execution and operator activity.

IDENTIFICATION: Detect changes to commonly used shortcuts (desktop, start menu, taskbar) where the target path has been altered to invoke malicious binaries or scripts.
Monitor for shortcut targets that chain commands (e.g., cmd.exe /c, powershell.exe -Command) in addition to the expected application.
Correlate shortcut edits with newly dropped executables, scripts, or temporary files in user-writable directories.
CONTAINMENT: Restore modified shortcuts to their expected targets using application baselines or deployment templates.
Quarantine malicious binaries referenced by altered shortcuts and block further execution.
Temporarily revoke write permissions to shortcut locations on affected hosts while investigations proceed.
COUNTERMEASURES: Deploy configuration management to enforce canonical shortcut definitions for critical applications.
Restrict non-admin users from modifying system-wide or shared shortcuts.
Use endpoint monitoring to alert on shortcut changes involving interpreters or unexpected command-line arguments.
FORENSICS: Identify which shortcuts were modified, by which account, and when.
Reconstruct user activity and attacker operations triggered via the altered shortcuts.
Correlate shortcut-based persistence with initial payload drops and subsequent lateral movement.

T1543.TITLE: Persistence — Create or Modify System Process (General)

IDENTIFICATION: Identify creation or modification of long-lived system processes (services, daemons, launch agents) that start at boot or on schedule.
Monitor for system processes configured to run binaries from non-standard directories or user-writable paths.
Correlate new or modified system processes with recent privilege escalation or admin credential use.
CONTAINMENT: Stop and disable malicious or suspicious system processes and document their configurations.
Quarantine associated binaries or scripts and prevent reuse under different process names.
Limit further creation of system processes from compromised accounts or management channels.
COUNTERMEASURES: Enforce strict change control for system process definitions on servers and critical endpoints.
Use application allowlisting to prevent arbitrary binaries from being configured as system services or daemons.
Segment administration tools and credentials used to manage system processes, with heavy auditing.
FORENSICS: Extract process definitions, including executable paths, arguments, and run-as identities.
Determine when and how the system process was created or altered and by which account or tool.
Correlate the lifespan of the malicious process with observed attacker behavior and impact.

IDENTIFICATION: Monitor for new or modified Windows services whose binaries reside in unusual or user-writable directories.
Detect services configured with suspicious start types (e.g., auto-start) that reference unknown executables or LOLBAS abuse.
Correlate service creation with administrative tools (sc.exe, PowerShell, WMI) and privileged user sessions.
CONTAINMENT: Stop and disable malicious services and document their configuration before removal.
Quarantine associated binaries and scripts and revoke accounts used to install or configure the service.
Increase scrutiny on systems where multiple unauthorized services have been observed.
COUNTERMEASURES: Apply group policies and configuration management to control which services can be installed or modified.
Alert on service configurations that run from temp directories, user profiles, or network shares.
Limit service management permissions to dedicated admin groups and jump hosts.
FORENSICS: Review service logs and security events to determine when the service was installed and who initiated it.
Analyze the service binary to understand its capabilities and communication patterns.
Correlate the service’s runtime with other persistence and lateral movement artifacts on the host.

IDENTIFICATION: Monitor LaunchAgents and LaunchDaemons directories for new or modified plist files pointing to suspicious executables or scripts.
Detect launch agents configured to run from user-writable locations or non-standard paths.
Correlate launch agent creation with suspicious downloads, script execution, or privilege escalation on macOS hosts.
CONTAINMENT: Unload and remove malicious launch agents and associated plist files from affected systems.
Quarantine referenced binaries and scripts to prevent reinstallation under different agent names.
Restrict write access to LaunchAgents and LaunchDaemons directories to trusted processes and admins.
COUNTERMEASURES: Implement configuration management to enforce expected launch agent definitions on managed macOS devices.
Enable endpoint monitoring for plist changes in known persistence directories with high-fidelity alerting.
Limit local admin rights and use MDM controls to lock down autostart mechanisms.
FORENSICS: Collect plist files, associated binaries, and unified logs related to launch agent activity.
Determine how long the malicious launch agent has been present and what actions it performed.
Correlate launch agent persistence with user activity, malware delivery, and C2 communications.

IDENTIFICATION: Identify mechanisms where code execution is bound to specific system or user events (logon, lock/unlock, network changes, or system notifications).
Monitor for new or modified event subscriptions, handlers, or hooks that invoke untrusted binaries or scripts.
Correlate event-triggered execution with prior attacker staging such as file drops or registry modifications.
CONTAINMENT: Disable or remove malicious event triggers and associated scripts or binaries.
Restrict access to event configuration interfaces (e.g., WMI subscriptions, logon scripts) to trusted admins.
Isolate compromised hosts where multiple event triggers are present, indicating layered persistence.
COUNTERMEASURES: Baseline expected event-triggered tasks and alert on creation of new triggers outside change control.
Enable detailed logging for event configuration changes and feed them into the SIEM for correlation.
Use principle of least privilege so routine users and services cannot create high-impact event hooks.
FORENSICS: Inventory all event-triggered execution points on affected systems and identify which are malicious.
Reconstruct the conditions under which the triggers executed and what actions were performed.
Correlate event-based persistence with initial access, lateral movement, and impact operations.

IDENTIFICATION: Monitor for creation of new WMI event filters, consumers, and bindings, especially those referencing unfamiliar scripts or binaries.
Detect WMI subscriptions configured to trigger on logon, process start, or system changes tied to persistence patterns.
Correlate new WMI subscriptions with recent WMI or PowerShell activity from privileged accounts.
CONTAINMENT: Remove malicious WMI event filters, consumers, and bindings from affected systems.
Quarantine the executables or scripts referenced by WMI consumers and block further execution.
Limit WMI write access to a minimal set of administrative identities and hardened management hosts.
COUNTERMEASURES: Enable WMI logging and regularly query for non-standard subscriptions across managed endpoints.
Use security baselines to define approved WMI usage and detect deviations from expected configuration.
Integrate WMI subscription checks into regular endpoint posture assessments.
FORENSICS: Export the WMI repository data to identify malicious subscriptions and their creation timestamps.
Determine which accounts created or modified the subscriptions and from which systems.
Correlate WMI-based persistence with C2, lateral movement, and execution artifacts.

IDENTIFICATION: Detect replacement or modification of accessibility binaries (e.g., utilman.exe, sethc.exe) with attacker-controlled executables.
Monitor registry and file changes associated with logon screen accessibility options.
Correlate accessibility abuse with privilege escalation events and unusual interactive logons at console.
CONTAINMENT: Restore original accessibility binaries from trusted sources and verify their integrity.
Remove or revert any registry changes that redirect accessibility executables.
Restrict local console access to critical systems until remediation is complete.
COUNTERMEASURES: Implement file integrity monitoring on accessibility executables and related registry keys.
Use full disk encryption and secure boot to limit offline tampering with system binaries.
Limit physical access to sensitive systems and enforce strong lock/console policies.
FORENSICS: Determine when accessibility binaries were altered and which account or process performed the modification.
Identify whether the mechanism was used for interactive access, persistence, or both.
Correlate accessibility-based persistence with other local and remote attacker actions.

IDENTIFICATION: Detect unexpected web-accessible scripts or binaries placed in application directories or upload locations.
Monitor web server logs for suspicious request patterns invoking rarely used or unknown resources.
Correlate web shell activity with file write events originating from exploited web vulnerabilities or compromised credentials.
CONTAINMENT: Remove web shells and restore affected directories from clean backups.
Block attacker IPs and user agents observed interacting with the web shell.
Rotate credentials and API keys used by the web application or its underlying services.
COUNTERMEASURES: Implement WAF protections and input validation to prevent file upload and RCE vulnerabilities.
Restrict write permissions in web content directories and segregate upload paths from executable locations.
Enable robust logging on web servers and application frameworks, forwarding events to centralized analysis.
FORENSICS: Collect web shell files, server logs, and execution traces for analysis.
Determine how the web shell was initially deployed (exploit, misconfiguration, credential misuse).
Correlate shell usage with lateral movement, credential dumping, and data access from the web tier.

IDENTIFICATION: Identify new accounts created outside standard provisioning workflows or identity governance processes.
Monitor for accounts with elevated privileges or unusual group memberships that appear without supporting tickets.
Correlate account creation with known compromise events, admin credential misuse, or suspicious management console logins.
CONTAINMENT: Disable suspicious accounts until ownership and purpose can be validated.
Revoke privileges and remove group memberships from accounts created by compromised identities.
Limit further account creation by restricting admin rights and tightening identity management controls.
COUNTERMEASURES: Centralize all account creation through automated workflows tied to HR and access requests.
Alert on direct account creation in directories, local systems, or cloud IdPs outside of approved channels.
Regularly review account inventories for dormant, duplicate, or unexplained identities.
FORENSICS: Review identity provider and OS logs to determine who created the accounts and from where.
Assess the usage history of suspicious accounts, including logins, resource access, and privilege changes.
Correlate persistence via new accounts with other footholds such as backdoor services or web shells.

IDENTIFICATION: Monitor for new local user accounts created on servers and critical endpoints outside of normal imaging or deployment.
Detect local accounts added to privileged groups such as Administrators, Remote Desktop Users, or sudoers.
Correlate local account creation with remote logons, lateral movement, or suspicious admin activity.
CONTAINMENT: Disable or remove unauthorized local accounts and reset passwords for any impacted administrative identities.
Restrict remote login permissions for local accounts, especially on servers and jump hosts.
Harden endpoint policies to prevent local account creation by non-managed tooling.
COUNTERMEASURES: Use domain-based or centralized identity solutions and minimize reliance on local accounts.
Regularly audit local account lists and group memberships across endpoints.
Enforce strong policies around local admin usage and prefer just-in-time privileged access.
FORENSICS: Determine when suspicious local accounts were created and from what session or tool.
Review login history, executed commands, and accessed resources associated with each account.
Correlate account-based persistence with other implants or system changes on the host.

IDENTIFICATION: Detect new domain accounts, especially admin or service accounts, created without corresponding change tickets.
Monitor for domain accounts assigned to powerful groups such as Domain Admins, Enterprise Admins, or custom high-privilege roles.
Correlate domain account creation with unusual domain controller logons or compromised admin workstations.
CONTAINMENT: Disable suspicious domain accounts and reset passwords or keys for associated service principals.
Review and remove group memberships and delegated rights associated with the malicious accounts.
Limit domain account creation permissions to a small set of tightly controlled administrative roles.
COUNTERMEASURES: Implement identity governance to enforce approval and attestation for new domain accounts.
Alert on direct domain account creation from unexpected admin hosts or non-standard tools.
Segment domain controllers and administrative workflows to reduce the chance of full directory compromise.
FORENSICS: Use directory service logs to reconstruct account creation, modifications, and logon activity.
Identify which systems and resources were accessed using malicious domain accounts.
Correlate domain account persistence with lateral movement paths and high-value system access.

IDENTIFICATION: Detect creation of new identities in cloud IdPs, SaaS platforms, or cloud providers that are not linked to HR records or approved requests.
Monitor for new cloud accounts granted high-privilege roles, tenant-wide admin rights, or powerful API permissions.
Correlate cloud account creation with suspicious console logins, API calls, or compromised on-prem accounts.
CONTAINMENT: Disable or delete unauthorized cloud accounts and revoke issued tokens and keys.
Review and remove role assignments, group memberships, and access policies associated with the accounts.
Restrict further identity administration to hardened break-glass accounts under close monitoring.
COUNTERMEASURES: Enforce just-in-time privilege elevation and strong approval workflows for cloud identity creation.
Integrate cloud user lifecycle with corporate identity governance and HR systems.
Alert on high-privilege role assignment and new account creation from unusual locations or devices.
FORENSICS: Review cloud audit and access logs for actions performed by the malicious accounts.
Determine whether the accounts were used for persistence only, or also for data access and modification.
Correlate cloud account persistence with other footholds such as API keys, tokens, and workload identities.

IDENTIFICATION: Monitor for creation or modification of at/atd jobs or legacy scheduled job mechanisms used to run arbitrary commands.
Detect jobs scheduled to run from non-standard paths, with obfuscated commands, or under unexpected accounts.
Correlate scheduled job changes with previous malware execution or admin credential misuse on the host.
CONTAINMENT: List and disable suspicious scheduled jobs and document their definitions before removal.
Quarantine referenced scripts and binaries, and revoke associated credentials or tokens.
Restrict job creation capabilities to known administrative identities and tools.
COUNTERMEASURES: Standardize job scheduling through managed frameworks and disallow ad hoc local job creation on critical systems.
Apply file integrity monitoring to scheduler configuration files and job definition directories.
Alert on creation of jobs outside of normal change windows or from non-standard tools.
FORENSICS: Collect scheduler configuration and logs showing job creation and execution history.
Determine what tasks were executed via malicious jobs, including data access and lateral movement.
Correlate scheduled job persistence with other implants present on the same host or in the same environment.

IDENTIFICATION: Monitor for new or modified systemd timer and service units that execute custom binaries or scripts.
Detect timers created in user-specific directories or those pointing to unusual or world-writable paths.
Correlate timer creation with privilege escalation on Linux hosts or suspicious SSH activity.
CONTAINMENT: Disable and remove malicious timer and service units while preserving unit files for analysis.
Quarantine referenced executables and scripts to prevent reuse under different unit names.
Restrict write permissions to systemd unit directories to trusted administrators only.
COUNTERMEASURES: Use configuration management to enforce a known-good set of systemd units and timers on Linux systems.
Apply file integrity monitoring to systemd directories and unit files.
Alert on new or modified unit files that reference non-standard paths or interpreters.
FORENSICS: Gather systemd unit and journal logs to understand when timers were created and what they executed.
Determine how long the malicious timer-based persistence was in use and what activity it supported.
Correlate systemd-based persistence with attacker objectives such as C2 beacons, exfiltration, or recon.

IDENTIFICATION: Detect commands and API calls that enumerate user or account lists (e.g., net user, Get-ADUser, cloud identity list calls) outside of normal admin workflows.
Monitor for large or scripted account enumeration, especially from non-admin hosts, newly created accounts, or atypical geolocations.
Correlate account enumeration with prior suspicious activity such as phishing, valid account usage, or brute-force attempts.
CONTAINMENT: Increase monitoring and conditional access controls on accounts and systems targeted by enumeration attempts.
Temporarily restrict high-risk admin interfaces (e.g., remote directory management, cloud IAM portals) if active enumeration is confirmed.
Review and, if needed, rotate credentials or enforce MFA for accounts most heavily probed during discovery.
COUNTERMEASURES: Limit directory and identity queries to least privilege, ensuring normal users cannot perform broad account listings.
Enable detailed auditing on account-related queries from admin tools, scripts, and service accounts.
Use just-in-time admin elevation for powerful account and group-management operations.
FORENSICS: Review identity provider and OS logs for the specific commands, APIs, and sessions that performed account discovery.
Determine which accounts were enumerated and whether follow-on actions (logon attempts, group membership changes) occurred.
Feed observed discovery patterns into hunt playbooks and future detection logic.

IDENTIFICATION: Monitor for commands that enumerate local users and groups (e.g., net user, net localgroup, Get-LocalUser) on servers and critical endpoints.
Detect local account enumeration from remote shells, scheduled tasks, or tools that are not part of standard management workflows.
Correlate local account discovery with privilege escalation attempts or lateral movement from the same host.
CONTAINMENT: Tighten local admin rights and remove unauthorized local accounts discovered during investigation.
Isolate hosts where local account discovery is observed alongside other malicious behaviors.
Apply enhanced logging and alerting on further local account enumeration from the same source.
COUNTERMEASURES: Standardize on domain or centralized identities and minimize use of local accounts on servers.
Enforce policies that restrict who can query or modify local accounts on critical endpoints.
Use configuration management to routinely audit and remediate local user and group configurations.
FORENSICS: Review host logs for the exact commands and tools used to enumerate local accounts.
Determine whether any discovered local accounts were then leveraged for logon or remote access.
Correlate local account discovery with the broader intrusion chain to map attacker objectives.

IDENTIFICATION: Detect LDAP, PowerShell, and directory-service queries that enumerate large sets of domain users or attributes.
Monitor for bulk retrieval of account details (emails, roles, group memberships) from non-standard admin hosts.
Correlate domain account discovery with Kerberos ticket activity, password-spraying, or lateral movement events.
CONTAINMENT: Increase monitoring and access restrictions on domain controllers and identity management interfaces.
Limit or temporarily suspend directory read permissions for suspicious accounts or sessions.
Alert identity and incident response teams to coordinate defensive actions on exposed high-value accounts.
COUNTERMEASURES: Implement tiered admin models that separate directory administration from general workstation usage.
Use directory ACLs and governance to restrict wide-scope queries to controlled identities.
Apply anomaly detection to identify unusual domain account enumeration patterns over time.
FORENSICS: Review directory and LDAP logs for query scope, filters, and originating systems.
Identify which domain accounts and attributes attackers focused on (e.g., admins, service accounts, VIPs).
Map domain account discovery to subsequent account misuse or lateral movement steps.

IDENTIFICATION: Detect commands and tools that collect OS version, hostname, hardware details, and installed roles (e.g., systeminfo, uname, hostname, WMIC queries).
Monitor for scripted or repeated system profiling across multiple hosts from the same operator or toolset.
Correlate system information discovery with follow-on exploitation or privilege escalation attempts targeting specific OS versions.
CONTAINMENT: Flag and investigate endpoints showing repeated or scripted system profiling from unapproved tools.
Isolate hosts where discovery is combined with vulnerability-scanning or exploit delivery.
Restrict remote command execution interfaces abused to run broad system information commands.
COUNTERMEASURES: Restrict interactive shell and admin tool access on servers to hardened jump hosts.
Implement monitoring that distinguishes normal administrative inventory tasks from attacker-style bulk discovery.
Use EDR policies to limit use of known offensive profiling tools in production environments.
FORENSICS: Review executed commands and captured output (where logged) to understand what system attributes were targeted.
Correlate system discovery timing with initial access and subsequent exploitation steps.
Feed observed discovery behavior into hunt queries to locate similarly profiled systems.

IDENTIFICATION: Monitor for recursive directory listing commands and tools (e.g., dir /s, ls -R, find, PowerShell Get-ChildItem) on sensitive paths.
Detect scripted enumeration of file shares, document repositories, and source code directories.
Correlate file and directory discovery with subsequent staging, compression, or exfiltration behavior.
CONTAINMENT: Increase monitoring and DLP controls on directories and shares that were heavily enumerated.
Temporarily restrict access to highly sensitive shares from suspicious accounts or hosts.
Isolate endpoints performing abnormal breadth/depth of file system discovery.
COUNTERMEASURES: Apply least privilege to file shares and reduce broad read access to critical repositories.
Instrument detailed access logging on high-value data locations (e.g., finance, legal, intellectual property).
Introduce behavioral analytics focused on unusual file traversal depth, speed, and pattern.
FORENSICS: Analyze file access logs to determine which directories and file types were targeted.
Identify whether attackers focused on specific data categories (e.g., credentials, IP, PII).
Correlate discovered paths with later staging and exfiltration events to quantify impact.

IDENTIFICATION: Detect commands and tools that enumerate installed software and versions (e.g., wmic product, dpkg -l, rpm -qa, registry/software inventory queries).
Monitor for scripted or repeated inventory queries from non-management hosts or newly compromised identities.
Correlate software discovery with vulnerability scanning, exploit attempts, or targeted use of known CVEs.
CONTAINMENT: Investigate hosts where non-standard software discovery is observed to determine if they are staging for exploitation.
Temporarily restrict remote execution and scripting on systems being profiled until risk is understood.
Coordinate with vulnerability management to quickly assess and remediate high-risk software found during discovery.
COUNTERMEASURES: Maintain accurate and centrally managed software inventory to reduce the need for ad hoc local enumeration.
Limit read access to detailed software inventory databases to trusted teams and tools.
Alert on use of offensive or dual-use inventory tools in production environments.
FORENSICS: Review logs and tool output to identify which software packages and versions attackers targeted.
Determine if discovery mapped directly to subsequent exploitation or privilege escalation attempts.
Feed observed patterns into threat intel mappings for attacker TTP refinement.

IDENTIFICATION: Monitor for commands and API calls specifically listing security tools, AV/EDR agents, firewalls, monitoring agents, or logging configurations.
Detect attempts to enumerate security services, running processes, or drivers on endpoints and servers.
Correlate security software discovery with later attempts to disable, tamper, or evade those controls.
CONTAINMENT: Escalate to high priority when attackers actively profile defensive tooling on key assets.
Apply stricter monitoring and protection policies on security agents and management consoles targeted in discovery.
Limit access to configuration interfaces and logs that reveal detailed defensive posture.
COUNTERMEASURES: Reduce the exposure of detailed security configuration information to non-security identities.
Harden and monitor the processes, services, and registry keys associated with security software.
Use deception or reduced telemetry disclosure where possible to avoid giving attackers full visibility of defenses.
FORENSICS: Determine which security tools, rules, or sensors attackers identified and whether they attempted to bypass or disable them.
Correlate security discovery events with any observed gaps in logging or sudden drop in telemetry.
Feed findings into security architecture reviews to close visibility and tamper-resistance gaps.

IDENTIFICATION: Detect commands and tools that enumerate hosts by name or IP (e.g., net view, ping sweeps, arp scans, cloud instance listings).
Monitor for broad host discovery across multiple subnets, VNets, or VPCs from a single compromised foothold.
Correlate remote system discovery with newly discovered credentials, VPN connections, or lateral movement tools.
CONTAINMENT: Increase segmentation and ACL restrictions around sensitive network segments identified during discovery.
Isolate hosts performing unauthorized network enumeration, especially in server and admin segments.
Limit remote management capabilities from compromised or high-risk subnets during active incidents.
COUNTERMEASURES: Implement network segmentation so enumeration from a single foothold exposes only a limited scope.
Apply rate limits and anomaly detection to ICMP, SMB, and discovery protocols commonly used in host enumeration.
Ensure network infrastructure logs and flow data are available and integrated into the SIEM for analysis.
FORENSICS: Review flow logs, firewall logs, and endpoint telemetry to reconstruct the scope of host enumeration.
Identify which networks and asset types were prioritized by the attacker for further targeting.
Feed findings into threat models and segmentation improvements to reduce future blast radius.

IDENTIFICATION: Monitor for port scans and service enumeration (e.g., nmap, masscan, nc scripts) across multiple hosts or ports in short time intervals.
Detect unauthorized vulnerability scanning tools or scripts executing from non-approved scanners or admin hosts.
Correlate scanning behavior with prior footholds, privilege escalation, or credential theft events.
CONTAINMENT: Rate limit or block scanning traffic at firewalls, especially from compromised or untrusted segments.
Isolate systems performing high-volume or stealthy scans that are not part of known assessments.
Engage network and vulnerability management teams to verify whether observed scans are legitimate.
COUNTERMEASURES: Whitelist only approved scanners and scanning windows; alert on all other service-scan activity.
Segment high-value services behind additional controls to reduce exposure revealed by scans.
Use honeypots or decoy services to detect and slow hostile scanning.
FORENSICS: Analyze scan patterns (ports, protocols, targets) to infer attacker objectives and capabilities.
Determine whether scanning preceded successful exploitation of identified services.
Feed resulting IOCs into network detection rules and long-term threat intel.

IDENTIFICATION: Detect commands and tools listing active connections and sessions (e.g., netstat, net use, lsof, who, w).
Monitor for repeated or scripted network-connection enumeration from remote shells or non-admin users.
Correlate network connection discovery with credential theft, C2 establishment, or lateral movement.
CONTAINMENT: Increase scrutiny on connections revealed during attacker discovery, especially to domain controllers and critical apps.
Isolate hosts performing abnormal levels of network connection introspection.
Apply enhanced logging for sessions crossing trust boundaries discovered by the attacker.
COUNTERMEASURES: Restrict interactive access to servers where network connection data is highly sensitive (e.g., bastions, DCs).
Instrument EDR detections for network-mapping commands executed outside maintenance tasks.
Use segmentation and zero-trust policies to reduce the usefulness of connection maps for lateral movement.
FORENSICS: Review how attackers used connection information to choose lateral movement targets.
Identify whether they focused on particular service types (RDP, SMB, databases, cloud gateways).
Incorporate discovered patterns into future lateral movement detection tuning.

IDENTIFICATION: Detect installation or execution of packet capture tools (e.g., tcpdump, Wireshark, custom sniffers) on servers and endpoints where they are not expected.
Monitor for interfaces placed into promiscuous mode or abnormal volume of raw packet capture activity.
Correlate sniffing with credential harvesting, session hijacking, or protocol downgrades.
CONTAINMENT: Terminate unauthorized capture processes and remove unapproved sniffing tools from affected hosts.
Isolate systems where sniffing occurred on sensitive segments such as domain controllers, databases, or VPN concentrators.
Rotate credentials and invalidate tokens that may have been exposed via cleartext or weakly protected traffic.
COUNTERMEASURES: Encrypt sensitive traffic end-to-end (TLS, SSH, IPsec) to limit the value of network sniffing.
Restrict who can install and run packet capture tools and enforce logging around their use.
Use network infrastructure to limit access to SPAN/TAP ports and mirrored traffic.
FORENSICS: Determine the time window and network segments covered by attacker packet captures.
Assess which credentials, sessions, or data types were likely exposed during sniffing.
Feed lessons learned into encryption, segmentation, and monitoring control improvements.

IDENTIFICATION: Monitor for enumeration of network shares using commands such as net view, net share, PowerShell SMB cmdlets, or Linux smbclient listing.
Detect scripted or repeated share discovery across multiple servers or domains.
Correlate network share discovery with access attempts to sensitive shares and subsequent file discovery or copying.
CONTAINMENT: Increase logging and alerting on access to high-value shares identified during attacker discovery.
Temporarily restrict access to sensitive or overly permissive shares for suspicious accounts.
Isolate endpoints performing broad share enumeration beyond normal user behavior.
COUNTERMEASURES: Reduce anonymous and overly broad share access; enforce least privilege on SMB and other network file services.
Use access-based enumeration and other features to limit visibility of shares to only authorized users.
Implement data classification and DLP controls on shares hosting critical or regulated data.
FORENSICS: Identify which shares were enumerated and whether data was subsequently accessed or staged.
Determine whether attackers focused on backup shares, admin shares, or business-critical repositories.
Map share discovery to exfiltration activity, ransomware staging, or lateral movement objectives.

IDENTIFICATION: Detect queries and commands that retrieve password policy information (e.g., net accounts, Get-ADDefaultDomainPasswordPolicy, cloud IAM policy reads).
Monitor for scripted or repeated policy inspection from non-administrative endpoints or identities.
Correlate password policy discovery with brute-force attempts, password spraying, or credential stuffing.
CONTAINMENT: Review and, if needed, strengthen password policies that are overly weak or misaligned with current threats.
Apply step-up authentication and monitoring on accounts and services targeted after policy discovery.
Limit generic read access to detailed password and lockout policy objects where feasible.
COUNTERMEASURES: Implement strong password standards and MFA such that policy knowledge provides minimal advantage to attackers.
Log and alert on sensitive policy enumeration from unusual tools or identities.
Use identity governance to limit who can read and modify authentication policies.
FORENSICS: Determine which policies were queried and from which sessions and hosts.
Correlate policy discovery with subsequent authentication attack patterns.
Incorporate observed attacker strategy into future simulations and hardening plans.

IDENTIFICATION: Monitor for commands and tools that enumerate domain trusts, forest relationships, and cross-tenant links (e.g., nltest, Get-ADTrust, AD mapping tools).
Detect trust discovery originating from non-domain-controller systems or unusual admin hosts.
Correlate domain trust discovery with lateral movement into new domains or external directories.
CONTAINMENT: Increase monitoring and restrictions on trust paths identified as being probed by attackers.
Temporarily tighten or suspend high-risk trusts if active misuse is suspected and business impact is acceptable.
Limit access to domain trust configuration tools and APIs to dedicated directory admins.
COUNTERMEASURES: Rationalize trust relationships and remove legacy or unnecessary domain and forest trusts.
Implement conditional access and additional controls on cross-domain and cross-tenant authentication paths.
Regularly review trust topology and logging coverage for movements across trust boundaries.
FORENSICS: Review logs detailing which trusts were enumerated and what subsequent access attempts were made.
Determine whether attackers used enumerated trusts to reach additional domains or tenants.
Feed trust topology learnings into segmentation and identity governance improvements.

IDENTIFICATION: Detect enumeration of security groups, roles, or permission sets via directory queries, IAM listing calls, or platform-specific commands.
Monitor for attempts to list group members for administrative or privileged roles in bulk.
Correlate permission group discovery with follow-on access attempts to join or abuse those groups.
CONTAINMENT: Increase monitoring on sensitive groups and roles discovered by attackers, including membership changes and token issuance.
Temporarily restrict high-risk group administration activities if compromise is suspected.
Review recent role and group modifications performed by suspicious identities.
COUNTERMEASURES: Apply least privilege to group memberships and roles, avoiding unnecessary global or tenant-wide privileges.
Enable alerting for modifications to critical groups, including admin and break-glass roles.
Use role-based access control with tight scoping rather than broad, catch-all permission groups.
FORENSICS: Identify which groups and roles were enumerated and which were later targeted or abused.
Determine whether group discovery was performed manually or via automated tooling.
Feed patterns into IAM monitoring rules and red-team scenarios.

IDENTIFICATION: Monitor for commands listing local groups and their members (e.g., net localgroup, PowerShell group queries) on servers and privileged endpoints.
Detect repeated local group enumeration from remote shells or untrusted user sessions.
Correlate local group discovery with attempts to add accounts to powerful local groups.
CONTAINMENT: Audit and clean up local group memberships on systems where discovery has occurred.
Restrict local group management privileges to defined admin identities and management tools.
Increase monitoring for local group changes following discovery events.
COUNTERMEASURES: Standardize local group configurations through configuration management and baseline enforcement.
Minimize use of powerful local groups on servers and critical workstations.
Alert on local group enumeration emanating from non-admin users or non-jump hosts.
FORENSICS: Review event logs for local group queries and subsequent membership changes.
Determine whether attackers successfully leveraged local group privileges for lateral movement or impact.
Feed observations into local privilege hardening efforts.

IDENTIFICATION: Detect LDAP and directory queries enumerating domain groups, especially administrative or custom privileged groups.
Monitor for bulk group listing and member enumeration from unusual hosts or newly active accounts.
Correlate domain group discovery with group membership changes or token abuse.
CONTAINMENT: Monitor and, if necessary, suspend group management actions from suspicious identities.
Review and lock down membership of critical domain groups that attackers have enumerated.
Increase audit and alerting around token issuance for high-privilege groups.
COUNTERMEASURES: Enforce strong approval workflows for changes to domain groups with elevated privileges.
Limit read access to highly sensitive group membership data where possible.
Integrate domain group monitoring with identity threat detection platforms.
FORENSICS: Analyze which groups were examined and whether members were targeted for credential theft or phishing.
Tie group discovery events to subsequent logons or access attempts by attacker-controlled accounts.
Feed results into IAM hardening and admin training programs.

IDENTIFICATION: Monitor cloud IAM and SaaS admin APIs for listing of roles, permission sets, and security groups outside normal change windows.
Detect scripted or broad enumeration of cloud roles and policies from suspicious API clients or unusual regions.
Correlate cloud group discovery with subsequent attempts to assume roles or modify access policies.
CONTAINMENT: Enable heightened monitoring for role assumption and policy changes on roles discovered by attackers.
Temporarily restrict sensitive role assumption paths if compromise is suspected.
Isolate or rotate API keys, tokens, and credentials used to enumerate cloud IAM.
COUNTERMEASURES: Use least-privilege IAM design and avoid overpowered catch-all roles or groups.
Alert on enumeration of high-privilege roles and cross-account trust relationships.
Require MFA and strong device posture for access to IAM configuration consoles.
FORENSICS: Review cloud audit logs to determine which IAM objects were listed and by which identities.
Correlate group/role discovery with any subsequent privilege escalations or data access.
Feed patterns into cloud threat detection and IAM governance playbooks.

IDENTIFICATION: Detect commands and APIs that enumerate running processes (e.g., tasklist, ps, Get-Process) in patterns inconsistent with normal admin activity.
Monitor for repeated process enumeration from malware, scripts, or remote shells soon after initial execution.
Correlate process discovery with targeted killing or injection into specific processes (e.g., security tools, browsers, database engines).
CONTAINMENT: Investigate endpoints where persistent or scripted process enumeration is observed from suspicious binaries.
Increase protection around critical processes identified during attacker discovery (e.g., EDR, identity agents).
Isolate compromised hosts exhibiting process discovery plus tampering behavior.
COUNTERMEASURES: Limit non-admin use of low-level process inspection tools on sensitive systems.
Improve logging and detection coverage for process enumeration from untrusted code.
Use application control to prevent execution of known offensive tooling used for process mapping.
FORENSICS: Review which processes were present and likely of interest to the attacker at the time of discovery.
Determine whether discovery was followed by injection, termination, or evasion actions.
Feed insights into EDR and hardening strategies for critical processes.

IDENTIFICATION: Monitor for commands and tools that inspect routing tables, interface configurations, DNS settings, and firewall rules (e.g., ipconfig, ifconfig, route, ip, netsh).
Detect scripted or repeated collection of network configuration data from multiple systems.
Correlate configuration discovery with subsequent attempts to pivot across subnets or modify local firewall settings.
CONTAINMENT: Review and secure network paths and interfaces identified during attacker discovery, especially those bridging trust zones.
Limit ability of compromised accounts to modify local firewall or routing settings.
Isolate endpoints where extensive network configuration discovery is combined with evidence of lateral movement.
COUNTERMEASURES: Use centralized network configuration management and monitoring to reduce reliance on manual inspection.
Restrict access to tools capable of modifying network configuration on critical systems.
Alert on network configuration commands executed by non-admin users or from unapproved tools.
FORENSICS: Identify which network interfaces, routes, and DNS settings the attacker examined.
Determine if they used this information to reach additional networks, VPNs, or cloud environments.
Feed results into network segmentation and zero-trust improvements.

IDENTIFICATION: Detect commands and APIs that query the current user, logged-on users, or owner of a system (e.g., whoami, query user, logname, environment variable inspection).
Monitor for combined user and host profiling shortly after initial access.
Correlate user discovery with decisions to persist, move laterally, or abandon the host.
CONTAINMENT: Increase monitoring on accounts and hosts where attackers confirmed user context and privilege level.
Lock or reset credentials for compromised users observed during attacker profiling.
Restrict remote access from endpoints where user discovery is tied to malicious activity.
COUNTERMEASURES: Use least privilege so determining current user provides limited advantage to attackers.
Detect and flag scripted user discovery from unusual binaries or remote sessions.
Integrate identity signals (device trust, session risk) into access decisions to limit attacker options.
FORENSICS: Review user discovery activity to understand which identities and devices were of interest to the attacker.
Correlate user discovery timing with subsequent privilege escalation, lateral movement, or data access.
Feed insights into identity security posture and prioritization of protective controls.

IDENTIFICATION: Monitor inbound email for suspicious senders, spoofed domains, unusual reply-to headers, and failed DMARC/DKIM/SPF checks.
Detect messages containing suspicious links, macros, archive files, or executable content, especially to users who do not usually receive such content.
Correlate clicked links or opened attachments with endpoint activity such as new processes, script interpreters, or dropped files shortly after email interaction.
CONTAINMENT: Quarantine or delete malicious emails from all mailboxes using message trace and server-side search where supported.
Invalidate sessions and reset credentials for users who interacted with confirmed phishing content.
Temporarily restrict risky protocols (e.g., legacy auth, basic auth, IMAP/POP) for impacted accounts until incident scoping is complete.
COUNTERMEASURES: Enforce email authentication (SPF, DKIM, DMARC) and implement advanced phishing-resistant controls in the mail gateway.
Deploy sandboxing and safe-link/safe-attachment capabilities for high-risk users and external communications.
Run continuous user awareness training and phishing simulations, prioritizing high-value and frequently targeted roles.
FORENSICS: Preserve full email artifacts (headers, body, attachments, URLs) and related mail gateway logs.
Map delivery, open, and click events to understand who interacted and when.
Correlate phishing events with endpoint, identity, and network logs to determine whether payload execution or credential theft occurred.

IDENTIFICATION: Detect emails with executable, macro-enabled, or script-based attachments (e.g., .exe, .dll, .scr, .js, .vbs, .ps1, macro Office docs) from untrusted or unexpected senders.
Monitor sandbox detonations and AV/EDR telemetry for attachments that spawn command interpreters, LOLBAS binaries, or unusual child processes.
Correlate attachment opening events in mail or endpoint telemetry with immediate process trees that include script engines, installers, or droppers.
CONTAINMENT: Quarantine malicious attachments and recall matching messages from all recipient mailboxes.
Terminate malicious processes spawned from the attachment and isolate affected endpoints from the network.
Reset passwords and revoke tokens for impacted users if credential theft or data access occurred post-execution.
COUNTERMEASURES: Block high-risk attachment types or require detonation in a sandbox before delivery to end users.
Configure Office and PDF applications with hardened macro/script policies and Protected View defaults.
Deploy application control on endpoints to restrict execution of untrusted scripts and binaries originating from mail clients or temp directories.
FORENSICS: Preserve the attachment sample, related email metadata, and sandbox analysis reports.
Reconstruct the full process chain from the initial document or executable through all child processes and network connections.
Determine whether the payload established persistence, deployed additional tools, or initiated lateral movement.

IDENTIFICATION: Monitor for emails containing URLs that use URL shorteners, lookalike domains, or recently registered domains.
Correlate link clicks with downstream HTTP/HTTPS requests to known phishing, malware, or credential-harvesting infrastructure.
Detect browser processes spawning unusual child processes or downloading suspicious files shortly after a link click event.
CONTAINMENT: Block or sinkhole malicious domains and URLs at the proxy, DNS, and secure web gateway layers.
Force sign-out and revoke tokens for users who entered credentials on confirmed phishing pages.
Reset impacted passwords and enable or enforce MFA for accounts whose credentials may have been harvested.
COUNTERMEASURES: Implement URL rewriting and time-of-click inspection for links in inbound email.
Use brand and domain monitoring to identify lookalike domains and preemptively block them in enterprise filters.
Deploy strong phishing-resistant authentication methods (e.g., FIDO2, modern MFA) to reduce credential usefulness.
FORENSICS: Preserve phishing pages, HTML, and server responses where possible, along with SSL/TLS certificate details.
Review proxy and DNS logs to determine which users visited the phishing site and whether downloads occurred.
Correlate phishing link activity with subsequent sign-in events from unusual locations or devices.

T1566.003.TITLE: Initial Access — Phishing: Spearphishing via Service

IDENTIFICATION: Monitor messages received via third-party platforms (e.g., LinkedIn, Teams, Slack, personal webmail) that contain suspicious links or file-sharing invitations.
Detect OAuth/app consent prompts and third-party app grants initiated shortly after receiving social or collaboration messages.
Correlate spearphishing via service with unusual sign-ins, new OAuth grants, or new device registrations for targeted users.
CONTAINMENT: Revoke malicious OAuth tokens and third-party app grants associated with the phishing campaign.
Block or restrict communication from attacker-controlled accounts or tenants in collaboration platforms.
Reset credentials and require re-registration of MFA for affected users where account compromise is suspected.
COUNTERMEASURES: Enable consent governance and admin approval workflows for risky third-party apps and integrations.
Educate users to treat external DMs and messages with unexpected links, job offers, or file requests as high-risk.
Implement anomaly-based detection on cloud sign-ins, device registrations, and app consents tied to collaboration tools.
FORENSICS: Collect chat logs, message content, and app consent records related to the spearphishing campaign.
Determine whether attackers gained access via direct credential theft, OAuth token abuse, or device enrollment.
Feed observed pretext themes and infrastructure into threat intel and future detection signatures.

IDENTIFICATION: Monitor web server and WAF logs for exploit patterns such as SQLi, RCE payloads, deserialization strings, path traversal, and known CVE signatures.
Detect abnormal HTTP methods, unexpected parameter values, or high-error-rate traffic originating from a small set of IPs.
Correlate suspicious web requests with new webshells, modified files, new processes, or outbound connections from the server.
CONTAINMENT: Virtually patch or block exploit traffic via WAF rules, signatures, or geofencing controls.
Isolate compromised web servers from the rest of the internal network and remove them from load balancers.
Rotate secrets, API keys, and credentials stored on or accessible from the compromised application.
COUNTERMEASURES: Maintain rigorous patch management for internet-facing applications and frameworks, prioritizing actively exploited CVEs.
Deploy a WAF with positive security models for critical apps and enforce least privilege on app service accounts.
Use secure SDLC practices and regular penetration testing to uncover vulnerabilities before adversaries do.
FORENSICS: Preserve web server logs, WAF logs, application logs, and filesystem snapshots for the affected host.
Identify the exact exploit path, vulnerable component, and time of first successful compromise.
Correlate initial web exploitation with deploying webshells, credential theft, or lateral movement into the internal network.

IDENTIFICATION: Monitor outbound web traffic for connections to known malicious or newly observed domains hosting exploit kits or malicious ads.
Detect browser processes spawning unusual child processes (e.g., script interpreters, LOLBAS, installers) shortly after visiting a site.
Correlate file creation, registry changes, or exploit mitigation events (e.g., DEP/ASLR alerts) with specific browsing sessions.
CONTAINMENT: Block or sinkhole malicious domains and IPs used for drive-by delivery and exploit hosting.
Isolate endpoints that show exploit telemetry or unexplained browser-linked process trees.
Rotate credentials and invalidate sessions used on sensitive apps accessed from compromised endpoints.
COUNTERMEASURES: Keep browsers, plugins, and endpoint runtimes fully patched and minimize the use of high-risk plugins.
Enable browser hardening settings, including script restrictions, site isolation, and download protections.
Route all web traffic through secure web gateways with reputation, sandboxing, and category-based filtering.
FORENSICS: Collect browser history, cache, and proxy logs to identify the malicious pages and content involved.
Analyze dropped payloads and memory artifacts to determine exploit type and post-exploitation behavior.
Correlate drive-by compromises with further lateral movement or data access activities.

IDENTIFICATION: Monitor VPN, VDI, and remote access gateways for sign-ins from unusual geolocations, impossible travel, or atypical time-of-day usage.
Detect repeated failed logons followed by a successful session from the same IP or ASN, especially to privileged accounts.
Correlate newly established remote sessions with rapid internal lateral movement, privilege escalation, or data access activity.
CONTAINMENT: Terminate suspicious remote sessions and block offending IPs or ASNs at the perimeter.
Require re-authentication with step-up MFA for accounts accessed in a suspicious manner.
Temporarily restrict remote access for high-risk accounts while the investigation proceeds.
COUNTERMEASURES: Enforce MFA for all remote access services and disable legacy/weak protocols and ciphers.
Segment remote access portals from the rest of the environment and limit reachable internal resources.
Implement continuous risk-based conditional access policies informed by device posture and sign-in risk.
FORENSICS: Review remote access logs, including device identifiers, IPs, and user agent strings, for the full session history.
Determine what resources were accessed during malicious sessions, including file shares and admin interfaces.
Correlate remote access misuse with any preceding credential theft or phishing events.

IDENTIFICATION: Detect anomalous logon patterns using valid credentials, including unusual times, locations, devices, and protocols for a given user.
Monitor for sudden use of privileged accounts or service accounts from hosts or networks where they are not normally used.
Correlate valid account use with recently reported phishing, password spraying, token theft, or credential dumping events.
CONTAINMENT: Force sign-out and revoke tokens for accounts suspected of being compromised across all connected services.
Reset passwords and enforce strong MFA re-enrollment for impacted identities.
Temporarily restrict privileged operations from suspect accounts while investigation is ongoing.
COUNTERMEASURES: Deploy phishing-resistant MFA and conditional access to limit the impact of stolen passwords.
Implement strict least privilege for all privileged and service accounts, with just-in-time access where possible.
Use behavioral identity analytics to continuously assess logon risk and block or challenge high-risk sessions.
FORENSICS: Reconstruct the full sign-in history (IP, device, application, protocol) for the compromised accounts.
Identify initial compromise vector (phishing, password reuse, password spraying, token theft).
Correlate valid account misuse with lateral movement, privilege escalation, and data access to determine blast radius.

IDENTIFICATION: Monitor connectivity and access patterns from third-party providers, MSPs, and contractors for deviations in volume, timing, or target systems.
Detect new or modified connections, VPN tunnels, or inter-org trusts that are not tracked in the CMDB or contract inventories.
Correlate provider access with unusual administrative actions, configuration changes, or data access within your environment.
CONTAINMENT: Immediately restrict or suspend connectivity from the suspected third-party channel when malicious activity is confirmed.
Rotate credentials, keys, and certificates shared with or managed by the affected partner.
Engage the third party’s security team under contract terms to coordinate incident response and evidence preservation.
COUNTERMEASURES: Segment and tightly scope all third-party access to only the systems and data required for their function.
Require strong MFA, logging, and contractual security obligations for all trusted relationships.
Continuously review and attest third-party access, revoking dormant or unnecessary connections and accounts.
FORENSICS: Reconstruct the timeline of activity performed over the trusted connection, including commands, changes, and accessed data.
Determine whether the third-party environment itself was compromised or if your credentials were abused in their environment.
Incorporate findings into third-party risk management and contract renegotiation, including revised technical controls.

IDENTIFICATION: Monitor for deployment of software, updates, or dependencies that, while signed or trusted, show anomalous behavior such as unexpected network connections or privilege requests.
Detect changes in build pipelines, repositories, or package registries that introduce new dependencies or modified artifacts without corresponding approvals.
Correlate incident reports or threat intel related to vendor compromises with your internal telemetry for affected products.
CONTAINMENT: Rapidly identify and isolate systems running compromised software versions or images.
Roll back to last known-good versions or artifacts and revoke trust in compromised signing keys or certificates where feasible.
Disable or firewall outbound communications from impacted components until behavior can be fully assessed.
COUNTERMEASURES: Implement software supply chain security controls (e.g., signed artifacts, SBOMs, reproducible builds, SLSA-level hardening).
Continuously validate software integrity at deployment time and during runtime via code signing and integrity checks.
Require vendors to disclose security practices, SBOMs, and incident notifications as part of procurement and contracts.
FORENSICS: Collect and preserve compromised binaries, container images, build logs, and deployment records.
Determine how the malicious component behaved in your environment, including persistence, lateral movement, and exfiltration.
Correlate supply chain compromise with upstream vendor incidents and share relevant IOCs with trusted intelligence channels.

T1195.002.TITLE: Initial Access — Supply Chain Compromise: Software Supply Chain

IDENTIFICATION: Monitor code repositories, package registries, and CI/CD systems for unauthorized commits, tag changes, or artifact replacements.
Detect inclusion of new or modified third-party packages and dependencies that have limited reputation or are recently created.
Correlate deployment of new builds with the first appearance of anomalous runtime behavior, C2 beacons, or data access patterns.
CONTAINMENT: Stop deployment pipelines that rely on compromised components and freeze affected branches or tags.
Rebuild and redeploy from verified clean sources and dependencies after removing malicious changes.
Invalidate any tokens, credentials, or secrets that may have been exposed via the compromised software.
COUNTERMEASURES: Enforce strong access control, code review, and signing requirements on all build and release processes.
Adopt dependency scanning and supply chain security tools to continuously assess third-party components.
Use private, controlled registries where feasible and limit direct pulls from public ecosystems into production pipelines.
FORENSICS: Analyze repository and CI/CD audit logs to determine who introduced malicious changes and how they gained access.
Reverse engineer compromised components to understand capabilities and targeted data or systems.
Feed findings into long-term hardening of build systems, developer endpoints, and code review processes.

IDENTIFICATION: Monitor for unauthorized or unexpected hardware devices connected to workstations, servers, or network infrastructure (e.g., rogue USB, mini-PCs, implant boards).
Detect new MAC addresses, switch port activations, or wireless access points that are not recorded in asset inventories.
Correlate appearance of new hardware with changes in network traffic patterns, spanning-tree events, or out-of-band management access.
CONTAINMENT: Physically locate and disconnect unauthorized devices from the network and power sources.
Disable affected switch ports, wireless networks, or USB interfaces while investigating scope and impact.
Escalate to physical security teams when devices are found in restricted or sensitive areas.
COUNTERMEASURES: Enforce strict physical access controls and visitor management, including escort policies for sensitive locations.
Implement network access control (802.1X, NAC) to restrict new devices from joining trusted segments.
Disable or tightly control USB ports and peripheral connections on critical systems where feasible.
FORENSICS: Image and analyze discovered hardware for firmware, payloads, and configuration to understand capabilities.
Review camera footage, access logs, and visitor records to identify potential insider or physical attacker activity.
Correlate hardware addition timelines with any anomalous access, data loss, or system instability.

T1091.TITLE: Initial Access — Replication Through Removable Media

IDENTIFICATION: Monitor for execution of binaries or scripts directly from removable media paths (e.g., USB drives, external disks) on endpoints.
Detect new or modified files on removable media that match known malware signatures or suspicious naming patterns.
Correlate removable media insertion events with immediate process execution, autorun behavior, or file copy operations to sensitive systems.
CONTAINMENT: Isolate systems that executed code from removable media, especially in air-gapped or high-security segments.
Scan and, if needed, confiscate removable media involved in the incident for offline forensic analysis.
Disable or restrict further removable media use in the affected environment until controls are reviewed.
COUNTERMEASURES: Enforce technical controls to block or limit code execution from removable media, such as ASR rules and application control.
Implement policies for approved and encrypted removable media, with mandatory scanning before use.
Educate users about the risks of unknown or found USB devices and enforce strict media-handling procedures in secure areas.
FORENSICS: Image both the endpoint and the removable media to capture all relevant artifacts.
Reconstruct how the malware or payload was introduced, executed, and whether it propagated to other systems.
Feed IOCs and TTPs into detections for other endpoints that may have interacted with the same media or payload family.

T1027.TITLE: Defense Evasion — Obfuscated or Encrypted Files and Information

IDENTIFICATION: Detect scripts, binaries, or archives that are packed, encrypted, or encoded in uncommon formats or that exhibit high entropy compared to typical files.
Monitor for repeated use of decoding, unpacking, or decryption routines immediately prior to process execution or script interpretation.
Correlate newly dropped or modified obfuscated files with inbound malware delivery events, phishing payloads, or exploitation activity.
CONTAINMENT: Quarantine suspicious obfuscated files and block their execution via application control or EDR policies.
Isolate hosts repeatedly generating or executing obfuscated payloads from critical segments.
Block outbound C2 endpoints associated with unpacked or decoded payloads identified during analysis.
COUNTERMEASURES: Enable advanced EDR heuristics that inspect file entropy, packing behavior, and runtime de-obfuscation.
Use secure email and web gateways that detonate or static-analyze compressed and encrypted attachments prior to delivery.
Harden script execution policies to limit untrusted or unsigned scripts and binaries from executing on endpoints.
FORENSICS: Capture samples of obfuscated artifacts along with memory dumps after de-obfuscation for reverse engineering.
Reconstruct the original payloads and map their capabilities, C2 infrastructure, and persistence behavior.
Feed resulting IOCs and TTPs into detection content, threat intelligence repositories, and hunt playbooks.

IDENTIFICATION: Detect executables that match known packer signatures or demonstrate abnormal section sizes, imports, or entropy.
Monitor for runtime unpacking behavior such as memory allocation followed by large writes and execution permission changes.
Correlate packed binaries with alerts from AV/EDR engines, sandbox detonations, or external threat intelligence hits.
CONTAINMENT: Quarantine packed executables that are not part of the approved software baseline.
Isolate hosts where packed binaries are executing outside of sanctioned software update or deployment channels.
Block known malicious packer families and associated indicators at the endpoint and network layers.
COUNTERMEASURES: Maintain an allowlist of legitimately packed enterprise software and treat all other packed binaries as high risk.
Deploy analysis pipelines that automatically unpack or emulate packed samples for deeper inspection.
Educate developers and IT teams to avoid unnecessary packing of internal tools that complicate detection.
FORENSICS: Unpack malicious binaries in a controlled lab environment and analyze their decrypted form.
Determine how the packed payload was delivered, executed, and whether additional stages were deployed.
Share packer family details and IOCs with threat intel partners to improve ecosystem-wide detection.

IDENTIFICATION: Monitor for repeated download or upload of media files (images, audio, video) from/to suspicious domains or accounts.
Detect tools or scripts known to embed or extract data from media containers on endpoints.
Correlate steganography tool usage with subsequent decoding events and execution of newly created binaries or scripts.
CONTAINMENT: Block communication with infrastructure hosting media-based command or payload files.
Quarantine media files suspected of carrying embedded content for offline analysis.
Isolate hosts where steganography tools are present and being used outside of approved workflows.
COUNTERMEASURES: Apply content inspection and DLP controls to high-risk outbound channels that frequently transfer media files.
Limit installation and execution of steganography utilities within the enterprise environment.
Use threat intelligence to track campaigns leveraging steganographic payloads and preemptively block associated artifacts.
FORENSICS: Extract and analyze hidden data from suspect media using steganalysis tooling.
Reconstruct the communication pattern between infected hosts and steganographic C2 infrastructure.
Feed recovered payloads and indicators into detection, blocking, and hunting operations.

IDENTIFICATION: Detect compilers, build tools, or language runtimes (e.g., gcc, cl.exe, csc, go build) invoked in non-development systems or user contexts.
Monitor for source code or intermediate representations dropped shortly before compilation and execution.
Correlate compile events with the creation of new binaries or scripts that are immediately executed or persisted.
CONTAINMENT: Terminate unauthorized compiler processes and quarantine resulting binaries for analysis.
Isolate endpoints where attackers are compiling payloads, particularly systems not designated for development.
Block outbound communications from newly compiled binaries until they are validated as benign.
COUNTERMEASURES: Restrict access to compilers and build toolchains on production servers and standard user workstations.
Use application control to allow only signed or pre-approved binaries to execute in sensitive environments.
Monitor software distribution channels to ensure compiled artifacts come only from trusted build pipelines.
FORENSICS: Collect source files, build artifacts, and compiler logs to understand what was compiled and how it was configured.
Reverse engineer compiled payloads to determine capabilities, persistence methods, and C2.
Use findings to adjust policies limiting where and how compilation tools may be used.

IDENTIFICATION: Detect binaries, scripts, or services that use names similar to but not exactly matching legitimate system components or applications.
Monitor for malicious files placed in directories commonly associated with trusted software (e.g., system32, Program Files) without corresponding installation logs.
Correlate suspicious naming patterns with known malware families and prior campaign indicators.
CONTAINMENT: Quarantine artifacts determined to be masquerading as legitimate components and terminate associated processes.
Isolate hosts running masqueraded binaries, services, or scheduled tasks for deeper triage.
Harden file system and service permissions to prevent non-admin users from deploying masqueraded executables into protected paths.
COUNTERMEASURES: Maintain strong baselines of known-good binaries, services, and scheduled tasks across key systems.
Deploy file integrity monitoring on critical OS and application directories to detect unauthorized additions.
Educate defenders to recognize common masquerading patterns, including typos, extra characters, and misleading extensions.
FORENSICS: Analyze the full file metadata and process tree for masqueraded components, including creation time and parent processes.
Determine how the masqueraded objects were introduced (phishing, lateral movement, supply chain).
Feed naming and placement patterns into detection rules to quickly spot similar activity in the future.

T1036.003.TITLE: Defense Evasion — Masquerading: Rename System Utilities

IDENTIFICATION: Monitor for legitimate system utilities being copied or renamed to non-standard file names or directories.
Detect execution of system utilities from unexpected paths, especially user-writable directories or temp locations.
Correlate renamed utility execution with suspicious command-line arguments typical of living-off-the-land abuse.
CONTAINMENT: Block or alert on execution of renamed system utilities from non-standard directories.
Isolate endpoints where renamed utilities are used to perform reconnaissance, credential access, or lateral movement.
Remove unauthorized copies of system binaries and restore from trusted sources as needed.
COUNTERMEASURES: Implement application control rules that enforce canonical paths for critical system utilities.
Use EDR analytics to flag uncommon parent process chains invoking renamed utilities.
Restrict write access in directories where attackers frequently place renamed tools.
FORENSICS: Determine who created and executed the renamed utilities and what operations they performed.
Map renamed binary usage to broader attacker objectives such as discovery or data theft.
Incorporate findings into future hunting queries for renamed or relocated system binaries.

T1036.005.TITLE: Defense Evasion — Masquerading: Match Legitimate Name or Location

IDENTIFICATION: Detect files that share names with legitimate applications but have different hashes, signatures, or publishers.
Monitor for binaries placed alongside legitimate executables in the same directory with subtle differences in attributes.
Correlate suspicious lookalike executables with user complaints, crashes, or AV/EDR detections on the same host.
CONTAINMENT: Quarantine impostor binaries and terminate any processes spawned from them.
Restore legitimate application binaries from secure sources and verify integrity via code signing.
Isolate systems where lookalike binaries were executed or distributed broadly.
COUNTERMEASURES: Use code-signing validation and reputation services to differentiate legitimate binaries from impostors.
Implement file integrity monitoring on directories hosting high-value applications.
Harden software deployment channels to prevent unauthorized binaries from being introduced.
FORENSICS: Compare impostor binaries to their legitimate counterparts to understand functional differences and malicious capabilities.
Trace distribution paths to identify how and where lookalike binaries were deployed.
Feed discovered hashes, paths, and metadata into detection and blocking controls.

IDENTIFICATION: Detect suspicious API usage indicative of process injection (e.g., OpenProcess, VirtualAllocEx, WriteProcessMemory, CreateRemoteThread) from untrusted binaries.
Monitor for memory regions in legitimate processes that transition from write-only to executable or contain code not associated with loaded modules.
Correlate injected processes with anomalous network connections, credential access, or persistence activity.
CONTAINMENT: Terminate or isolate processes confirmed to be hosting injected malicious code.
Isolate affected endpoints from critical networks while injected payloads are analyzed.
Block further execution of the injecting binary via application control or EDR prevention policies.
COUNTERMEASURES: Enable advanced EDR telemetry that inspects process memory operations and suspicious API call chains.
Deploy exploit mitigation features (e.g., CFG, ASLR, code integrity) to increase difficulty of injection.
Limit local admin rights and signing exemptions that allow attackers to execute injection-capable tools.
FORENSICS: Acquire full memory dumps of injected processes and analyze for shellcode, modules, and configuration data.
Reconstruct the injection sequence, including origin binary, targeted process, and resulting activity.
Feed signatures of injected code and injector behaviors into detection and prevention content.

T1055.001.TITLE: Defense Evasion — Process Injection: Dynamic-Link Library Injection

IDENTIFICATION: Monitor for suspicious use of LoadLibrary, LdrLoadDll, or similar APIs targeting DLL paths not associated with the target process.
Detect unsigned or untrusted DLLs loaded into high-value processes such as browsers, credential managers, or security tools.
Correlate DLL injection with changes in process behavior, new network connections, or disabling of protections.
CONTAINMENT: Unload or terminate processes where malicious DLLs are injected, prioritizing containment over uptime for critical assets.
Quarantine injected DLLs and block their hashes across the environment.
Isolate endpoints where DLL injection occurred to prevent lateral movement or further credential theft.
COUNTERMEASURES: Enforce DLL signing and whitelisting for sensitive processes where feasible.
Harden search paths and restrict write access to directories where DLLs are commonly loaded.
Use endpoint protections that inspect module load events and block known malicious libraries.
FORENSICS: Analyze injected DLLs to identify capabilities, configuration, and C2 protocols.
Reconstruct the injection timeline and identify the initial vector that delivered the DLL.
Feed artifacts into long-term detection rules and threat intelligence repositories.

T1055.002.TITLE: Defense Evasion — Process Injection: Portable Executable Injection

IDENTIFICATION: Detect PE images mapped into process memory that are not backed by files on disk or loaded modules.
Monitor for sequences of memory allocation, section mapping, and thread creation that indicate PE injection behavior.
Correlate injected PEs with anomalous outbound connections, credential harvesting, or persistence creation.
CONTAINMENT: Terminate processes containing injected PE regions and isolate affected endpoints.
Quarantine any associated droppers or staging binaries used to perform the injection.
Block identified C2 endpoints to disrupt communication from the injected payloads.
COUNTERMEASURES: Leverage EDR that performs in-memory scanning to detect PE structures in process memory.
Harden process integrity controls, limiting which binaries can start and interact with critical system processes.
Apply least privilege and hardening to high-value services to make them unattractive injection targets.
FORENSICS: Dump injected PE regions from memory and reconstruct them as analyzable executables.
Reverse engineer payloads to understand full capabilities and potential impact.
Feed resulting intelligence into detection content and targeted hunts for similar injection patterns.

T1055.009.TITLE: Defense Evasion — Process Injection: /proc Memory Injection

IDENTIFICATION: Monitor Linux systems for suspicious writes to /proc/<pid>/mem and related debugging interfaces by non-root or unusual processes.
Detect use of ptrace or similar system calls by binaries that are not standard debuggers or monitoring tools.
Correlate /proc-based injection with unexpected code execution paths and process behavior changes.
CONTAINMENT: Terminate suspicious injector processes and the compromised target processes where feasible.
Isolate affected hosts from sensitive networks until the scope of injection is understood.
Increase audit logging on debugging and tracing interfaces for systems engaged in high-risk workloads.
COUNTERMEASURES: Restrict ptrace and similar debugging capabilities to trusted root processes only, using kernel configuration or security modules.
Deploy security tooling that inspects and alerts on unauthorized access to process memory via /proc.
Use containerization and sandboxing to limit injection blast radius on multi-tenant systems.
FORENSICS: Analyze audit logs and system call traces to reconstruct the injection sequence and involved processes.
Capture memory snapshots of targeted processes to recover injected code and configuration.
Use insights to refine hardening strategies for Linux debugging interfaces and controls.

T1055.013.TITLE: Defense Evasion — Process Injection: Process Doppelgänging / Advanced Variants

IDENTIFICATION: Detect abnormal use of advanced Windows features such as transactional file systems, section objects, or NTFS tricks that create processes from modified memory-mapped executables.
Monitor for processes whose executable on disk does not match the in-memory image hash or that have no backing file.
Correlate suspected doppelgänging activity with sudden disappearance of on-disk artifacts and evasion of file-based scanning.
CONTAINMENT: Terminate suspect processes that exhibit mismatched disk versus memory images.
Isolate endpoints where process doppelgänging or similar advanced injection behavior is observed.
Block the tools and frameworks used to implement doppelgänging within the environment.
COUNTERMEASURES: Leverage EDR tooling that correlates on-disk executables with in-memory images and flags mismatches.
Restrict access to NTFS and transactional APIs required to perform doppelgänging-style tricks.
