Employ kernel-level protections that detect and prevent execution from manipulated sections.
FORENSICS: Capture memory dumps and NTFS metadata to understand how the doppelgänging technique was implemented.
Reverse engineer injected or modified images to determine capabilities and objectives.
Use findings to tune behavioral detections and educate responders on recognizing this advanced technique.

T1140.TITLE: Defense Evasion — Deobfuscate/Decode Files or Information

IDENTIFICATION: Monitor for repeated execution of decoding or decompression utilities (e.g., certutil, base64 decoders, custom unpackers) by non-admin users.
Detect scripts that embed large base64 or hex-encoded blobs which are decoded and immediately executed.
Correlate decode operations with creation of new binaries, scripts, or configuration files used in subsequent stages.
CONTAINMENT: Block or restrict use of dual-use decoding tools commonly abused by malware where not operationally required.
Quarantine decoded artifacts for sandboxing and deeper inspection.
Isolate hosts where malicious decode-and-execute behavior is confirmed.
COUNTERMEASURES: Configure security controls to inspect decoded content, not just the original encoded file or script.
Limit command-line access to tools capable of arbitrary decoding or downloading and storing remote content.
Develop detections for common deobfuscation patterns used in past intrusions and commodity malware.
FORENSICS: Recover both encoded and decoded forms of files to understand the transformation process and attacker intent.
Trace back to the delivery vector that introduced the encoded content into the environment.
Feed newly decoded payloads and configuration into threat intelligence platforms and hunting activities.

T1218.TITLE: Defense Evasion — Signed Binary Proxy Execution (General)

IDENTIFICATION: Detect system-signed binaries (LOLBAS/LOLBINs) invoked with suspicious command-line arguments, especially when executing scripts, remote payloads, or downloaded content.
Monitor for unusual parent-child relationships where office apps, browsers, or mail clients spawn signed system utilities in rare patterns.
Correlate signed binary misuse with additional defense evasion events such as disabling protections or staging payloads.
CONTAINMENT: Terminate suspicious proxy execution instances and block further use of abused signed binaries with high-risk parameters.
Isolate endpoints heavily abusing signed binary proxy execution techniques.
Quarantine or remove scripts and payloads invoked through signed system utilities.
COUNTERMEASURES: Implement application control rules that restrict dangerous command-line switches for known living-off-the-land binaries.
Maintain and regularly update a list of high-risk LOLBAS utilities with tuned detections.
Harden endpoints such that only trusted management tooling can leverage signed binaries for automation.
FORENSICS: Collect full command-lines, parent processes, and script contents associated with proxy execution events.
Determine whether signed binary abuse was used for delivery, execution, lateral movement, or defense evasion.
Incorporate observed patterns into both EDR detections and red team emulations.

T1218.004.TITLE: Defense Evasion — Signed Binary Proxy Execution: InstallUtil

IDENTIFICATION: Monitor for installutil.exe execution on systems where .NET installer classes are not routinely used.
Detect InstallUtil command lines referencing unusual assemblies, network paths, or user-writable directories.
Correlate InstallUtil activity with creation of new services, registry keys, or persistent components.
CONTAINMENT: Block installutil.exe invocation by standard users or in environments where it is not operationally required.
Terminate InstallUtil-launched processes that exhibit malicious behavior and quarantine associated assemblies.
Isolate hosts where InstallUtil has been abused to install or execute unapproved payloads.
COUNTERMEASURES: Use application control to restrict InstallUtil to signed, approved assemblies only.
Deploy detections that flag InstallUtil usage outside authorized deployment workflows.
Educate administrators about the risks of using InstallUtil on production endpoints without security review.
FORENSICS: Collect the assemblies executed by InstallUtil and analyze their installer classes for malicious behavior.
Review system logs to identify any services or registry entries created via these assemblies.
Integrate resulting indicators into enterprise detection and hunting content.

T1218.005.TITLE: Defense Evasion — Signed Binary Proxy Execution: Mshta

IDENTIFICATION: Detect mshta.exe execution, especially when loading remote or local .hta, .js, or HTML content from temp or user-writable paths.
Monitor for mshta processes spawned from Office documents, browsers, or mail clients.
Correlate mshta usage with subsequent script execution, payload download, or registry modification.
CONTAINMENT: Block mshta.exe in environments where legacy HTA functionality is not required.
Terminate active mshta instances executing untrusted scripts and quarantine associated files.
Isolate endpoints where mshta is repeatedly invoked during phishing or exploit chains.
COUNTERMEASURES: Use application control to prevent mshta from executing arbitrary remote or local scripts.
Harden file associations and script runtimes to reduce mshta’s usefulness as an execution proxy.
Deploy detections tuned to mshta command-line patterns commonly used in malware campaigns.
FORENSICS: Review the HTML or script content executed by mshta for payload URLs, encoded data, and persistence logic.
Trace mshta activity back to the initial delivery vector such as malicious email or drive-by site.
Feed recovered indicators into web and email security filters for proactive blocking.

T1218.011.TITLE: Defense Evasion — Signed Binary Proxy Execution: Rundll32

IDENTIFICATION: Monitor rundll32.exe executions where the DLL path or export function is abnormal, user-writable, or located in temp directories.
Detect rundll32 command lines that embed URLs, scriptlets, or non-DLL file types.
Correlate suspicious rundll32 usage with subsequent network beacons, process injection, or persistence creation.
CONTAINMENT: Terminate malicious rundll32 instances and quarantine associated DLLs or payloads.
Block execution of rundll32 with known malicious arguments or from non-standard directories.
Isolate endpoints repeatedly abusing rundll32 as a proxy execution mechanism.
COUNTERMEASURES: Deploy application control rules limiting rundll32 to approved DLLs and exports only.
Harden system paths and ensure unprivileged users cannot drop DLLs into directories commonly searched by rundll32.
Implement detections for known rundll32-based malware patterns from past incidents.
FORENSICS: Analyze DLLs and payloads invoked by rundll32 to identify capabilities and persistence behavior.
Reconstruct how rundll32 was invoked, including parent processes and command lines.
Feed discovered techniques into detection signatures and defensive playbooks.

IDENTIFICATION: Detect attempts to disable, uninstall, or tamper with security tools, logging agents, or monitoring configurations.
Monitor for changes to firewall rules, AV/EDR policies, and audit settings that are not tied to approved change tickets.
Correlate impaired defense events with known intrusion timelines, privilege escalation, and lateral movement.
CONTAINMENT: Immediately re-enable disabled defenses where possible and restore baseline configurations.
Isolate systems where core defensive controls have been modified or removed.
Escalate incidents where multiple defensive layers were impaired simultaneously as likely active intrusions.
COUNTERMEASURES: Protect security tooling and logging configurations with strong access controls and tamper protection features.
Regularly verify the health and presence of defensive agents and alert on unexpected gaps.
Implement change control processes that log and approve any modifications to defensive technologies.
FORENSICS: Review logs and configuration histories to determine when and how defenses were impaired.
Identify which attacker accounts, tools, or malware families performed the impairment.
Feed lessons learned into improved hardening of security tooling and monitoring of configuration drift.

T1562.001.TITLE: Defense Evasion — Impair Defenses: Disable or Modify Tools

IDENTIFICATION: Monitor for service stops, uninstalls, or configuration changes targeting AV, EDR, firewall, backup, and monitoring agents.
Detect command-line usage of vendor-specific disable switches, tamper attempts, or registry changes related to security products.
Correlate disabling of tools with concurrent execution of malware, ransomware, or lateral movement utilities.
CONTAINMENT: Re-enable or redeploy disabled security tools and restore secure default configurations.
Isolate hosts where defenders have lost visibility or protection due to tool impairment.
Engage vendor support if tamper protection mechanisms were bypassed or failed to trigger.
COUNTERMEASURES: Enable built-in tamper protection features that require additional authentication for disabling security tools.
Limit administrative access to security product consoles and management APIs.
Implement continuous monitoring and alerting for any changes in the status of defensive agents.
FORENSICS: Review logs from security tools and OS events to identify when and by whom they were disabled.
Determine whether impairment originated from legitimate admin credentials or attacker-controlled accounts.
Feed findings into identity hardening, privileged access management, and security tool configuration tuning.

T1562.002.TITLE: Defense Evasion — Impair Defenses: Disable Windows Event Logging

IDENTIFICATION: Detect stoppage of Windows Event Log services or changes to event channel configuration and retention.
Monitor for registry and policy changes that redirect, lower, or disable logging on endpoints and servers.
Correlate logging disruption with other suspicious activities such as privilege escalation, account abuse, or persistence.
CONTAINMENT: Restore logging services and configurations to baseline as rapidly as possible.
Isolate systems that experienced logging suppression during a suspected intrusion window.
Use alternative telemetry (EDR, network, backups) to reconstruct events that occurred during the blind period.
COUNTERMEASURES: Protect event logging configuration via GPOs and hardening guides that restrict modification to specific admins.
Forward logs to centralized collectors in near real-time so temporary local suppression does not erase all evidence.
Alert when logging volume suddenly drops or key channels stop sending events from critical systems.
FORENSICS: Review policy and registry changes to identify the mechanism used to disable logging.
Estimate the time window of missing data and cross-reference with other telemetry sources.
Incorporate identified TTPs into improved logging integrity monitoring.

T1562.004.TITLE: Defense Evasion — Impair Defenses: Disable or Modify System Firewall

IDENTIFICATION: Monitor for firewall service stoppage, profile disabling, or rule changes that open broad inbound or outbound access.
Detect use of command-line tools or APIs to modify firewall rules outside authorized change windows.
Correlate firewall modifications with new C2 channels, lateral movement, or exfiltration activity.
CONTAINMENT: Revert firewall configurations to known-good baselines on affected systems.
Isolate hosts where firewalls were disabled or significantly weakened during an active intrusion.
Block suspicious new ports, protocols, or destinations revealed by compromised firewall rules.
COUNTERMEASURES: Enforce centrally managed firewall policies and restrict local overrides on standard endpoints.
Alert on firewall configuration drift and maintain regular configuration backups.
Use least-privilege access for firewall administration and protect management interfaces.
FORENSICS: Analyze firewall change logs and command histories to identify who modified the rules and how.
Determine which malicious connections were enabled by the altered firewall posture.
Feed this information into segmentation and firewall policy hardening efforts.

T1562.006.TITLE: Defense Evasion — Impair Defenses: Indicator Blocking

IDENTIFICATION: Detect manipulation of hosts files, DNS settings, or proxy configurations that prevents communication with update or security telemetry endpoints.
Monitor for blocking rules added to firewalls or EDR configurations that target security or logging destinations.
Correlate indicator blocking actions with a drop in telemetry from affected hosts or tools.
CONTAINMENT: Restore trusted DNS, proxy, and routing configurations on affected systems.
Remove malicious block rules targeting security infrastructure and re-establish telemetry flows.
Isolate systems that attempted to block indicators from reaching security tooling.
COUNTERMEASURES: Harden and centrally manage DNS, proxy, and routing settings to prevent unauthorized overrides.
Use multiple redundant channels for critical security telemetry and updates.
Alert on attempts to alter hosts files, DNS servers, or firewall rules associated with security endpoints.
FORENSICS: Review configuration changes and command histories to determine how indicator blocking was performed.
Identify which defensive tools and feeds were impacted by the blocking.
Incorporate observed techniques into configuration monitoring and integrity checks.

T1562.008.TITLE: Defense Evasion — Impair Defenses: Disable or Modify Cloud Logs

IDENTIFICATION: Monitor cloud audit logs and configuration changes for disabling, downgrading, or redirecting logging services (e.g., CloudTrail, Activity Logs, audit pipelines).
Detect sudden changes to log retention periods, storage locations, or export configurations without corresponding change tickets.
Correlate logging suppression with suspicious identities, API activity, or privilege escalations.
CONTAINMENT: Immediately re-enable cloud logging services and restore secure retention and export settings.
Limit or suspend access for identities that modified logging configurations until fully investigated.
Use out-of-band telemetry (network, endpoint, backup snapshots) to reconstruct actions taken during logging gaps.
COUNTERMEASURES: Protect logging configurations with strong access controls, MFA, and approval workflows.
Replicate logs to multiple independent accounts or tenants to reduce single-point-of-failure risk.
Alert on any modification to logging configuration for high-value cloud accounts and services.
FORENSICS: Analyze who changed logging settings, from where, and using what authentication methods.
Estimate missing telemetry windows and correlate with other sources to understand impact.
Feed insights into cloud governance and security baselines to prevent recurrence.

T1562.011.TITLE: Defense Evasion — Impair Defenses: Spoof Security Alerting

IDENTIFICATION: Monitor for unexpected or inconsistent security alerts that do not align with telemetry from underlying sensors.
Detect unauthorized senders or applications that generate messages imitating official security tooling or SOC notifications.
Correlate spoofed alerts with attempts to misdirect responders, suppress investigations, or trigger unsafe actions.
CONTAINMENT: Validate suspect alerts against trusted telemetry sources and official tool consoles before taking action.
Block or decommission unauthorized integrations and apps that can send security-like notifications.
Notify operators that spoofing attempts occurred and reinforce verification procedures.
COUNTERMEASURES: Use cryptographic signing, secure channels, or trusted chat integrations for official security notifications.
Restrict who can configure or modify alert routing, email templates, and integration webhooks.
Educate SOC staff and administrators to verify the origin of unusual or high-impact alerts.
FORENSICS: Collect headers, payloads, and metadata from spoofed security messages to trace their origin.
Determine whether attackers leveraged spoofed alerts to achieve additional objectives (e.g., forcing password resets, disabling tools).
Feed findings into improved alert authenticity checks and playbook verification steps.

IDENTIFICATION: Monitor registry writes to keys controlling security tools, logging, startup behavior, and OS hardening settings.
Detect unusual processes modifying autorun locations, service definitions, or browser and script engine settings.
Correlate registry changes with new persistence, disabled protections, or altered application behavior.
CONTAINMENT: Revert unauthorized registry modifications to hardened baselines via GPO or configuration management.
Isolate hosts where registry tampering appears linked to active malware or intrusion activity.
Quarantine binaries responsible for malicious registry edits and block further execution.
COUNTERMEASURES: Limit registry modification privileges to administrative tools and trusted management processes.
Deploy registry auditing focused on autorun, security, and policy keys for critical systems.
Use application control to block untrusted binaries from invoking high-risk registry modification APIs.
FORENSICS: Review registry change logs and transaction records to determine the full set of impacted keys and values.
Identify the processes and accounts that performed the modifications and map them to attacker activity.
Feed new key/value IOCs into detection rules and hardening guidance.

T1222.TITLE: Defense Evasion — File and Directory Permissions Modification

IDENTIFICATION: Monitor for chmod, icacls, Set-Acl, or similar commands modifying permissions on sensitive files, directories, or executables.
Detect sudden broadening of access rights (e.g., Everyone/Full Control, world-writable) on critical paths.
Correlate permission changes with subsequent execution, persistence, or data staging from those locations.
CONTAINMENT: Restore secure permissions on modified files and directories using baseline templates.
Isolate hosts where attackers altered permissions to facilitate execution, tampering, or exfiltration.
Quarantine scripts and binaries used to apply malicious ACL changes.
COUNTERMEASURES: Implement least-privilege file system permissions and avoid granting broad write access to critical paths.
Enable auditing on permission changes for high-value directories and security-sensitive files.
Use configuration management to enforce and periodically re-apply correct ACLs.
FORENSICS: Analyze who modified permissions, on which objects, and at what time.
Determine whether altered permissions were leveraged to deploy malware, access data, or disable controls.
Add paths and patterns to monitoring and hardening guidelines to detect similar attempts early.

DE_RULE_SUPPRESSION.TITLE: Detection Engineering — Rule Disabled or Muted

IDENTIFICATION: Detect SIEM or security platform rules that are disabled, placed in learning mode, or muted outside of an approved change window.
Monitor for suppression filters added to high-value detections (e.g., credential access, lateral movement, exfiltration) by non-SOC change owners.
Correlate rule suppression activity with concurrent or subsequent suspicious behavior in the same log sources or entities.
CONTAINMENT: Immediately re-enable or unmute high-priority rules that were modified without proper authorization.
Temporarily restrict administrative access to detection content for accounts involved in unauthorized suppression.
Notify the SOC lead or on-call detection engineer and initiate an out-of-band review of all recent rule changes.
COUNTERMEASURES: Enforce role-based access control for rule management, separating content authors, approvers, and operators.
Require ticket IDs and justifications for any change that disables or suppresses high-severity detections.
Implement daily or near real-time reporting on rule state changes, including who changed what and when.
FORENSICS: Pull full change histories, including before/after versions of affected rules and the identities that modified them.
Determine whether suppression changes coincided with known or suspected intrusion timelines.
Feed lessons learned into detection governance, including stricter approval workflows for critical rule modifications.

DE_RULE_VOLUME_DROP.TITLE: Detection Engineering — Sudden Drop in Expected Alert Volume

IDENTIFICATION: Monitor baseline firing rates for key detections and identify significant drops in alert volume without corresponding environment changes.
Detect zero-alert conditions for rules that historically fire regularly (e.g., brute-force attempts, malware detections).
Correlate alert volume drops with recent content changes, parser errors, ingestion failures, or log source outages.
CONTAINMENT: Verify that log sources feeding the affected rules are healthy, ingesting data, and correctly parsed.
Temporarily increase alternative detections or hunts targeting the same behaviors while root cause is investigated.
Escalate to detection engineering and platform teams when multiple high-value rules show simultaneous volume drops.
COUNTERMEASURES: Implement health dashboards that track rule and data-source volume trends with anomaly detection.
Tie rule deployment and parser changes to automated tests that validate expected alert behavior on sample data.
Document expected alert baselines for critical rules and review them regularly with SOC leadership.
FORENSICS: Review configuration, parser, and pipeline changes applied shortly before the volume drop.
Determine whether attackers exploited the blind period while rules were failing to fire.
Feed findings into regression testing suites and change management requirements for detection updates.

DE_RULE_VOLUME_SPIKE.TITLE: Detection Engineering — Sudden Spike in Alert Volume (Potential Flood or Misconfiguration)

IDENTIFICATION: Detect significant spikes in firing rate for a given rule, rule set, or data source beyond historical norms.
Identify whether spikes are driven by a small number of entities, a newly onboarded source, or a rule misconfiguration.
Correlate alert spikes with known offensive behaviors such as brute-force, scanning, or decoy traffic meant to overwhelm analysts.
CONTAINMENT: Throttle or batch low-value alerts while maintaining full logging and retention for deeper offline analysis.
Adjust filtering or tuning on noisy rules in a controlled manner, ensuring underlying malicious activity remains visible.
Coordinate with infrastructure teams if spikes originate from legitimate but misconfigured systems generating excessive noise.
COUNTERMEASURES: Design rules with noise budgets, thresholds, and entity-scoped limits to prevent environment-wide flooding.
Use severity bucketing and deduplication to compress repetitive alerts while preserving context.
Incorporate resilience testing into detection engineering to simulate high-volume scenarios without overwhelming operations.
FORENSICS: Analyze spike-driving events to distinguish between benign misconfiguration, testing artifacts, and hostile activity.
Identify whether attackers attempted to hide signal by burying it under high alert volume.
Feed conclusions into rule tuning, playbooks, and capacity planning for the SOC platform.

DE_INGESTION_FAILURE.TITLE: Detection Engineering — Log Ingestion or Parser Failure

IDENTIFICATION: Monitor for sudden drops in event counts, parse success rates, or field population for critical log sources.
Detect sustained parser errors, schema mismatches, or ingestion backlog that prevent timely processing of security events.
Correlate ingestion failures with infrastructure changes, version upgrades, or connectivity issues in upstream systems.
CONTAINMENT: Fail open to archival storage where possible so raw logs are retained even if parsing is degraded.
Temporarily prioritize restoration of ingestion for the highest-value security sources (identity, endpoint, network, cloud control plane).
Engage platform owners to restore pipeline health and confirm catch-up processing of backlogged data.
COUNTERMEASURES: Implement robust monitoring and alerting on pipeline health: latency, error rates, queue depth, and schema validation.
Use versioned parsers and staged rollouts with rollback capability to minimize impact of bad deployments.
Maintain test harnesses and sample logs for each source to validate parsing before production changes.
FORENSICS: Review logs from pipeline components to determine root cause and duration of ingestion failure.
Estimate the volume and types of events affected and cross-check with other telemetry sources.
Document the incident and feed improvements into runbooks and platform reliability engineering.

DE_BLIND_SPOT_SEGMENT.TITLE: Detection Engineering — Unmonitored or Under-Monitored Segment

IDENTIFICATION: Compare asset inventories and network topology against onboarded log sources to identify segments lacking telemetry.
Detect newly created VLANs, VPCs, VNets, or subnets that do not feed flows, logs, or endpoint data into the SIEM.
Correlate access to or from blind segments with high-value applications, identities, or data stores.
CONTAINMENT: Limit exposure of critical systems to or from under-monitored segments until telemetry is established.
Apply stricter network ACLs around blind areas as an interim control.
Notify network and cloud engineering to prioritize onboarding of missing logs and security controls.
COUNTERMEASURES: Integrate CMDB, cloud inventory, and network configuration with SIEM onboarding pipelines to flag gaps automatically.
Require security sign-off when creating new network segments or environments, including logging requirements.
Regularly review coverage reports showing which assets and segments are lacking sufficient detection visibility.
FORENSICS: Analyze historical connectivity to blind segments using flow logs, firewall logs, and asset inventories.
Determine whether attackers have previously abused blind areas during intrusions.
Incorporate the segment into threat modeling and targeted monitoring once telemetry is active.

DE_CORRELATION_GAP.TITLE: Detection Engineering — Broken or Gapped Correlation Logic

IDENTIFICATION: Detect correlation rules that consistently receive input events but rarely or never produce correlated alerts despite known test patterns.
Monitor for rule execution errors, timeout conditions, or misconfigured joins across data sources.
Correlate correlation gaps with known missed incidents or manually discovered attack paths that should have triggered alerts.
CONTAINMENT: Temporarily complement failing correlations with simpler pattern-based rules or hunts targeting the same behaviors.
Disable or clearly label broken correlations to avoid a false sense of coverage while fixes are in progress.
Notify detection engineering and SOC leads of critical correlation failures affecting high-risk threats.
COUNTERMEASURES: Create automated unit tests and replay harnesses for correlation rules using synthetic and historical attack data.
Document dependencies and assumptions for each correlation, including required fields and data sources.
Schedule periodic correlation health reviews to validate continued effectiveness as the environment evolves.
FORENSICS: Analyze rule execution logs and metrics to identify where logic or data alignment failed.
Map missed detections back to the correlation designs to understand why they did not fire.
Update detection roadmaps and resilience plans based on observed correlation weaknesses.

DE_TEST_MODE_LEFT_ON.TITLE: Detection Engineering — Detection Deployed in Test or Inform-Only Mode

IDENTIFICATION: Identify rules and security controls that have remained in test, simulation, or inform-only mode beyond their planned evaluation window.
Detect detections that generate analytics or logs but are not wired into active alert queues or response workflows.
Correlate test-mode detections with real attacker behavior observed via other sources, indicating missed response opportunities.
CONTAINMENT: Promote mature, low-noise test detections into active monitoring and response pipelines.
Retire or redesign tests that continue to produce high noise or low value, rather than leaving them indefinitely in limbo.
Inform SOC analysts of newly activated detections and update runbooks accordingly.
COUNTERMEASURES: Enforce clear lifecycles for new detections: design, test, review, promote, or retire.
Track detection states (test, pilot, production) in a central registry tied to change management.
Schedule periodic reviews of all test-mode content with metrics on efficacy and false positive rates.
FORENSICS: Review historical matches from test-mode detections to see whether any correlated with actual incidents.
Assess whether delays in promotion materially affected time-to-detect for prior campaigns.
Incorporate findings into detection engineering KPIs and improvement initiatives.

DE_TIME_DRIFT_DETECTED.TITLE: Detection Engineering — Time Drift Impacting Detection Accuracy

IDENTIFICATION: Monitor for significant clock drift on critical log sources compared to NTP references or SIEM ingest time.
Detect events arriving with timestamps in the future or far in the past relative to processing time.
Correlate time drift issues with broken correlations, misordered timelines, or anomalous window-based detections.
CONTAINMENT: Coordinate with infrastructure teams to immediately correct time synchronization on affected systems.
Adjust detection windows or temporarily rely on ingest-time fields while host timestamps are unreliable.
Flag incident timelines that may be impacted by drift and annotate investigations accordingly.
COUNTERMEASURES: Standardize NTP configuration and continuous monitoring for clock health across all critical systems.
Design detections to be resilient to modest skew by using both event time and ingest time where possible.
Alert on any host or application whose time deviates beyond an agreed threshold from reference clocks.
FORENSICS: Reconstruct attack timelines accounting for corrected timestamps and ingestion delays.
Determine whether attackers exploited time drift to evade correlation or confuse responders.
Feed findings into infrastructure hardening and SIEM data quality dashboards.

T1068.TITLE: Privilege Escalation — Exploitation for Privilege Escalation

IDENTIFICATION: Monitor for processes spawning from untrusted input paths (uploads, temp, web roots) that immediately request higher-privileged operations or kernel access.
Detect exploitation artifacts such as crash dumps, access violations, or exploit-specific API call patterns on services running with elevated privileges.
Correlate suspicious privilege changes with known vulnerability exploitation attempts sourced from IDS/IPS, WAF, or threat intelligence feeds.
CONTAINMENT: Isolate hosts where privilege escalation exploits are suspected or confirmed, prioritizing domain controllers, management servers, and jump hosts.
Terminate processes exploiting vulnerable services and disable or restart affected services under hardened configurations.
Block associated exploit payload hashes, network indicators, and vulnerable service exposures at relevant control points.
COUNTERMEASURES: Maintain aggressive patching and virtual patching programs for OS, kernel, and high-value services exposed to untrusted input.
Deploy exploit mitigation technologies (DEP, ASLR, CFG, sandboxing) and ensure they are enabled for critical applications.
Continuously monitor vulnerability intelligence and align detection content with actively exploited CVEs in your environment.
FORENSICS: Collect memory images, crash dumps, and relevant logs from exploited hosts to reconstruct the exploit chain.
Determine which privileges were obtained, what accounts or tokens were compromised, and what actions were performed post-escalation.
Feed discovered exploit techniques, payloads, and infrastructure into long-term detection and threat hunting operations.

IDENTIFICATION: Monitor for suspicious use of token-related APIs (e.g., OpenProcessToken, DuplicateTokenEx, SetThreadToken) by non-standard binaries or scripts.
Detect processes that abruptly inherit higher-privileged security contexts without corresponding interactive logon or service transitions.
Correlate access token manipulation activity with concurrent lateral movement, credential access, or defense evasion behaviors.
CONTAINMENT: Terminate processes operating under suspected stolen or manipulated tokens where business impact permits.
Invalidate or reset sessions and tokens associated with compromised identities, especially privileged accounts.
Isolate endpoints where token abuse is observed and review all recent access from those hosts.
COUNTERMEASURES: Limit local admin rights and interactive logons on servers to reduce exposure of high-value tokens.
Harden privileged access workstations and enforce strong session isolation between admin and user contexts.
Deploy EDR detections focused on abnormal token operations and dangerous token-related API usage.
FORENSICS: Analyze token manipulation events, including source processes, target accounts, and resulting privileges.
Determine whether token abuse facilitated further lateral movement or data access.
Feed observed patterns into hunting queries and update detection content for token-based abuse.

IDENTIFICATION: Detect processes that duplicate tokens from high-privilege services such as LSASS, winlogon, or service hosts.
Monitor for suspicious handle access events where low-privilege processes request rights to manipulate security tokens of privileged processes.
Correlate token theft events with subsequent privileged operations or access to sensitive resources.
CONTAINMENT: Immediately reset credentials and sessions associated with accounts whose tokens were impersonated.
Isolate endpoints where token theft has occurred and increase monitoring on resources accessed with stolen tokens.
Block tools and binaries used for token theft (e.g., common credential dumping frameworks) across the environment.
COUNTERMEASURES: Enable security features that restrict access to LSASS and other credential-bearing processes.
Use credential guard or similar virtualization-based protections where available.
Reduce the number of long-lived privileged sessions and enforce just-in-time administration.
FORENSICS: Review security event logs and EDR telemetry to map which tokens were duplicated and where they were used.
Determine whether stolen tokens were leveraged for lateral movement, persistence, or data access.
Integrate findings into risk assessments for privileged accounts and session management policies.

T1134.002.TITLE: Privilege Escalation — Create Process with Token

IDENTIFICATION: Monitor for CreateProcessWithToken, CreateProcessAsUser, or runas usage by unexpected binaries or user contexts.
Detect child processes whose owner or integrity level does not match that of the parent process.
Correlate token-based process creation with recent credential theft, token duplication, or privilege escalation attempts.
CONTAINMENT: Terminate suspicious processes spawned with elevated tokens that do not align with normal administrative workflows.
Reset or revoke access for accounts abused to launch high-privilege processes via tokens.
Isolate systems where malicious token-based process creation is observed.

Analyze binaries or scripts tied to login items for persistence behavior and additional capabilities.

IDENTIFICATION: Detect processes accessing sensitive credential locations such as LSASS memory, SAM hives, NTDS.dit, or Linux /etc/passwd and /etc/shadow files.
Monitor execution of known credential dumping tools or scripts (e.g., Mimikatz-like behavior, secretsdump-style activity) via process command-line and image paths.
Flag sudden access to registry hives, domain controller databases, or system key material by accounts or hosts that do not typically perform administrative or backup functions.
CONTAINMENT: Terminate unauthorized processes performing credential dumping and isolate the affected host from the network.
Invalidate or rotate exposed credentials, prioritizing high-privilege and domain accounts.
Temporarily increase monitoring on authentication activity to identify potential lateral movement using stolen credentials.
COUNTERMEASURES: Apply least privilege and restrict local admin and domain admin account usage to dedicated jump hosts.
Harden logging and EDR policies to capture process creation, handle access, and file/registry reads for credential-related components.
Use Credential Guard, protected LSASS, and secure backup practices to reduce access to sensitive credential stores.
FORENSICS: Collect full process trees, command-line arguments, and binaries associated with credential dumping activity.
Capture relevant memory images, registry hives, and domain controller database copies for offline analysis.
Correlate time of credential dumping with later authentication attempts, lateral movement, and privilege escalation events.

IDENTIFICATION: Monitor for processes opening LSASS (lsass.exe) with read or full access rights, especially non-system tools or unexpected admin utilities.
Detect memory dump creation involving LSASS, such as procdump-style usage, comsvcs.dll minidumps, or similar patterns.
Flag execution of tools and scripts known for LSASS dumping behavior, including unusual use of rundll32, PowerShell, or LOLBins to access LSASS handles.
CONTAINMENT: Immediately terminate processes performing unauthorized LSASS memory access or dumps.
Isolate the host and treat credentials for all users logged on at the time as compromised.
Force password changes and Kerberos ticket invalidation (e.g., purge tickets, reset passwords, rotate service account secrets).
COUNTERMEASURES: Enable LSASS protection (e.g., RunAsPPL) and use Credential Guard where supported.
Restrict and monitor local admin accounts and disallow interactive logons using domain admin credentials on regular workstations.
Deploy EDR rules to detect suspicious handle access to LSASS and block common dump patterns.
FORENSICS: Collect EDR telemetry related to LSASS access and associated process trees.
Review command-line arguments and parent processes for the LSASS-dumping tools.
Correlate LSASS dump times with later suspect logins, lateral movement, or privilege escalation using harvested credentials.

IDENTIFICATION: Monitor access to the SAM registry hive (HKLM\SAM) and related SYSTEM hive keys that are not part of expected backup or system processes.
Detect use of utilities such as reg.exe or custom tools that export or copy SAM and SYSTEM hives.
Flag creation of hive backup files or shadow copies specifically referencing SAM and SYSTEM data outside scheduled backup windows.
CONTAINMENT: Terminate unauthorized processes reading or exporting SAM and SYSTEM hives.
Treat all local account hashes on the affected host as compromised and plan password resets.
Isolate the endpoint if SAM extraction occurred alongside other credential dumping or lateral movement indicators.
COUNTERMEASURES: Restrict who can load, export, or access sensitive registry hives and enforce strong admin separation.
Monitor and alert on SAM and SYSTEM hive export commands and unusual use of reg.exe or volume shadow copy tools.
Disable or tightly control remote registry access on sensitive systems.
FORENSICS: Collect copies of exported hives, command-line history, and process telemetry for analysis.
Identify which accounts and hashes could be recovered from the exported SAM data.
Correlate the timing of SAM access with subsequent authentication attempts and privilege changes.

IDENTIFICATION: Monitor domain controllers for access to or copying of the NTDS.dit file and associated registry hives (e.g., SYSTEM).
Detect use of tools such as ntdsutil, esentutl, vssadmin, or custom scripts to create volume shadow copies specifically involving NTDS.dit.
Flag mounting of DC virtual hard disk backups or file-level exports outside of authorized backup workflows.
CONTAINMENT: Assume full domain credential compromise when NTDS.dit has been accessed or exfiltrated by an adversary.
Isolate affected domain controllers and initiate emergency credential hygiene (e.g., reset KRBTGT, rotate domain admin and service account credentials).
Temporarily heighten monitoring across the domain for anomalous authentication and privilege escalations.
COUNTERMEASURES: Restrict membership in groups authorized to perform DC backups and NTDS.dit access.
Audit and alert on usage of ntdsutil, vssadmin, esentutl, and similar tools on domain controllers.
Protect domain controller backups with strong access controls and encryption, and separate backup networks from production.
FORENSICS: Collect logs showing access to NTDS.dit, shadow copy creation, and related backup activities.
Determine whether NTDS.dit was copied successfully and whether it was exfiltrated from the environment.
Correlate NTDS access with later signs of Golden Ticket, Silver Ticket, or wide-scale credential abuse.

IDENTIFICATION: Monitor access to LSA-related registry locations, such as HKLM\SECURITY\Policy\Secrets, that store service account and system secrets.
Detect tools or scripts that query or export LSA secrets via registry APIs or LSASS interaction.
Flag non-standard processes enumerating or decrypting secrets from LSA-related data stores.
CONTAINMENT: Terminate unauthorized processes accessing LSA secrets and isolate impacted hosts.
Rotate any service accounts, scheduled task accounts, or application credentials potentially exposed.
Increase monitoring for abnormal authentication events involving service accounts and privileged identities.
COUNTERMEASURES: Limit which accounts and processes have permissions to read LSA secrets.
Monitor registry key access and tools known to retrieve LSA secrets from LSASS or the registry.
Use managed service accounts and vault-backed credentials instead of static long-lived secrets where possible.
FORENSICS: Collect registry hives and process telemetry associated with LSA secret access.
Identify which accounts and secrets were likely retrieved based on system configuration and captured data.
Correlate LSA secret access with subsequent lateral movement or use of exposed service accounts.

IDENTIFICATION: Monitor access to locations where cached domain credentials are stored, such as specific registry keys and SECURITY hive structures.
Detect tools that attempt to parse or decrypt cached domain credential data from offline system files or mounted disks.
Flag repeated or scripted access to cached credential storage on multiple endpoints by the same account or host.
CONTAINMENT: Isolate systems where cached credential harvesting has occurred.
Invalidate or rotate credentials for accounts that frequently log on to impacted systems, prioritizing admins.
Consider reducing or disabling the number of cached logons for high-value endpoints where operationally feasible.
COUNTERMEASURES: Limit cached domain credential storage via group policy, especially on high-value or shared systems.
Ensure full disk encryption is enabled to reduce offline harvesting from stolen or decommissioned devices.
Monitor for credential dumping tools and scripts known to target cached domain credentials specifically.
FORENSICS: Collect security hives, relevant registry data, and tool artifacts from systems where cached credentials were accessed.
Analyze which accounts are likely to have cached credentials on compromised hosts.
Correlate cached credential harvesting with subsequent lateral movement paths in the environment.

T1003_006.TITLE: Credential Access — DCSync (Domain Replication API Abuse)

IDENTIFICATION: Monitor domain controller replication traffic and logs for replication requests originating from non-DC hosts or unusual security principals.
Detect use of tools that invoke Directory Replication Service (DRS) APIs to request credential data, such as secretsdump-style activity.
Flag changes in account privileges that grant replication rights (e.g., members of Domain Admins, Enterprise Admins, or replication-focused groups).
CONTAINMENT: Immediately disable or restrict accounts abusing replication privileges.
Isolate compromised hosts used to perform DCSync from the domain network.
Reassess and rotate high-privilege credentials and consider KRBTGT resets if replication-based theft is confirmed.
COUNTERMEASURES: Limit DCSync-capable permissions to tightly controlled, monitored service accounts or DCs.
Continuously monitor for non-DC systems performing replication-like operations.
Implement alerting for changes to sensitive groups and delegation settings that grant replication rights.
FORENSICS: Collect domain controller security logs and replication logs surrounding the DCSync event.
Identify which accounts and attributes were replicated by the attacker.
Correlate replication-based credential theft with subsequent use of Golden Tickets, Silver Tickets, or mass lateral movement.

T1003_007.TITLE: Credential Access — /proc Filesystem (Linux Credentials via Proc)

IDENTIFICATION: Monitor access to sensitive /proc entries such as /proc/<pid>/mem and /proc/<pid>/maps where credential material may be present.
Detect tools or scripts that systematically iterate over /proc entries to extract authentication data from running processes.
Flag unusual read access to security- or authentication-related processes via /proc by non-standard accounts.
CONTAINMENT: Terminate processes that are abusing /proc to read authentication-related memory.
Isolate affected Linux hosts and treat credentials processed on those systems during the event as potentially compromised.
Increase monitoring of SSH, sudo, and other authentication activity tied to impacted usernames and systems.
COUNTERMEASURES: Restrict access to /proc-based memory interfaces where feasible (e.g., Yama LSM ptrace_scope-like controls).
Deploy EDR or audit frameworks on Linux capable of tracking /proc access patterns and process memory reads.
Separate high-value authentication services onto hardened systems with strict local access controls.
FORENSICS: Collect process execution histories, audit logs, and copies of tools used to traverse /proc.
Determine which processes and credentials were likely targeted based on /proc access patterns.
Correlate /proc-based credential harvesting with subsequent SSH or other remote authentication from attacker-controlled hosts.

IDENTIFICATION: Monitor read access to /etc/shadow and related password or account databases by non-root or non-standard processes.
Detect copying, exfiltration, or backup of /etc/passwd and /etc/shadow outside of normal configuration management workflows.
Flag tools that parse or export local password hashes or account files on Unix-like systems.
CONTAINMENT: Terminate unauthorized processes accessing or exporting password files.
Rotate passwords for local accounts stored in the affected password databases, prioritizing privileged accounts.
Isolate compromised hosts if password file access is linked to a broader intrusion.
COUNTERMEASURES: Restrict direct access to /etc/shadow to root and necessary system processes only.
Use strong password policies, multi-factor authentication, and avoid password reuse across systems.
Implement file integrity monitoring on critical account and password files.
FORENSICS: Collect copies of accessed password file data and related logs for analysis.
Determine whether password hashes were likely cracked or reused based on attacker activity.
Correlate password file access with new logins, privilege escalations, and lateral movement events.

IDENTIFICATION: Detect repeated failed authentication attempts against the same account, host, or service within a constrained time window.
Monitor authentication logs (VPN, SSO, RDP, SSH, web apps) for high volumes of failures followed by a successful login from the same source or closely related IPs.
Flag patterns where multiple accounts are targeted from a single IP range, or one account is targeted across many different services.
CONTAINMENT: Temporarily lock or challenge accounts experiencing sustained brute force attempts with additional verification (MFA, step-up auth).
Block or rate-limit IPs and user agents responsible for high-volume failed authentication attempts.
Increase monitoring and alerting for any successful logins following a brute force pattern until the account is confirmed safe.
COUNTERMEASURES: Enforce strong password policies and require multi-factor authentication for external and privileged access.
Implement account lockout, throttling, or adaptive risk-based controls on authentication endpoints.
Segregate administrative authentication paths (e.g., jump hosts, dedicated portals) and monitor them more strictly for brute force attempts.
FORENSICS: Collect authentication logs from affected services including timestamps, source IPs, user agents, and outcomes.
Identify which accounts were targeted and which, if any, were eventually successfully accessed.
Correlate brute force windows with subsequent suspicious activity such as unusual resource access, privilege escalation, or lateral movement.

IDENTIFICATION: Detect repeated authentication failures against a small set of accounts (often one) from the same IP or small IP pool using different passwords.
Monitor for patterns of consistent retries on a single username with slight timing gaps that indicate manual or semi-automated guessing.
Flag authentication attempts that use common or weak passwords (e.g., password1, Summer2024) against monitored or high-value accounts.
CONTAINMENT: Temporarily lock or challenge the targeted accounts after a safe threshold of failed attempts.
Block offending IP addresses or apply captchas and secondary challenges where possible.
Notify impacted users that their accounts were subject to guessing activity and advise review of their password hygiene.
COUNTERMEASURES: Deploy MFA for all external-facing services and for privileged accounts.
Enforce strong, non-guessable password policies and prohibit common or reused passwords.
Tune lockout thresholds or risk-based authentication to quickly react to concentrated guessing attempts without impacting legitimate users.
FORENSICS: Collect authentication logs around the time of the guessing activity, including IPs, user agents, and geolocation data.
Determine whether any guess eventually resulted in a successful login and what actions occurred post-compromise.
Correlate password guessing incidents with other scanning or reconnaissance from the same sources.

IDENTIFICATION: Monitor for the presence or transfer of large credential data sets (hash dumps, password files, NTDS/SAM exports) from production systems to attacker-controlled hosts.
Detect installation or execution of cracking tools and frameworks on internal systems (e.g., hashcat-style behavior, GPU-intensive workloads on non-expected systems).
Flag unusual access to archives, backups, or forensic images that contain credential stores, especially when followed by outbound transfers.
CONTAINMENT: Identify and isolate systems used to store or process dumped credential data.
Treat all credentials contained in the exposed data set as compromised and prioritize resets based on privilege level and reach.
Block exfiltration channels used to move cracked or uncracked credential data out of the environment.
COUNTERMEASURES: Limit who can access and export credential stores, backups, and forensic images, enforcing strict segmentation and encryption.
Ensure that any credential-containing artifacts are stored in controlled environments, not on general-purpose workstations.
Monitor for cracking tools, GPU misuse, and high-intensity compute workloads on systems that should not perform such tasks.
FORENSICS: Determine the scope of credential material that may have been extracted and where it was processed.
Review logging around backup access, file transfers, and tool usage to reconstruct the cracking workflow.
Correlate suspected cracking timeframes with later waves of suspicious logins, lateral movement, or privilege escalation.

IDENTIFICATION: Detect authentication patterns where a small set of common passwords is tried against many different accounts across a domain, VPN, cloud identity provider, or SaaS application.
Monitor for low-and-slow failed login attempts distributed over time across multiple users from the same IP, IP range, or ASN.
Flag spraying against legacy or less-protected protocols (e.g., older mail protocols, legacy auth endpoints) that bypass stronger controls.
CONTAINMENT: Block or rate-limit IPs and ASN ranges performing spraying attacks, especially against external-facing login portals.
Temporarily enforce step-up authentication or MFA prompts for accounts targeted during a spray campaign.
Coordinate with identity and network teams to ensure spraying campaigns are fully understood and contained across all exposed auth surfaces.
COUNTERMEASURES: Require MFA for remote and high-value services and reduce or eliminate legacy, non-MFA-capable protocols.
Deploy detections tuned specifically for distributed, low-rate failed login patterns across many users.
Implement password policies that forbid commonly sprayed passwords and maintain regular user awareness training about password reuse.
FORENSICS: Collect authentication telemetry for all targets of the spray to identify any successful compromise.
Analyze source IPs, user agents, and targeting patterns to attribute campaigns and distinguish broad Internet noise from focused attacks.
Correlate successful logins following a spray with changes in device, location, or behavior profiles for the involved accounts.

IDENTIFICATION: Detect authentication attempts that reuse known breached username/password pairs, often sourced from credential dumps targeting multiple user accounts.
Monitor for bursts of login attempts against many accounts from the same IPs or automation frameworks, where each attempt uses a distinct username/password combo.
Flag successful logins that match credentials known to be part of external breach corpuses or reused across multiple services.
CONTAINMENT: Force password resets for accounts confirmed to have logged in using known breached credentials.
Block or aggressively rate-limit IPs, IP ranges, or automation platforms identified as the source of stuffing activity.
Temporarily require MFA step-up or re-verification for accounts targeted during a stuffing campaign, even if logins appear successful.
COUNTERMEASURES: Integrate with breach credential monitoring services to detect when organization-related usernames appear in public or private dump sets.
Enforce unique password requirements and disallow the use of known breached passwords via password filters where supported.
Require MFA for external and cloud-facing services, especially user portals likely to be targeted by credential stuffing.
FORENSICS: Collect web and identity provider logs to profile credential stuffing activity, including targeted accounts, success rates, and source infrastructure.
Determine whether successfully stuffed accounts were used for data access, configuration changes, or lateral movement.
Correlate credential stuffing patterns with other reconnaissance or intrusion activity involving the same attacker infrastructure.

T1558.TITLE: Credential Access — Steal or Forge Kerberos Tickets (Generic)

IDENTIFICATION: Monitor domain controller Kerberos events for suspicious ticket activity, such as abnormal volumes of TGT or TGS requests, or requests from atypical hosts or service accounts.
Detect use of tools or commands that interact directly with Kerberos tickets, including exporting, injecting, or replaying ticket data on endpoints or jump hosts.

Flag authentication patterns where Kerberos is used to access many services in rapid succession or from unusual devices, especially following credential dumping on a domain controller or admin workstation.
CONTAINMENT: Treat Kerberos ticket theft or forgery as a high-severity domain compromise and activate incident response playbooks.
Identify and isolate systems where tickets were generated, stolen, or replayed (e.g., domain controllers, admin workstations, jump servers).
Plan staged credential hygiene actions, including resetting high-value accounts and eventually rotating KRBTGT when appropriate.
COUNTERMEASURES: Limit the number of accounts with privileges to request or manipulate Kerberos tickets and enforce least privilege on domain admins and service accounts.
Deploy detections tuned to abnormal Kerberos usage such as unusual ticket lifetimes, encryption types, or ticket requests from non-standard hosts.
Enforce strong credential protection controls such as protected users groups, constrained delegation, and hardened domain controller configurations.
FORENSICS: Collect Kerberos-related security logs from domain controllers, including ticket request, issuance, and failure events.
Identify which accounts and services had tickets issued or forged during the suspected compromise window.
Correlate Kerberos ticket abuse with lateral movement paths, service access, and data access patterns across the environment.

IDENTIFICATION: Monitor domain controller logs for Kerberos TGTs issued with anomalous properties such as unusually long lifetimes, unfamiliar encryption types, or unusual client devices.
Detect access patterns where a single account or host suddenly gains broad access across many systems and services using Kerberos authentication.
Flag use of administrative privileges originating from hosts that are not normal admin workstations or jump boxes, especially after suspected credential dumping on domain controllers.
CONTAINMENT: Treat Golden Ticket activity as a full-domain compromise and escalate to highest severity response.
Isolate suspected administrator workstations, domain controllers, and any hosts known to store or process KRBTGT or domain admin credentials.
Plan and execute KRBTGT password rotations in accordance with Microsoft guidance, coordinating closely to minimize operational impact.
COUNTERMEASURES: Protect domain controllers with hardened baselines, limited interactive logon, and dedicated admin workstations.
Implement strong monitoring for LSASS access and DC credential dumping techniques that could expose the KRBTGT hash.
Segment administrative workflows so that KRBTGT and domain admin credentials are never used on low-trust systems.
FORENSICS: Collect domain controller Kerberos logs, security logs, and EDR telemetry from suspected admin endpoints.
Determine when and how the KRBTGT hash was likely obtained and which forged TGTs were used during the intrusion.
Reconstruct attacker activity across the domain using forged tickets, including resource access, privilege changes, and data exfiltration.

T1558_002.TITLE: Credential Access — Silver Ticket (Service Ticket Forgery)

IDENTIFICATION: Monitor Kerberos service ticket (TGS) usage for anomalies such as access to services without corresponding, legitimate TGT activity from the same client.
Detect authentication to service SPNs (e.g., MSSQL, HTTP, CIFS, SharePoint) from clients or accounts that do not normally use those services.
Flag service access using Kerberos tickets that appear to bypass normal interactive logon patterns or originate from suspicious or compromised hosts.
CONTAINMENT: Identify and isolate systems hosting services targeted by Silver Ticket activity, such as file servers, databases, or web applications.
Reset passwords for service accounts associated with compromised SPNs to invalidate forged tickets.
Increase monitoring on affected services for data access, configuration changes, or lateral movement behavior.
COUNTERMEASURES: Use strong, unique passwords or key material for service accounts and rotate them regularly.
Limit privileges of service accounts to the minimal set required and avoid using them for interactive logon.
Monitor for unusual SPN usage and service ticket requests, especially for high-value services and Tier-0 resources.
FORENSICS: Collect Kerberos TGS logs from domain controllers and access logs from targeted services.
Determine which service accounts, SPNs, and resources were involved in Silver Ticket activity.
Correlate forged service ticket usage with suspicious operations such as data exfiltration, privilege escalation, or service tampering.

T1558_003.TITLE: Credential Access — Kerberoasting (Service Ticket Hash Cracking)

IDENTIFICATION: Monitor domain controller logs for unusual volumes or patterns of TGS requests, especially for service accounts with SPNs that are not frequently used.
Detect tools or scripts on endpoints that request TGS tickets for many SPNs or export ticket hashes for offline cracking.
Flag accounts or hosts that suddenly begin requesting TGS tickets for high-privilege services or for a wide variety of services in a short timeframe.
CONTAINMENT: Identify which service accounts were targeted by Kerberoasting and treat their credentials as compromised.
Reset passwords for impacted service accounts, prioritizing those with elevated privileges or broad access.
Increase monitoring on hosts where Kerberoasting tools were executed, as they may be staging points for further lateral movement.
COUNTERMEASURES: Use long, complex passwords or managed service accounts for SPN-bearing accounts to resist offline cracking.
Limit privileges of service accounts and avoid assigning domain admin or highly privileged roles unnecessarily.
Deploy detections focused on abnormal TGS request patterns and service account ticket usage.
FORENSICS: Collect Kerberos TGS request logs, SPN mappings, and endpoint telemetry where Kerberoasting tools were likely executed.
Estimate cracking difficulty for exposed service account hashes and determine which accounts are most at risk.
Correlate Kerberoasting activity with subsequent successful authentications and service access using compromised accounts.

IDENTIFICATION: Monitor Kerberos AS-REP activity for accounts that do not require preauthentication, especially high-value or rarely used accounts.
Detect scripted or automated requests for AS-REP responses across many accounts from the same host or IP range.
Flag AS-REP traffic associated with accounts that previously did not exhibit no-preauth behavior or that are not expected to be accessed frequently.
CONTAINMENT: Identify accounts with the 'Do not require Kerberos preauthentication' flag enabled and evaluate them for compromise.
Reset passwords for accounts that were targeted by AS-REP roasting and remove unnecessary no-preauth configuration.
Isolate systems used to perform large-scale AS-REP requests or hash collection for offline cracking.
COUNTERMEASURES: Disable the 'Do not require Kerberos preauthentication' setting for all but strictly necessary and tightly controlled accounts.
Review and harden Active Directory account configurations regularly, focusing on legacy or service accounts.
Monitor for AS-REP request patterns aligned with known AS-REP roasting techniques and tools.
FORENSICS: Collect logs of AS-REP requests, including requesting hosts, targeted accounts, and timestamps.
Determine which accounts were likely roasted and assess whether cracking or misuse of those credentials has already occurred.
Correlate AS-REP roasting with subsequent authentication attempts, privilege escalations, or lateral movement.

T1558_005.TITLE: Credential Access — Kerberos Ccache Files (Ticket Theft from Disk)

IDENTIFICATION: Monitor access to Kerberos credential cache files (e.g., /tmp/krb5cc_*, KRB5CCNAME locations) by processes or users that do not normally manipulate tickets.
Detect copying, archiving, or exfiltration of ccache files from endpoints, jump hosts, or bastion systems.
Flag use of tools or commands that enumerate, extract, or re-use Kerberos ccache data outside of standard SSO flows.
CONTAINMENT: Terminate unauthorized processes accessing or exporting Kerberos ccache files.
Invalidate or expire tickets associated with exposed caches, forcing re-authentication with valid credentials.
Increase monitoring on systems and accounts whose caches were exposed, focusing on subsequent access patterns.
COUNTERMEASURES: Restrict access to Kerberos cache file locations and ensure proper file permissions for user ticket stores.
Encourage frequent re-authentication and minimal ticket lifetimes for high-value accounts.
Use hardened jump hosts and isolated admin workstations to limit where reusable Kerberos tickets are stored.
FORENSICS: Collect copies of suspected stolen ccache files and endpoint logs showing how they were accessed.
Determine which principals and services were represented in the stolen caches.
Correlate potential reuse of these tickets with unusual access to resources or lateral movement from new hosts.

T1550_003.TITLE: Defense Evasion / Lateral Movement — Pass the Ticket (Kerberos Ticket Reuse)

IDENTIFICATION: Monitor for Kerberos authentication events where valid tickets are used from atypical hosts, devices, or geographic locations compared to the ticket owner’s normal behavior.
Detect replay or reuse of the same ticket across multiple systems or services in a short timeframe, especially from different network segments.
Flag access to administrative or server systems where Kerberos authentication occurs without corresponding interactive logon or expected session establishment patterns.
CONTAINMENT: Invalidate or expire tickets suspected of being reused or replayed and force re-authentication with valid credentials.
Isolate systems believed to be used as launching points for Pass-the-Ticket activity, such as compromised admin workstations or jump hosts.
Reset credentials or rotate keys for accounts associated with stolen tickets, prioritizing high-privilege and service accounts.
COUNTERMEASURES: Implement strong workstation and credential hygiene so that high-value accounts and tickets are only used on hardened admin systems.
Deploy monitoring that correlates Kerberos ticket usage with device identity, IP, and expected user behavior.
Use short ticket lifetimes and enforce modern encryption types to reduce the value and usable lifespan of stolen tickets.
FORENSICS: Collect Kerberos authentication logs, including client IPs, device identifiers, and service access patterns associated with suspected ticket reuse.
Identify which tickets were likely stolen, where they were first used legitimately, and where they were later replayed.
Reconstruct attacker lateral movement paths using stolen tickets and correlate with initial credential dumping events and privilege escalations.

T1539.TITLE: Credential Access — Steal Web Session Cookie (Browser / Web Apps)

IDENTIFICATION: Monitor web proxy, WAF, and application logs for indicators of session cookie theft, such as suspicious JavaScript injection, unexpected cookie exfiltration parameters, or responses that expose Set-Cookie headers to untrusted origins.
Detect access to browser cookie storage artifacts on endpoints (e.g., browser Cookies SQLite DB, cookie.json, or secure storage APIs) by non-browser processes or untrusted tools.
Flag repeated access to high-value SaaS or internal web applications from new devices or IPs without corresponding credential-based logins, suggesting reuse of stolen session cookies.
CONTAINMENT: Invalidate or revoke active web sessions associated with suspected stolen cookies by forcing logout or rotating session identifiers on affected applications.
Temporarily require re-authentication and, where supported, MFA re-prompt for impacted accounts accessing sensitive web applications.
Block suspicious IPs, user agents, or ASNs associated with cookie theft or anomalous web session reuse.
COUNTERMEASURES: Enforce secure cookie attributes (Secure, HttpOnly, SameSite) and short session lifetimes for high-value applications.
Deploy browser and endpoint protections capable of detecting unauthorized access to cookie stores or browser memory.
Use risk-based access controls and device trust checks so that new devices or locations require fresh authentication, not just a cookie.
FORENSICS: Collect web server, WAF, and proxy logs related to targeted accounts and their session identifiers.
Review endpoint telemetry for tools or scripts that accessed browser cookie storage or injected malicious JavaScript into browser processes.
Correlate suspected cookie theft with later unauthorized actions within SaaS, internal portals, or admin interfaces.

T1550_001.TITLE: Credential Access — Application Access Token (OAuth / API Tokens)

IDENTIFICATION: Monitor identity provider and SaaS audit logs for abnormal token issuance patterns, such as a single client or IP obtaining many access tokens or refresh tokens for multiple accounts.
Detect use of access tokens from devices, IP ranges, or geolocations that do not match the original token issuance context or user behavior.
Flag API calls authenticated solely via bearer tokens that originate from unusual automation frameworks, scripts, or unfamiliar user agents.
CONTAINMENT: Revoke or invalidate compromised access tokens and refresh tokens at the identity provider or SaaS platform.
Force re-authentication with MFA for users whose tokens were misused or accessed from suspicious environments.
Temporarily restrict or disable sensitive API scopes and high-privilege application registrations pending investigation.
COUNTERMEASURES: Use least-privilege scopes for OAuth and API tokens, limiting each token to minimal required operations.
Implement continuous access evaluation and risk-based policies that can revoke tokens when device, network, or user risk changes.
Regularly audit app registrations, service principals, and long-lived tokens to ensure necessity and proper ownership.
FORENSICS: Collect logs from identity providers, SaaS platforms, and API gateways showing token issuance, refresh, and usage.
Identify which users, applications, and resources were accessed using the compromised tokens.
Correlate token abuse with data exfiltration, configuration changes, or lateral movement between SaaS tenants and services.

T1550_004.TITLE: Defense Evasion / Credential Access — Web Session Cookie (Reuse of Stolen Tokens)

IDENTIFICATION: Monitor authentication and access logs for sessions that appear without recent, valid credential-based login events but reuse existing cookies or tokens from new IPs or devices.
Detect simultaneous or rapidly sequential use of the same web session cookie or token from geographically distant locations or distinct device fingerprints.
Flag browser or endpoint activity where tools or scripts read browser session cookies or where browser processes are subjected to memory inspection or dumping for token extraction.
CONTAINMENT: Immediately revoke or rotate session cookies and tokens associated with suspected hijacked sessions.
Force global logout for impacted users on affected applications and require MFA-backed re-authentication.
Block or challenge suspicious IPs, device IDs, or browser fingerprints that reused stolen cookies or tokens.
COUNTERMEASURES: Deploy device and network-aware conditional access that binds sessions to trusted devices and contexts, making cookie reuse from new environments high-risk or blocked.
Implement short-lived session cookies combined with refresh mechanisms that require continuous risk evaluation.
Harden browsers and endpoints with protections against cookie theft, including EDR detections for browser memory scraping and cookie store access.
FORENSICS: Collect application, proxy, and identity logs for all activity tied to the compromised session IDs or tokens.
Reconstruct the timeline of when the cookie or token was likely stolen and from which host or browser.
Correlate session hijacking with any preceding phishing, adversary-in-the-middle, or malware activity on the victim’s device.

T1027.TITLE: Defense Evasion — Obfuscated Files or Information

IDENTIFICATION: Detect executables, scripts, or archives that are packed, encrypted, or heavily obfuscated compared to typical software in the environment.
Correlate detections of unusual packers, custom crypters, or high-entropy binaries with recent ingress events (email attachments, web downloads, remote transfers).
Identify processes that load or drop files which rapidly change hashes or that unpack in memory shortly before execution.
CONTAINMENT: Quarantine or block execution of highly obfuscated binaries or scripts that are not signed or previously approved.
Isolate affected endpoints from the network when repeated detections of packed or encrypted payloads occur.
Temporarily increase monitoring and application control policies for hosts that repeatedly handle obfuscated content.
COUNTERMEASURES: Deploy endpoint controls that inspect file entropy, packer signatures, and script characteristics to flag suspicious obfuscation.
Enforce allow-listing for executables and script hosts in sensitive segments to reduce execution of unknown packed binaries.
Integrate sandbox detonation for suspicious archives and executables prior to allowing broad distribution.
FORENSICS: Preserve original packed samples and any unpacked payloads recovered from memory for reverse engineering.
Document delivery paths, user interactions, and systems that processed the obfuscated payload.
Correlate obfuscation events with subsequent malicious behavior such as persistence creation, lateral movement, or data staging.

T1027.009.TITLE: Defense Evasion — Obfuscated Files or Information: Embedded Payloads

IDENTIFICATION: Detect scripts, documents, or binaries that contain embedded secondary payloads, shellcode, or encoded blobs that are decoded at runtime.
Monitor for processes that read benign-looking files (such as scripts or office documents) and then write or execute new binary content.
Flag unusual use of compression, encoding, or archive libraries immediately followed by code injection or process hollowing activity.
CONTAINMENT: Block or quarantine files that exhibit embedded payload extraction behavior not observed in known-good applications.
Terminate processes that decode or extract payloads and immediately attempt execution in unusual directories or memory-only regions.
Restrict outbound network connections from hosts executing newly extracted payloads until triage completes.
COUNTERMEASURES: Enable deep content inspection for documents and scripts from email or web channels to identify embedded payload structures.
Train detection rules on common embedded payload frameworks used by commodity malware and red-team tools.
Enforce macro, script, and plugin hardening in productivity and browser applications to limit arbitrary code execution from embedded content.
FORENSICS: Recover original carrier files and extracted payloads, capturing in-memory artifacts where possible.
Reconstruct the decode/decompression chain to understand how the embedded payload is triggered.
Map all endpoints and users that opened or executed the carrier file to gauge blast radius.

T1140.TITLE: Defense Evasion — Deobfuscate/Decode Files or Information

IDENTIFICATION: Monitor script interpreters and common admin tools for repeated use of decoding or decompression functions on suspicious input (Base64, gzip, custom encodings).
Detect sequences where encoded blobs are decoded and immediately executed, written to disk, or injected into other processes.
Flag rare or custom decoding utilities appearing on endpoints, especially when launched by non-admin users or service accounts.
CONTAINMENT: Terminate processes that perform deobfuscation or decoding followed by unapproved code execution.
Quarantine decoded artifacts and block further decoding attempts from the same source script or user.
Temporarily restrict scripting and remote administration capabilities on impacted hosts while investigation proceeds.
COUNTERMEASURES: Instrument command-line logging and script-block logging for interpreters such as PowerShell, Python, and bash to capture decoding behavior.
Deploy policies that restrict unapproved interpreters or scripting engines on high-value assets.
Use code-signing and script allow-lists for administrative automation to distinguish legitimate decoding from malicious behavior.
FORENSICS: Capture decoded payloads, original encoded content, and execution traces (command history, script files, logs).
Identify the origin of the encoded data (email attachment, web download, shared drive) to determine initial attack vector.
Correlate deobfuscation events with subsequent persistence, credential access, or lateral movement activity.

IDENTIFICATION: Detect changes to security-relevant services, agents, or kernel drivers that reduce or disable protective capabilities.
Monitor configuration changes to antivirus, EDR, firewall, and logging components that lower sensitivity, disable rules, or stop update mechanisms.
Correlate attempts to stop or uninstall defensive tools with concurrent suspicious process execution or privilege escalation.
CONTAINMENT: Restore baseline configurations and restart impaired defensive services on affected hosts.
Isolate systems where multiple defensive components were disabled or tampered with in a short time window.
Escalate incidents where impairment targets centralized security infrastructure or domain-wide policies.
COUNTERMEASURES: Harden security tool configurations to require administrative privileges and, where possible, additional approval to modify or disable protections.
Deploy tamper-protection features for antivirus and EDR agents to prevent unauthorized service stops and configuration changes.
Continuously monitor and alert on deviations from approved security baselines using configuration management tooling.
FORENSICS: Collect system and security configuration snapshots before and after impairment, including registry keys, policy files, and agent logs.
Identify the process, account, and remote origin responsible for changing defensive settings.
Correlate defense impairment timing with first evidence of malicious payload deployment or lateral movement.

T1562.001.TITLE: Defense Evasion — Disable or Modify Security Tools

IDENTIFICATION: Monitor process creation and service control events for attempts to stop, uninstall, or kill antivirus, EDR, or monitoring agents.
Detect registry or configuration changes that disable real-time scanning, quarantine, or alerting features in security tools.
Flag execution of known security tool management utilities or command-line switches being used by non-admin or unexpected accounts.
CONTAINMENT: Immediately restart or redeploy disabled security tools on affected endpoints.
Temporarily isolate hosts where security agents were forcibly stopped while investigation determines scope.
Revoke or reset compromised administrative credentials used to disable or modify security tools.
COUNTERMEASURES: Enable tamper protection, self-defense, and access controls for security tools to prevent unauthorized modifications.
Segment management interfaces and require MFA plus just-in-time access to administer defensive tooling.
Implement SIEM alerts for any stop, uninstall, or disable actions against security-related services or drivers.
FORENSICS: Collect service logs, Windows event logs, and tool-specific logs around the time of disablement.
Identify which accounts and remote IPs initiated tool modifications and what processes were running concurrently.
Correlate periods of tool downtime with other malicious activities that may have occurred without detection.

T1562.004.TITLE: Defense Evasion — Disable or Modify System Firewall

IDENTIFICATION: Detect commands or API calls that disable host-based firewall services or significantly alter firewall profiles.
