Monitor for sudden changes in local firewall rules that open high-risk ports, allow any-to-any traffic, or trust unapproved subnets.
Correlate firewall rule changes with newly established external connections or lateral movement between internal hosts.
CONTAINMENT: Reapply baseline firewall policies on endpoints where rules were modified or services disabled.
Block suspicious external IPs or subnets that began communicating immediately after firewall changes.
Isolate critical systems whose firewall protections were removed while further analysis is performed.
COUNTERMEASURES: Manage firewall policies centrally where possible and restrict local override capabilities.
Generate alerts on firewall disablement events and rule changes that deviate from approved configuration baselines.
Regularly audit host-based firewall configurations to ensure enforcement of least-privilege network access.
FORENSICS: Export firewall configuration before and after changes and preserve associated event logs.
Determine which account and process modified firewall settings, including remote management channels used.
Correlate firewall impairment with subsequent command-and-control, data exfiltration, or lateral movement traffic.

IDENTIFICATION: Detect malware or scripts that perform environmental checks (domain, username, IP range, language, virtualization) before executing primary payloads.
Monitor for binaries that exit early or remain dormant when run in analysis environments but fully execute on production hosts.
Identify code paths that only execute when specific external infrastructure, domain names, or encryption keys are reachable.
CONTAINMENT: Quarantine binaries or scripts that exhibit environment-aware behavior indicative of execution guardrails.
Instrument affected hosts for heightened monitoring, as code guarded in this way often supports targeted or high-value campaigns.
Block outbound connections to infrastructure used in guardrail checks where possible.
COUNTERMEASURES: Improve sandbox and detonation environments to better emulate production conditions and expose guarded payloads.
Leverage behavior-based detections focused on environment checks and anti-analysis routines.
Document known good software that performs similar checks to reduce false positives and focus on unknown binaries.
FORENSICS: Capture full binaries, configuration data, and logs showing environment checks and conditional execution paths.
Analyze which attributes (domain, user, location) the guardrails rely on to infer intended targets.
Correlate execution guardrail detections with targeted phishing, supply-chain compromises, or advanced intrusion activity.

IDENTIFICATION: Detect processes whose names, icons, or metadata mimic legitimate system binaries but execute from non-standard directories.
Monitor for signed binaries whose hashes or publishers do not match expected values for the claimed application.
Correlate unusual parent-child process relationships where a masquerading binary is launched by scripting engines or document readers.
CONTAINMENT: Suspend or terminate processes that appear to be system binaries running from user-writable or temporary directories.
Quarantine masquerading executables and block their hashes across the environment.
Restrict access for accounts that launched masquerading binaries until their activity is reviewed.
COUNTERMEASURES: Implement application control and allow-listing for core system processes and their expected locations.
Use file reputation and code-signing validation to identify binaries claiming trusted names but lacking legitimate signatures.
Continuously baseline typical process paths and names to detect deviations indicative of masquerading.
FORENSICS: Collect file samples, metadata (hashes, timestamps, digital signatures), and process lineage for masquerading binaries.
Identify how the masquerading executable was delivered and persisted on the system.
Correlate masquerading activity with credential theft, persistence creation, or data access on affected hosts.

T1036.005.TITLE: Defense Evasion — Match Legitimate Name or Location

IDENTIFICATION: Monitor for binaries using names of known system processes but executing from directories not associated with the legitimate files.
Detect duplicate executable names present in multiple locations where only one instance is expected in a standard build.
Identify scheduled tasks, services, or startup entries that reference executables with legitimate names in suspicious paths.
CONTAINMENT: Disable or remove malicious services, tasks, and startup items referencing masquerading binaries.
Quarantine non-standard copies of system process names and block execution based on path and hash.
Compare affected hosts against a gold image or baseline to determine which copies are legitimate.
COUNTERMEASURES: Enforce file integrity monitoring on directories containing legitimate system binaries.
Document and monitor expected filesystem locations for critical executables, raising alerts on deviations.
Restrict write access to system binary directories to administrative processes and trusted update mechanisms.
FORENSICS: Capture both legitimate and malicious copies of similarly named executables for comparison.
Trace creation times and installer logs to determine when and how masquerading binaries appeared.
Correlate masquerading by name/location with user reports, performance issues, or other security alerts on the host.

IDENTIFICATION: Detect binaries or drivers that are signed with unexpected or compromised certificates, especially those recently revoked or associated with malware campaigns.
Monitor changes to trusted root certificate stores, code-signing policies, and application control rules that expand what is considered trusted.
Identify attempts to side-load malicious libraries or components through legitimate signed applications.
CONTAINMENT: Block or quarantine executables and drivers using untrusted or suspicious code-signing certificates.
Remove unauthorized root certificates and restore trusted certificate stores from a known-good baseline.
Temporarily restrict execution of newly signed binaries pending additional validation in high-value environments.
COUNTERMEASURES: Integrate certificate reputation and revocation checking into endpoint and gateway security controls.
Apply strict application control policies that consider both signature and known-good publisher context.
Continuously audit trust stores and signing policies for unauthorized additions or relaxations of controls.
FORENSICS: Preserve suspicious signed binaries, associated certificates, and event logs reflecting trust store changes.
Determine whether the signing certificate is stolen, abused, or incorrectly trusted and scope its use across the environment.
Correlate trust subversion with follow-on activities such as driver loading, persistence creation, or credential access.

IDENTIFICATION: Monitor registry modifications to keys controlling security tools, audit policies, logging, and execution controls.
Detect writes to autorun, service, and shell extension keys by non-standard processes or user accounts.
Correlate registry changes with subsequent behavior such as disabled protections, new persistence points, or altered file associations.
CONTAINMENT: Revert unauthorized registry changes using configuration management or backup baselines.
Isolate endpoints where registry modifications directly impact security posture or enable stealthy execution.
Revoke access tokens or credentials used to perform malicious registry edits.
COUNTERMEASURES: Harden critical registry paths with access control lists limiting modifications to trusted administrative processes.
Enable granular logging of registry changes relevant to security, startup, and execution control.
Leverage application and device control solutions that validate configuration integrity against approved baselines.
FORENSICS: Export affected registry hives and relevant Windows event logs around the time of modification.
Analyze which process, script, or tool performed the changes and whether they were remotely triggered.
Correlate registry tampering with other techniques such as persistence, credential theft, or defense impairment.

T1070.TITLE: Defense Evasion — Indicator Removal on Host

IDENTIFICATION: Detect deletion or modification of logs, history files, and security artifacts associated with recent activity on a host.
Monitor for tools and commands commonly used to wipe traces, such as log clearing utilities, secure delete tools, and artifact cleaners.
Correlate sudden reductions in log volume or gaps in expected telemetry with other suspicious host-level behavior.
CONTAINMENT: Increase monitoring on systems where indicators were removed, as active intrusion is likely ongoing or recently completed.
Preserve remaining forensic artifacts immediately to prevent further loss of evidence.
Consider isolating hosts where critical audit trails were deliberately erased, especially in high-value segments.
COUNTERMEASURES: Forward logs to remote, write-once, or hardened collectors so local deletion does not fully erase evidence.
Deploy file integrity monitoring on key log and history locations.
Alert on use of log and artifact cleaning utilities outside of approved maintenance windows or administrators.
FORENSICS: Attempt recovery of deleted artifacts from backups, shadow copies, or central logging infrastructure.
Reconstruct timelines using remaining telemetry sources such as network captures, EDR traces, and backup metadata.
Correlate indicator removal with the attacker’s likely objectives and subsequent actions inside the environment.

IDENTIFICATION: Monitor for bulk deletion of tools, scripts, or temporary files in directories commonly used during attacks (temp, downloads, staging folders).
Detect use of secure delete utilities or unusual command-line flags for file removal executed by non-maintenance accounts.
Correlate file deletions with just-completed suspicious processes, privilege escalation, or data collection activities.
CONTAINMENT: Snapshot affected systems and preserve remaining file system metadata before additional cleanup occurs.
Increase monitoring for re-creation of similar tooling or repeated staging behavior on the same host.
Consider isolating endpoints where attackers performed deliberate cleanup after high-risk actions.
COUNTERMEASURES: Enable auditing on sensitive directories and tooling locations to capture file create/delete operations.
Restrict the use of secure deletion utilities to authorized administrators and scheduled tasks.
Utilize backups and versioning for critical directories to mitigate the impact of malicious deletions.
FORENSICS: Recover deleted files from backups, shadow copies, or forensic carving where feasible.
Analyze remaining artifacts (shortcuts, prefetch, registry traces) to infer what was deleted and how it was used.
Correlate deletion events with attacker dwell time, key objective completion, and exfiltration activity.

IDENTIFICATION: Detect anomalous file timestamp patterns such as creation times significantly in the past or closely matching system installation dates.
Monitor for tools and APIs known to manipulate file metadata being used by non-administrative or unusual processes.
Correlate timestamp changes on binaries, scripts, and logs with other suspicious behaviors on the same host.
CONTAINMENT: Preserve current file system metadata and copies of affected files for later analysis.
Treat hosts with evidence of timestomping as high-risk for deeper compromise and expand monitoring scope.
Restrict write and metadata modification access on critical directories implicated in timestomping activity.
COUNTERMEASURES: Leverage file integrity monitoring solutions that compare hashes and metadata against known-good baselines.
Harden permissions on system directories to limit who can alter file attributes and timestamps.
Incorporate timestamp anomaly checks into DFIR and SIEM analytics to highlight potential tampering early.
FORENSICS: Use alternative timeline sources (prefetch, registry, USN journal, EDR telemetry) to reconstruct true activity ordering.
Identify which artifacts were timestomped and whether they relate to tools, payloads, or logs.
Correlate timestomping operations with other tradecraft indicative of stealthy, long-term intrusions.

IDENTIFICATION: Detect repetitive bulk file access, recursive directory reads, or scripted enumeration.
Correlate automated scripts that gather large volumes of files within short time intervals.
CONTAINMENT: Suspend suspicious automated processes or scripted collectors.
Restrict staging directories and apply least-privilege access controls.
COUNTERMEASURES: Require execution of signed automation scripts.
Enable monitoring for rapid directory traversal patterns.
FORENSICS: Extract execution traces for scripts and automated binaries.
Capture directory access logs for targeted file paths.

IDENTIFICATION: Detect creation of compressed archives in atypical directories.
Correlate archival utilities (zip, rar, 7z) following bulk file access.
CONTAINMENT: Quarantine staging directories containing sensitive archive files.
Disable outbound transfer attempts of compressed payloads.
COUNTERMEASURES: Disable high-risk archiving tools on sensitive hosts.
Apply DLP controls to detect archives with sensitive data.
FORENSICS: Examine archive metadata for file lists.
Correlate archive creation timestamps with prior data collection events.

IDENTIFICATION: Detect bulk data copied into a single staging directory.
Identify sensitive environment files consolidated prior to exfiltration.
CONTAINMENT: Lock down staging directories and isolate filesystem activity.
Terminate active processes interacting with staged data.
COUNTERMEASURES: Implement DLP rules targeting staging file naming patterns.
Deploy monitoring for hidden directories and temp archive paths.
FORENSICS: Catalog all files present in staging directories.
Correlate timestamps to identify origin of source files.

IDENTIFICATION: Detect unauthorized access to locally stored credentials, configs, and sensitive documents.
Correlate processes with high read I/O on sensitive directories.
CONTAINMENT: Restrict host-level access to sensitive directories.
Suspend processes performing bulk reads without prior authorization.
COUNTERMEASURES: Encrypt sensitive local data and require MFA for access.
Remove unneeded files containing sensitive content.
FORENSICS: Analyze targeted directories for accessed files.
Preserve forensic timeline of read operations.

T1039.TITLE: Collection — Data from Network Shared Drive

IDENTIFICATION: Detect large download or copy operations from shared drives.
Correlate unauthorized hosts accessing multiple shares rapidly.
CONTAINMENT: Disable host access to shares involved in bulk reads.
Limit SMB/Share permissions dynamically during incidents.
COUNTERMEASURES: Segment sensitive file shares by role.
Enable logging for SMB read operations and access anomalies.
FORENSICS: Extract access control logs for targeted shares.
Trace user/device responsible for staged network data.

IDENTIFICATION: Detect file access patterns when removable media is mounted.
Correlate processes repeatedly reading large volumes from external drives.
CONTAINMENT: Block removable media mounting on sensitive hosts.
Quarantine devices auto-executing file transfer utilities.
COUNTERMEASURES: Disable external device access on critical systems.
Enable DLP alerts for removable media operations.
FORENSICS: Acquire forensic images of removable media involved.
Trace process identifiers that accessed USB volumes.

IDENTIFICATION: Detect browser process injections or malicious extensions.
Correlate unauthorized credential harvesting from HTTP POST requests.
CONTAINMENT: Terminate compromised browser sessions.
Disable extensions installed without cryptographic signatures.
COUNTERMEASURES: Enforce signed browser extension policies.
Monitor for injection APIs used to intercept browser traffic.
FORENSICS: Extract browser extension manifest and permission data.
Analyze captured HTTP payloads for credential theft patterns.

IDENTIFICATION: Detect bulk mailbox exports or unauthorized IMAP downloads.
Correlate scripts using API tokens to query email accounts.
CONTAINMENT: Lock compromised email accounts and revoke sessions.
Disable mailbox export permissions.
COUNTERMEASURES: Require MFA for admin API access.
Restrict programmatic mailbox access to approved apps.
FORENSICS: Acquire export logs and message audit trails.
Trace OAuth token usage and originating hosts.

IDENTIFICATION: Detect microphone activation outside authorized apps.
Correlate processes invoking audio APIs at abnormal times.
CONTAINMENT: Disable microphone hardware access.
Suspend processes capturing audio in stealth mode.
COUNTERMEASURES: Enforce hardware device permissions at OS layer.
Alert on long-duration audio capture sessions.
FORENSICS: Extract captured audio files for metadata review.
Trace process handles opened against audio interfaces.

IDENTIFICATION: Detect processes logging keystrokes or intercepting window focus events.
Correlate hooks placed in keyboard input APIs or raw HID streams.
CONTAINMENT: Suspend processes attaching input hooks.
Reset session tokens and device peripherals.
COUNTERMEASURES: Restrict access to input device APIs.
Deploy endpoint anti-keylogging defenses.
FORENSICS: Capture memory dumps to identify input hook addresses.
Extract suspicious keystroke log files.

IDENTIFICATION: Detect sensitive data aggregated into local directories.
Correlate bulk copy operations from diverse sources.
CONTAINMENT: Restrict staging directory permissions.
Suspend processes preparing data for transfer.
COUNTERMEASURES: Implement DLP scanning on temp directories.
Enforce encryption policies for bulk local storage.
FORENSICS: Enumerate staged files and extract metadata.
Trace source origin for each staged artifact.

IDENTIFICATION: Detect local client mailbox exports (PST, OST, MBOX).
Correlate processes accessing on-disk email stores.
CONTAINMENT: Lock access to local email database files.
Disable auto-sync operations if tampering detected.
COUNTERMEASURES: Encrypt local email storage.
Restrict access to email client data directories.
FORENSICS: Analyze exported mailbox files for sensitive content.
Trace processes interacting with local email caches.

IDENTIFICATION: Detect repetitive bulk file access, recursive directory reads, or scripted enumeration across local or networked paths.
Correlate automated scripts or tools that gather large volumes of files within short time intervals from multiple directories.
CONTAINMENT: Suspend or isolate suspicious automated processes performing large-scale file access.
Restrict staging directories and apply least-privilege access controls for data-heavy paths.
COUNTERMEASURES: Require execution of signed or approved automation scripts on critical systems.
Enable monitoring for rapid directory traversal and bulk-read patterns on sensitive data locations.
FORENSICS: Extract execution traces for scripts and binaries performing automated collection.
Capture directory access logs and audit events for targeted file paths to reconstruct the scope of collection.

IDENTIFICATION: Detect creation of compressed archives (e.g., .zip, .rar, .7z) in atypical directories or with unusually large sizes.
Correlate use of archiving utilities shortly after bulk access to sensitive files or directories.
CONTAINMENT: Quarantine directories containing suspicious archives with sensitive content.
Block or closely monitor outbound transfer attempts of newly created archive files.
COUNTERMEASURES: Disable or restrict high-risk archiving tools on sensitive hosts where not required.
Apply DLP controls tuned to detect archives containing regulated or business-critical data.
FORENSICS: Examine archive metadata and file listings to determine what was staged for potential exfiltration.
Correlate archive creation timestamps with prior file access and login activity on the system.

IDENTIFICATION: Detect bulk data copied or moved into dedicated staging directories, especially in temp or user-writable locations.
Identify creation of new folders that rapidly accumulate sensitive files from multiple disparate locations.
CONTAINMENT: Lock down identified staging directories and restrict further access.
Terminate processes actively interacting with staged data when behavior is unauthorized.
COUNTERMEASURES: Implement DLP scanning focused on common staging paths and patterns used before exfiltration.
Limit users' ability to create arbitrary share-like or temp locations on critical hosts.
FORENSICS: Catalog all files found in staging locations and map them back to original sources.
Correlate staging events with later outbound network transfers or use of archiving utilities.

IDENTIFICATION: Detect unauthorized or unusual access to locally stored credentials, configuration files, and sensitive documents.
Correlate processes showing high read I/O across user profile folders, desktop, documents, and custom sensitive directories.
CONTAINMENT: Restrict host-level access to identified sensitive directories when suspicious collection is occurring.
Suspend or isolate processes performing broad local data reads without clear justification.
COUNTERMEASURES: Encrypt sensitive local data and require strong authentication for decryption operations.
Reduce unnecessary local storage of sensitive information by enforcing centralization and cleanup policies.
FORENSICS: Analyze file access logs and telemetry to determine which local files were accessed or copied.
Preserve timeline data for read operations to correlate with user activity and remote connections.

T1039.TITLE: Collection — Data from Network Shared Drive

IDENTIFICATION: Detect large, sustained read or copy operations from network file shares, especially from unusual hosts or accounts.
Identify access to multiple new shares or deep directory structures in a short period by a single user or system.
CONTAINMENT: Temporarily disable or restrict access to shares involved in suspicious bulk-read activity.
Throttle or block SMB/DFS access from compromised endpoints while incident triage is performed.
COUNTERMEASURES: Segment sensitive file shares and enforce strict role-based access and least-privilege permissions.
Enable detailed logging for SMB access and read operations on high-value shares.
FORENSICS: Extract file access and share logs to identify which data was read or copied.
Trace the user and device principal used for the activity and correlate with authentication logs.

IDENTIFICATION: Detect file access and copy operations that occur shortly after removable media is mounted.
Correlate processes that scan entire external volumes or copy large sets of files from removable drives.
CONTAINMENT: Block or unmount removable media involved in suspicious collection activity.
Quarantine hosts that repeatedly perform unauthorized reads from external storage devices.
COUNTERMEASURES: Disable or limit removable media usage on critical systems and sensitive segments.
Enable DLP and logging for file operations involving external storage.
FORENSICS: Acquire forensic images of removable media where feasible.
Trace which processes and accounts interacted with the mounted device and what was accessed.

IDENTIFICATION: Detect browser process injections, malicious browser extensions, or modules that hook HTTP/HTTPS traffic.
Correlate suspicious modifications to web forms, injected scripts, or altered transaction data within browser sessions.
CONTAINMENT: Terminate compromised browser sessions and remove malicious extensions or injected components.
Isolate endpoints exhibiting evidence of in-browser credential or transaction tampering.
COUNTERMEASURES: Enforce policies to only allow signed and vetted browser extensions.
Deploy endpoint controls that detect injection into browser processes and prevent unauthorized code from running.
FORENSICS: Extract browser configuration, extension lists, and injected script artifacts for analysis.
Review captured HTTP payloads and transaction logs to identify manipulated or stolen data.

IDENTIFICATION: Detect bulk mailbox exports, mass message downloads, or large IMAP/POP synchronization from unusual hosts.
Correlate scripted or API-based access to email accounts that retrieve large volumes of messages or attachments.
CONTAINMENT: Lock or temporarily disable email accounts involved in suspicious collection activity.
Revoke active sessions, OAuth tokens, and app passwords used to access targeted mailboxes.
COUNTERMEASURES: Require MFA for administrative and API-based access to mail systems.
Restrict mailbox export permissions to tightly controlled administrators or service accounts.
FORENSICS: Acquire export logs, message trace data, and audit trails for impacted mailboxes.
Determine which messages, attachments, and folders were accessed or exported by the attacker.

IDENTIFICATION: Detect microphone activation or audio input usage outside of approved communication or conferencing applications.
Correlate processes that open audio capture devices for extended periods without user interaction.
CONTAINMENT: Disable microphone access for suspicious processes or globally on compromised endpoints.
Suspend processes responsible for unauthorized or stealthy audio recording.
COUNTERMEASURES: Enforce OS-level permissions for audio devices and require explicit user consent for recording.
Alert on long-duration audio capture sessions initiated by non-communication applications.
FORENSICS: Collect any audio files or streams captured during the suspected activity for metadata analysis.
Trace process handles and API calls used to access microphone devices.

IDENTIFICATION: Detect processes that install keyboard hooks, intercept input events, or access low-level input APIs in an unusual manner.
Correlate the presence of keylogging binaries, scripts, or libraries with suspicious persistence mechanisms.
CONTAINMENT: Suspend or terminate processes attaching to keyboard or input devices without a legitimate need.
Reset active credentials, tokens, and sessions used on compromised endpoints.
COUNTERMEASURES: Restrict access to raw input device APIs and require elevated privileges for such operations.
Deploy endpoint anti-keylogging protections and integrity checks around input-handling components.
FORENSICS: Capture memory snapshots to identify installed hooks, injected modules, or logging buffers.
Extract and analyze any discovered keystroke log files to determine what was captured.

IDENTIFICATION: Detect aggregation of sensitive files into local temp or user-created staging directories.
Correlate copy operations from multiple source locations into a single local folder over a short time period.
CONTAINMENT: Restrict access to or lock local staging locations that contain collected data.
Stop processes responsible for large-scale staging when collection is unauthorized.
COUNTERMEASURES: Implement DLP or content inspection on local temp and staging directories for sensitive data patterns.
Limit users' ability to write large volumes of data into unmonitored local folders.
FORENSICS: Enumerate all files staged locally and determine their original locations.
Correlate staging timelines with user logins, privilege escalations, and network activity.

IDENTIFICATION: Detect creation or access of local mailbox export files such as PST, OST, MBOX, or similar formats.
Correlate processes that open or copy on-disk email client databases outside of normal client usage.
CONTAINMENT: Lock access to local email database and export files during an active investigation.
Disable sync or export features of email clients on affected hosts until activity is understood.
COUNTERMEASURES: Encrypt local email storage and enforce OS-level access controls to client data directories.
Restrict export capabilities in email clients to a small set of administrators.
FORENSICS: Analyze exported mailbox files to identify the volume and type of email content collected.
Trace which processes and accounts interacted with local email caches and export functions.

IDENTIFICATION: Detect processes invoking screen capture APIs or repeatedly taking screenshots without user interaction.
Correlate creation of image files or screen recordings in unusual paths or at regular intervals indicative of automation.
CONTAINMENT: Terminate processes performing unauthorized screen capture.
Restrict or disable screen capture capabilities on high-sensitivity endpoints where feasible.
COUNTERMEASURES: Monitor for common screen capture tool signatures and API usage on endpoints.
Harden remote access and monitoring solutions so only approved tools can capture display content.
FORENSICS: Collect any saved screenshot or recording files for timing and content analysis.
Review process and user context at the time of screen capture to determine attacker objectives.

IDENTIFICATION: Detect processes that poll clipboard contents frequently or register global clipboard listeners.
Correlate clipboard monitoring with other credential theft or data collection activity on the same host.
CONTAINMENT: Suspend applications or scripts that continuously read clipboard data without a legitimate purpose.
Clear clipboard contents when compromise is suspected and reset any sensitive data that may have been copied.
COUNTERMEASURES: Restrict access to clipboard APIs for background processes and untrusted applications.
Educate users to avoid copying highly sensitive secrets (passwords, long-term tokens) into the clipboard on shared or unmanaged devices.
FORENSICS: Review process telemetry and API call traces related to clipboard access.
Correlate clipboard capture with subsequent use of copied secrets in remote logins or application access.

IDENTIFICATION: Detect commands or scripts enumerating OS version, system configs, hardware, or installed roles.
Correlate tools like 'systeminfo', 'wmic os', 'uname', or PowerShell system interrogation during suspicious activity.
CONTAINMENT: Throttle or block repeated system profile queries from unauthorized processes.
Isolate endpoint if system profiling occurs alongside credential or network scanning.
COUNTERMEASURES: Restrict access to system interrogation utilities and APIs on sensitive hosts.
Require signed binaries or admin privileges to query detailed system metadata.
FORENSICS: Capture executed commands referencing system enumeration.
Analyze logs to determine whether profiling preceded privilege escalation or lateral movement.

IDENTIFICATION: Detect repeated connections across high port ranges or multiple hosts in rapid succession.
Correlate scanning signatures from tools such as Nmap, Masscan, or custom scripts.
CONTAINMENT: Rate-limit scanning traffic from offending host.
Quarantine endpoint performing unauthorized reconnaissance.
COUNTERMEASURES: Restrict internal network discovery via segmentation.
Deploy honeypot services to detect active scanning early.
FORENSICS: Review packet capture to identify scan pattern, timing, and tool used.
Trace scanning origin to compromised credentials or remote sessions.

IDENTIFICATION: Identify enumeration of remote hosts via NetBIOS, LDAP, PowerShell remoting, or SMB lookups.
Detect scripts listing domain machines, clusters, or reachable nodes.
CONTAINMENT: Restrict node enumeration to privileged monitoring services.
Block the querying host from directory or network resolution sources.
COUNTERMEASURES: Segment broadcast and enumeration protocols.
Require authentication tokens for domain host queries.
FORENSICS: Review mapped machines and correlate with access attempts.
Analyze discovery timeline before lateral movement occurred.

IDENTIFICATION: Detect enumeration of user or group permissions via LDAP, net group, Azure AD Graph, or PowerShell modules.
Correlate permission discovery with credential harvesting activity.
CONTAINMENT: Throttle access to AD metadata from suspicious accounts.
Limit visibility of privileged groups to authorized roles.
COUNTERMEASURES: Apply Just-Enough-Administration (JEA) for domain queries.
Disable anonymous or public directory enumeration.
FORENSICS: Extract AD query logs and determine which groups were targeted.
Correlate queries with account misuse or privilege escalation.

IDENTIFICATION: Detect enumeration of SMB shares, mount points, or DFS paths.
Correlate repeated unauthenticated or low-privilege probes.
CONTAINMENT: Limit share visibility to authenticated and role-based systems.
Suspend sessions performing mass directory listing.
COUNTERMEASURES: Apply network share segmentation and least-privilege access.
Enable detailed access logs for sensitive file shares.
FORENSICS: Review logs to identify which shares were enumerated.
Trace follow-up attempts to access protected share paths.

IDENTIFICATION: Detect execution of directory queries referencing password policies, lockout thresholds, and expiration settings.
Correlate queries with brute force or credential harvesting behaviors.
CONTAINMENT: Terminate sessions performing targeted policy enumeration prior to credential attacks.
Restrict AD policy query permissions.
COUNTERMEASURES: Apply policy redaction for non-admin queries.
Enable anomaly alerts when password policy data is retrieved.
FORENSICS: Review AD query logs for targeted policy enumeration.
Correlate with authentication abuse attempts.

IDENTIFICATION: Detect tools enumerating domain trust relationships (e.g., 'nltest', LDAP trust queries, BloodHound).
Identify cross-domain mapping prior to lateral movement.
CONTAINMENT: Throttle or block trust enumeration from untrusted hosts.
Restrict directory discovery to domain-admin-approved tooling.
COUNTERMEASURES: Reduce trust exposure and require authenticated queries.
Limit open forest trust topologies.
FORENSICS: Extract trust map of domains targeted by attacker.
Correlate enumeration with credential relay attempts.

IDENTIFICATION: Detect enumeration of installed software via package managers, registry calls, dpkg queries, or MSI queries.
Correlate enumeration with exploitation of known vulnerable applications.
CONTAINMENT: Restrict access to software inventory on high-sensitivity assets.
Block unauthorized hosts from querying package lists at scale.
COUNTERMEASURES: Deploy application allow-listing to reduce enumeration value.
Limit remote enumeration APIs to privileged audit services.
FORENSICS: Analyze software lists targeted prior to exploitation attempts.
Match discovered apps against exploit payloads used.

IDENTIFICATION: Detect enumeration of running services via 'sc query', 'systemctl', 'Get-Service', or registry inspection.
Identify repeated service listing associated with privilege escalation mapping.
CONTAINMENT: Restrict access to service status queries when unnecessary.
Block suspicious host from further service interaction.
COUNTERMEASURES: Limit visibility of privileged services to admin roles.
Harden service permissions to prevent tampering post-discovery.
FORENSICS: Review service lists accessed during enumeration phase.
Correlate with later persistence or privilege escalation activity.

IDENTIFICATION: Detect queries that enumerate users, admin groups, or service accounts via LDAP, SAM, wmic, or PowerShell.
Flag sequences where account discovery occurs immediately before privilege escalation or brute force.
CONTAINMENT: Temporarily block enumeration for suspicious principals.
Force re-authentication and revoke cached Kerberos tickets.
COUNTERMEASURES: Limit user enumeration permissions and restrict AD attributes exposed.
Enable identity-based anomaly detection for account queries.
FORENSICS: Trace which accounts were enumerated and correlate with later credential theft.
Review domain logs to determine discovery path and origin host.

IDENTIFICATION: Detect use of uncommon or custom encodings, padding, or packet structures in outbound traffic that deviate from normal application patterns.
Correlate encrypted or obfuscated traffic over protocols or destinations that are not associated with business-approved applications.
Identify repeated small payloads, beacons, or structured blobs in HTTP(S), DNS, or other channels that do not match legitimate application signatures.
CONTAINMENT: Temporarily block outbound connections to destinations exhibiting suspicious obfuscated traffic patterns.
Quarantine endpoints that generate consistently obfuscated or encoded payloads to untrusted hosts.
Apply deep inspection or sinkholing where feasible to observe attacker response behavior without impacting production services.
COUNTERMEASURES: Baseline typical encoding and encryption behaviors for critical applications and alert on deviations.
Limit outbound connectivity from user and server segments to only required protocols and destinations.
Deploy advanced inspection at egress points capable of detecting protocol misuse and covert channels.
FORENSICS: Capture full packet data for suspicious flows and attempt decoding or protocol reconstruction.
Identify which processes and users on the originating host generated the obfuscated traffic.
Correlate obfuscation events with prior intrusion steps such as malware execution, credential theft, or lateral movement.

IDENTIFICATION: Detect suspicious C2-like patterns over common protocols such as HTTP(S), DNS, SMTP, or WebSockets, including periodic beacons and low-volume command responses.
Correlate connections to rare domains, IPs, or URLs with user agents, headers, or TLS fingerprints that do not match known applications.
Identify traffic masquerading as legitimate services (e.g., fake API calls, malformed requests) while communicating with unknown infrastructure.
CONTAINMENT: Block outbound connections to identified malicious C2 domains, IPs, or URL paths at the proxy or firewall.
Isolate endpoints exhibiting repeated beaconing or suspicious application-layer communication to untrusted infrastructure.
Terminate VPN or remote access sessions being used as C2 channels if confirmed malicious.
COUNTERMEASURES: Enforce explicit proxy usage, TLS inspection (where allowed), and egress filtering to limit direct outbound access.
Maintain allow-lists for critical SaaS and API endpoints, alerting on traffic outside of approved destinations.
Use behavioral analytics to distinguish normal application traffic from low-and-slow C2 communication.
FORENSICS: Collect HTTP(S), DNS, or protocol logs associated with suspected C2 sessions for timeline reconstruction.
Identify commands, tasks, or data transferred within application-layer C2 where possible.
Correlate C2 activity with observed attacker actions on endpoints, including persistence, discovery, and exfiltration.

IDENTIFICATION: Detect hosts acting as unexpected intermediaries relaying traffic between internal and external systems, including port-forwarding or tunneling behavior.
Identify long-lived connections or pivot channels (SOCKS, SSH tunneling, VPN daemons) from endpoints not designated as gateways or bastions.
Correlate traffic patterns consistent with pivoting tools or frameworks used for lateral movement and external C2.
CONTAINMENT: Block or terminate unauthorized proxy, tunneling, or port-forwarding sessions at firewalls and hosts.
Isolate systems identified as malicious proxies or pivot points for further investigation.
Revoke any credentials used to configure or authenticate unauthorized proxy channels.
COUNTERMEASURES: Restrict which systems can operate as proxies, VPN concentrators, or bastion hosts and enforce strict controls on them.
Monitor for common proxy and tunneling tool signatures and unusual listening ports.
Segment networks so that compromised endpoints cannot act as effective pivot proxies between sensitive zones.
FORENSICS: Collect logs of proxied connections, including source/destination pairs and session durations.
Determine whether internal assets were exposed through the malicious proxy to external infrastructure.
Correlate proxy use with attacker campaigns, tools, and associated infrastructure for threat intelligence updates.

T1092.TITLE: Command & Control — Communication via Removable Media

IDENTIFICATION: Detect periodic creation, modification, or polling of special command files or markers on removable media.
Correlate patterns where multiple hosts read and write to the same removable drive in a command/response pattern.
Identify malware that drops tasking files or exfiltrated data onto removable drives instead of using a network channel.
CONTAINMENT: Block or restrict use of removable media on compromised or high-risk endpoints.
Quarantine removable devices suspected of being used as an offline C2 channel.
Disable auto-mount or auto-execution behavior related to removable media on sensitive systems.
COUNTERMEASURES: Implement policies limiting or prohibiting the use of USB and other removable devices in secure environments.
Deploy endpoint monitoring for unusual read/write patterns to removable media.
Use encryption and access control for any sanctioned removable media to reduce the value of this channel.
FORENSICS: Capture full images of removable media suspected of use in C2 or data transfer.
Analyze timestamps and file sequences to reconstruct command and response flows between systems.
Correlate removable-media-based C2 activity with physical access logs and user presence.

IDENTIFICATION: Detect C2 traffic using raw TCP/UDP or uncommon protocols not typically used in the environment (e.g., ICMP for data exchange).
Identify unusual patterns such as fixed-size packets, periodic beacons, or data in protocol fields not normally used for payloads.
Correlate host processes opening persistent connections on ports that do not belong to known services.
CONTAINMENT: Block suspicious non-application layer traffic at perimeter and internal firewalls.
Isolate hosts engaging in anomalous low-level protocol communication to untrusted IPs.
Apply rate limits or drop rules on specific protocol types known to be abused for covert channels.
COUNTERMEASURES: Limit outbound connectivity to only required ports and protocols from each network segment.
Deploy anomaly detection on ICMP, raw TCP/UDP, and other low-level protocols rarely used legitimately.
Document and baseline legitimate non-application layer uses (e.g., monitoring tools) to reduce false positives.
FORENSICS: Collect packet captures for suspected non-application layer C2 channels for deeper protocol analysis.
Identify processes bound to suspicious sockets and their execution histories.
Correlate protocol misuse with earlier stages of the intrusion such as malware deployment or privilege escalation.

IDENTIFICATION: Detect repeated use of base64, custom encodings, or nested encoding layers in outbound requests or responses.
Identify encoded data embedded into otherwise normal-looking protocol fields such as HTTP parameters, headers, or DNS labels.
Correlate encoding behavior on hosts that recently executed suspicious binaries or scripts.
CONTAINMENT: Block or challenge outbound requests carrying highly encoded payloads to untrusted destinations.
Quarantine endpoints generating unusual encoded blobs over C2-suspect channels.
Increase scrutiny and logging of flows identified as using encoded data for potential attacker command or exfiltration.
COUNTERMEASURES: Monitor for excessive or unusual use of encoding libraries and utilities on endpoints tied to outbound network activity.
Enable detection signatures for common malware encoding schemes at network security layers.
Limit unmonitored egress paths to a small number of inspected proxies or gateways.
FORENSICS: Extract encoded data from captured traffic and attempt decoding to reveal underlying commands or data.
Trace encoding operations back to specific processes and scripts on compromised hosts.
Correlate data encoding events with exfiltration attempts and attacker tasking patterns.

IDENTIFICATION: Detect installation or execution of known remote access tools (RATs), remote admin software, or unauthorized remote desktop utilities.
Monitor for new listening services, startup entries, or scheduled tasks that establish persistent remote control channels.
Correlate unusual inbound or outbound sessions with processes not associated with approved remote administration solutions.
CONTAINMENT: Terminate RAT processes and disable associated services, startup items, or scheduled tasks.
Block remote access from attacker-controlled IPs and domains at network boundaries.
Isolate compromised systems from the rest of the environment until reimaging or full remediation is performed.
COUNTERMEASURES: Maintain an allow-list of approved remote administration tools and block all others at the endpoint and network level.
Require strong authentication and logging for all remote access into production systems.
Monitor software inventories and process lists for unsanctioned remote-access applications.
FORENSICS: Collect copies of RAT binaries, configuration files, and related artifacts for analysis.
Reconstruct the timeline of remote access sessions, including commands executed and data accessed.
Correlate RAT activity with initial infection vectors and any persistence or lateral movement established.

IDENTIFICATION: Detect frequent DNS queries for domains associated with dynamic DNS (DDNS) providers or rapidly changing IP addresses.
Identify patterns where an endpoint resolves multiple changing C2 domains over short periods, especially with low TTL values.
Correlate DNS resolution to suspicious IPs followed by encrypted or atypical C2 traffic.
CONTAINMENT: Block resolution and outbound connections to confirmed malicious or suspicious dynamic domains.
Sinkhole known C2-related domains to capture and study attacker traffic safely.
Isolate endpoints that repeatedly query dynamic domains associated with threat actor infrastructure.
COUNTERMEASURES: Implement DNS filtering for known malicious or high-risk dynamic DNS providers and domains.
Monitor for domains with abnormal registration characteristics, rapid IP changes, or short-lived lifetimes.
Use internal DNS logging and analytics to detect unusual hostname lookups indicative of C2.
FORENSICS: Review DNS logs to map all hostnames queried by compromised systems and associated resolved IPs.
Correlate domain resolution events with C2 sessions and attacker actions over time.
Feed identified domains and IPs into threat intelligence systems for future detection and blocking.

IDENTIFICATION: Detect use of uncommon or non-standard ports for known protocols (e.g., HTTP on high random ports, RDP on non-3389).
Identify long-lived outbound connections from user endpoints to external IPs over high or unusual port numbers.
Correlate non-standard port usage with suspicious processes or recently dropped binaries on the originating host.
CONTAINMENT: Block outbound traffic on non-standard ports from user and server segments unless explicitly required.
Temporarily restrict or monitor traffic from endpoints that initiated suspicious connections on unusual ports.
Reset suspicious sessions and enforce new egress filtering policies where gaps are identified.
COUNTERMEASURES: Define and enforce an allowed-port policy per segment, blocking unneeded ports by default.
Deploy anomaly detection on destination ports used by endpoints to spot deviations from normal behavior.
Regularly review firewall and proxy logs for emerging non-standard port usage trends.
FORENSICS: Collect connection logs for all non-standard port communication from compromised hosts.
Determine whether attackers used these ports solely for C2 or also for exfiltration and lateral movement.
Correlate with IDS/IPS alerts and process execution history to understand the full attack path.

IDENTIFICATION: Detect encrypted C2 traffic using TLS, SSH, or custom encryption where the destination, certificate, or handshake patterns do not match known legitimate services.
Identify endpoints establishing persistent encrypted connections to rare or newly registered domains.
Correlate encrypted channels with recent execution of malware, scripts, or tools on originating hosts.
CONTAINMENT: Block or terminate encrypted sessions to known malicious or unapproved destinations.
Isolate endpoints using suspicious encrypted channels while preserving network captures for analysis.
Revoke any credentials or keys suspected to be used for establishing attacker-controlled encrypted sessions.
COUNTERMEASURES: Implement TLS inspection or out-of-band decryption for high-risk segments where permitted by policy.
Maintain allow-lists of legitimate encrypted services and alert on connections outside those sets.
Monitor certificate metadata, JA3/JA4 fingerprints, and SNI information for anomalies indicative of C2 frameworks.
FORENSICS: Collect network captures and, where possible, decrypted traffic for suspected encrypted C2 sessions.
Analyze certificate chains, keys, and protocol parameters to attribute the channel to known threat tooling or actors.
Correlate encrypted C2 usage with attacker actions on the endpoint, including command execution, staging, and exfiltration.

IDENTIFICATION: Identify newly registered domains, VPS instances, or hosting accounts associated with adversary campaigns or suspicious registration patterns.
Correlate threat intelligence reports of attacker-owned infrastructure with internal connection attempts or scanning activity.
Detect internal systems resolving or connecting to domains or IPs that have been recently flagged as attacker-controlled staging or C2 infrastructure.
CONTAINMENT: Block access to confirmed adversary-owned domains, IP ranges, and cloud assets at perimeter and proxy controls.
Share indicators of attacker infrastructure with upstream providers or ISPs where possible.
Update internal blocklists, EDR policies, and mail filters with the identified adversary infrastructure indicators.
COUNTERMEASURES: Continuously ingest and correlate external threat intelligence feeds focused on newly acquired malicious infrastructure.
Monitor domain registration patterns, WHOIS data, and certificate transparency logs for attacker-linked naming or registration behaviors.
Implement egress filtering to limit outbound communications to only business-approved destinations and cloud providers.
FORENSICS: Document all internal systems that communicated with attacker-acquired infrastructure and when those connections occurred.
Correlate adversary infrastructure usage with observed phishing, malware delivery, or C2 activities in the environment.
Preserve DNS, proxy, and firewall logs related to the attacker infrastructure for long-term campaign analysis.

IDENTIFICATION: Identify use of compromised legitimate domains, websites, or cloud accounts as staging points, redirectors, or C2 hubs.
Correlate sudden reputation changes or abuse reports for previously benign domains that your environment communicates with.
Detect internal clients accessing legitimate infrastructure that has been repurposed to host malware, phishing content, or C2 frameworks.
CONTAINMENT: Block or tightly restrict access to compromised infrastructure until ownership and remediation status are verified.
Coordinate with the legitimate owner or provider of the compromised infrastructure when possible and appropriate.
Update security controls with temporary override rules to treat compromised legitimate infrastructure as hostile until cleared.
COUNTERMEASURES: Monitor for abuse reports, reputation changes, and IOC updates affecting commonly used SaaS and cloud providers.
Use domain categorization, SSL/TLS inspection (where allowed), and content inspection to detect and block abused infrastructure usage.
Maintain internal exception workflows so that once infrastructure is confirmed remediated, access can be restored in a controlled manner.
FORENSICS: Capture logs of all internal access to compromised infrastructure, including timestamps, users, and accessed resources.
Correlate compromised infrastructure usage with specific malware families, phishing campaigns, or threat actor clusters.
Preserve evidence of hosted malicious content (binaries, scripts, phishing pages) where lawful and feasible for later analysis.

IDENTIFICATION: Identify new or evolving malware, tooling, or exploit frameworks attributed to threat actors before they are deployed in your environment.
Correlate new capability development with test activity observed in sandbox detonations, honeypots, or decoy systems.
Detect patterns of staged but not yet fully weaponized scripts or binaries appearing in threat feeds or malware repositories.
CONTAINMENT: Add emerging malware and tool signatures to endpoint and network detection rules prior to widespread deployment.
Flag and restrict internal experimentation with unvetted offensive security tools or exploit frameworks.
Limit direct internet access from research and testing environments to reduce risk of accidental exposure.
COUNTERMEASURES: Maintain an internal malware and tooling knowledge base mapped to MITRE ATT&CK techniques.
Work with threat intelligence sources to track actor capability development and likely targeting patterns.
Use controlled environments and sandboxes to evaluate new malicious capabilities and pre-build detections for them.
FORENSICS: Archive samples of new capabilities for long-term analysis and retroactive detection testing.
Map developed capabilities to observed TTPs and threat actor clusters for campaign-level understanding.
Correlate capability development timelines with their first observed usage in your environment or sector.

IDENTIFICATION: Identify malware, exploits, access brokers, and tooling being sold or shared in underground ecosystems that target your sector.
Correlate newly obtained capabilities with known attack chains, especially ransomware, infostealers, and initial access brokers.
Monitor for reuse of purchased or shared malware families across multiple campaigns and infrastructures.
CONTAINMENT: Rapidly integrate IOCs, behavioral signatures, and YARA rules for newly obtained adversary capabilities.
Limit exposure of vulnerable services and software known to be targeted by widely available exploit kits.
Engage incident response planning when high-impact capabilities (e.g., zero-day exploit kits) become widely accessible.
COUNTERMEASURES: Continuously track threat marketplaces, leak sites, and dark web sources through trusted intel partners.
Prioritize patching and hardening for software and services targeted by commonly obtained exploit kits and malware.
Develop layered defenses for high-impact capabilities, such as credential theft, ransomware encryption, and remote access tooling.
FORENSICS: Map obtained capabilities to observed intrusions in your environment to understand attacker sourcing and ecosystem use.
Preserve examples of obtained malware, exploit modules, and builder tools for prevention testing and training.
Correlate capability acquisition timelines with spikes in related attack activity globally and within your sector.

IDENTIFICATION: Identify malware, payloads, or scripts being staged on external infrastructure such as cloud storage, paste sites, or code repositories.
Correlate URLs and hosting locations used as malware staging points with download attempts seen in internal logs.
Detect staged content that changes frequently or is obfuscated, indicating active preparation for delivery.
CONTAINMENT: Block access to staging URLs, domains, and IP addresses at network and web gateway layers.
Engage hosting providers, if possible, to remove staged malicious content.
Add staged payload hashes and signatures to endpoint protection and email filters.
COUNTERMEASURES: Monitor high-risk content delivery platforms for malware staging patterns relevant to your environment.
Use sandboxing to safely retrieve and analyze staged payloads before they are used against your users.
Deploy URL and content filtering tuned to detect known staging behaviors, including shortened or redirecting links.
FORENSICS: Preserve copies of staged payloads and metadata (timestamps, uploader info, hosting provider).
Correlate staged payload URLs with phishing, drive-by downloads, or loader activity seen in internal telemetry.
Analyze code and configuration in staged payloads to identify targeting, C2 infrastructure, and capabilities.

IDENTIFICATION: Track initial access brokers and leaked credential sets being advertised for sale related to your organization, vendors, or sector.
Correlate compromised account reports from third parties with observed suspicious logins in your environment.
Identify reuse of acquired access (credentials, session tokens, VPN access) across multiple attacker campaigns.
CONTAINMENT: Force credential resets, revoke tokens, and invalidate sessions for accounts suspected to be part of acquired access sets.
Temporarily restrict or harden remote access methods (VPN, SSO) when associated with known access broker activity.
Coordinate with partners or vendors whose accounts or infrastructure are being sold as access vectors into your environment.
COUNTERMEASURES: Use credential leak monitoring services and dark web monitoring to detect when your identities appear for sale.
Enforce MFA, conditional access, and device trust to make acquired credentials alone insufficient for compromise.
Limit standing access and move to just-in-time access models for privileged accounts.
FORENSICS: Analyze authentication logs for evidence of unauthorized logins using acquired credentials.
Correlate external access sale data with internal incidents to understand how acquired access was leveraged.
Preserve evidence of access broker listings or conversations for potential legal or law enforcement follow-up.

IDENTIFICATION: Detect external scanning of your internet-facing assets, including port scans, banner grabs, and service fingerprinting.
Correlate repeated scans against the same assets or subnets from specific IPs, ASNs, or cloud providers.
Identify scanning behaviors that map to known actor toolsets or campaigns in threat intelligence reports.
CONTAINMENT: Block or rate-limit abusive scanners at the edge where feasible.
Divert hostile scanning to honeypots or deception systems to gather further intelligence safely.
Notify upstream providers or ISPs about large-scale or clearly malicious scanning when appropriate.
COUNTERMEASURES: Continuously monitor perimeter telemetry for scanning patterns and maintain awareness of exposed services.
Regularly perform your own authenticated vulnerability scans and harden exposed services before attackers find them.
Use external attack surface management tools to see your environment as an attacker does and reduce unnecessary exposure.
FORENSICS: Preserve logs of scanning activity including source addresses, targeted ports, and timing.
Correlate early scanning behavior with later exploitation attempts against the same assets.
Feed observed scanners and patterns into threat intelligence platforms to track ongoing campaigns.

IDENTIFICATION: Identify phishing campaigns that appear aimed primarily at gathering information rather than delivering malware, such as credential harvesting or reconnaissance surveys.
Detect repeated information-gathering emails using pretexts to elicit organizational details, contacts, or internal workflows.
Correlate data submitted to attacker-owned forms or websites with subsequent targeted attacks or social engineering attempts.
CONTAINMENT: Block and remove identified phishing messages from user inboxes.
Disable or reset accounts that may have provided credentials or sensitive information through phishing portals.
Block access to attacker-controlled phishing domains and associated infrastructure.
COUNTERMEASURES: Educate users on reconnaissance-style phishing that asks for organizational details or verifies contact information.
Deploy email security controls to detect forms, credential harvesting pages, and suspicious embedded links.
Require MFA and conditional access so that stolen credentials alone are insufficient for compromise.
FORENSICS: Collect full phishing message samples, headers, and landing page content for analysis.
Determine what information was requested or successfully disclosed by victims.
Correlate phishing-for-information campaigns with later intrusion attempts, infrastructure, and threat actors.
